Sir,

English name ...............................................................
Age ...............................................................
Born Feb. 18, 1938

Katzie (New Westminster Agency)

Yes

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

With reference to the December Quarterly Return for the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, it is noted that pupil # 641 was sick in hospital during the quarter. The Principal has neglected to indicate the dates of absence. Pupil # 656 was placed in Nanaimo Hospital during the quarter; however, the Principal has neglected to indicate the date.

Pupil # 664 was discharged to attend Tsartlip School. The Principal has claimed 25 days grant but has neglected to indicate the date the pupil left the school.

For pupil # 666 the Principal has claimed 92 days grant as indicated in the Remarks Column. This pupil was truant. If the pupil was truant for even one day the Principal should not have claimed grant for that day.

It would be appreciated if you would advise the dates the above-mentioned children left the school or the period of their absences and instruct the Principal that on future Quarterly Returns this information must be indicated in the Remarks Column of the Return otherwise, it will be necessary to delay payment of the Per Capita Grant until this information is obtained.
Please advise the Principal that we have allowed 122 days grant for pupil # 677 and 107 days for pupil # 0645. These are the children for whom no applications for admission were received and for whom grant was claimed on the September Quarterly Return. We have now received the necessary applications for admission and have allowed the retroactive grant.

Jan. 16/53 - Information Pupils
641 and 664

Pupil 641 was sent after two days of illness at school, with the approval of the M.O. for observation to the Chemainus General Hospital, Dec. 17/52. Subsequently he missed a full week of class, the end of the term. This same pupil 641, as of Jan. 8/53 is discharged here and registered in the Nanaimo Indian Hospital where he has been admitted for treatment on that date.

Pupil 664 was discharged Oct. 25/52 at the request of the father who was now home from the Nanaimo Indian Hospital. As home conditions were improved, and the boy could attend a day school, Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Superintendent approved the discharge in favor of someone on our long waiting list.

I reported this discharge on Form 1069 Oct. 31/52. Sorry that through distraction, I overlooked reporting on quarterly Form 411 filed at the end of the term.

Trusting that this will clarify this matter and thanking you for calling my attention to it, I am

Sincerely yours,

RE: YOUR FILE 885-10 (E6)

With reference to your letter of the 26th instant, requesting information why certain children who were in attendance at Westholme, Tsartlip Consolidated and St. Catherine's Indian Day Schools were sent to the Kuper Island Residential School, rather than remaining at the day schools, I would advise that these children were sent to the Residential School as they were not being cared for at home by their parents or guardians, or they came from broken homes.

I can assure you they were not put in the Residential School without due consideration and investigation and while I, personally, do not recall the exact cause in each individual case, I know the conditions were unsatisfactory, not only from the point of view of this office, but also from that of the schools previously attended and the children themselves.

The father and mother of this child are both
blind and he was in poor physical condition, being undernourished
and with severe ear and skin ailments. It was obvious that he
was not being cared for at home and his mother threw out all the
medication and drugs given her for his use by the Health Services.

KUPER ISLAND INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

At the time of my visit to this school this summer (1922), the following matters were brought to my attention.

I found here the best gymnasium at any Indian school in Canada. There is a spectators' balcony, dressing rooms, lavatories and playrooms—all in the gymnasium building. There is a splendid band here, they need a few more instruments at this time. They have a splendid manual training equipment, but no instructor. Mr. Cairns suggests a Government manual training instructor to travel among the 5 or 6 residential schools on the mainland.

E. T. F.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF W. E. DITCHBURN,
INDIAN COMMISSIONER, VICTORIA, B. C. (P.O.BOX 666)
dated January 25, 1929.

Original on 600224.

Kuper Island School ------ The Principal stated that while he had a fair supply of tools purchased by the Department in 1915, six of the eight benches supplied them had been taken away for use at the Nanaimo Day School Manual Training room, and others would have to be supplied. He also informed me that the services of a manual training instructor from Ladysmith could be obtained, if necessary, but some arrangement would have to be made with regard to transporting him to and from the school each week. It may be possible that an addition to the staff will be made of a competent carpenter.
February 7, 1929.

Ottawa, May 14, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is making special efforts to improve the instruction in manual and vocational training for boys in the Indian schools of British Columbia. If this phase of our educational programme can be made more effective, it will greatly benefit the Indians of the Province. Most residential schools have a workshop or other space that can be used for vocational training. If steps to improve the workshop facilities should be taken at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, please cooperate with Mr. Indian Agent Lomas with a view to making a recommendation to the Department.

A thorough course in carpentry is the present aim. To this end, Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn has been authorized to supply benches and tools and there has been directed to you a text on manual training, job sheets in woodworking and a publication on how to work with tools and wood. Further, you have been authorized to present to Mr. Indian Agent Lomas reasonable accounts for materials with which to work.

The Department is desirous of having a qualified instructor for this work at all schools where this special training is being undertaken. Some schools have on the staff an officer who is well qualified for the activity and who can be released from other duties for the manual training classes. I understand there are summer courses for instructors in manual training in Vancouver and Victoria. Other Indian schools are so situated that they can secure the services of instructors from municipal schools. In this case, classes are held two or three times per week. The Department would like to know what arrangements you have made, or can make, for this important work. Do not hesitate to enlist the cooperation of Mr. Indian Agent Lomas, if the Department can be of any assistance.

At a later date, it is hoped to extend the vocational training to include gas engines and other machinery; and, whenever you believe this additional course should be given at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, you will please inform the Department. A copy of this letter is being directed to Mr. Lomas for his information.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Kuper Island,
via Chemainus,

Dear Sir:

In answer to your favored of 26th ultimo No 152-0-11 re manual training; benches were made last summer at the school, some tools were supplied; and according to instructions of Mr Ditchburn material to work with was bought to the amount of about $50.00.

The work is started under the direction of Mr Wiseman, member of the staff; class in the evening between 5-6; and during the regular work hours 6 boys in turn do necessary and practical work under the supervision of the instructor. Just now they are putting shingles on the barn; later on they will put new floors in the play-halls.

Re improving the present service this is very difficult under prevailing conditions. First of all, owing to the location of the school it is impossible to get an instructor from surrounding public schools for a few days a week. Then again by affecting to the work a member of the staff much of his time is taken up and many important improvements and necessary repairs are being put off for weeks and months.

Now if I am allowed to make a suggestion I would say that there should be one man more on the staff i.e.: one instructor for man training and gen.carpentry work: improvements and repairs. one mechanic for all machinery, boats and pipe system. one for farm and stock. one for all odd jobs in and around the house: bakery, furnace, garden etc. one for general discipline when pupils neither in class nor trade, asst.principal, on half day salary. - With this arrangement more time could be given to the pupils for their training, and proper care could be taken of things which begin to require more and more as the buildings are getting older.

But this can absolutely not be done with our present grant. Up till last spring I was about able to manage things by very careful administration. But since then many things seem to be making it more and more difficult every day: This summer I have been paying for meat as much as 28cts per pound by the quarter. Then 6 sisters who were getting $25.00 per month
have asked repeatedly for $50.00 which I have not been able to give so far. Now with this additional work which requires another man it is impossible to manage, with the actual grant.

In view then of these present conditions I humbly ask the Department kindly to consider the grant we were getting so far and to increase it in such a way as to make it possible to put the whole system on the above proposed basis with one man more, and a fair salary for the work that is done.

By doing this the Department takes away a great deal of my present worries and will always be assured of the devotedness of

Your obedient servant

July 23, 1930.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

Father Geurts, Principal of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, visited the Department today. He is desirous of erecting a utility building, approximately 24 x 40, in the centre of which will be a machine room and at either end a blacksmith shop and a repair shop. Underneath the space will be used for storing wood.

He has a very fine mechanic and they can erect it themselves, if we will provide about $800 worth of material. This could quite properly be a charge on B.C. Special and, as not more than $12,000 is being used for Education this year, I wish to recommend that $800 be allowed for the purpose.

During the next and the following years, Father Geurts hopes to provide a lathe, a drill and other equipment. Some of it will be purchased by the School, but they will also want help from time to time. This ought to prove a very useful training for the older boys.

[Signature]

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, August 9, 1930.

Sir:

Father Guerts, Principal of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, visited the Department some two weeks ago. He is desirous of erecting a utility building, approximately 20' x 40', in the centre of which will be a machine room and at the ends a blacksmith shop and a repair shop. The basement will be used for storing wood, etc. Father Guerts promised that he would be responsible for the erection of such a building if the Department would provide approximately $500 for materials. Will you please inform him that his request is granted and that he may purchase the materials without delay. The accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded through your office. Father Guerts is receiving a copy of this letter direct for his information. It is understood that the accounts will be paid from B. C. Special Vote.

Let me remind you of a short interview we had with Dr. Scott, the Deputy Minister, in your office at Victoria on Wednesday, August 19th, regarding the question of providing necessary equipment for carrying on the third year work of instruction in the Motor Mechanics class at Coqualeetza Residential School.

The equipment required by the instructor, and which should be in place within the next four weeks, is a Deisel or semi-Deisel engine; an automatic electric light motor system for a medium sized fishing launch; and a few tools. The Deisel engine we thought would cost between $500.00 and $600.00. Mr. Edwards found one, a used engine, which would answer all purposes of instruction, much cheaper.

1 Scandia 7 horsepower, semi-Deisel engine, 1 cylinder, 2 cycle, equipped with direct reversal and also with reverse clutch. It is a used engine and has been running for eight months. It is in good running order, complete with extra parts $200.00

1 Matthews automatic electric light motor system, model H, 32 volt, 400 watt. This is in splendid condition and good working order 150.00

1 hand drill and drills 12.50

1 vise, 4" 10.65

1 solder copper and solder 2.45

1 12" Crescent wrench 2.75

1 8" Crescent wrench 1.65

1 14" pipe wrench 2.55

2 tanks for engine test purposes, complete with fittings 15.00

1 blackboard (present one is worn out) 15.00

Estimated freight 10.00

$422.55
Both Mr. Edwards and I have been to Vancouver and looked over a number of engines, used and new. The new ones are out of the question at the present time. We could have obtained a used Deisel engine, 20 horsepower, for $500.00 but came across this semi-Deisel. The principles involved in the working of the Deisel and the semi-Deisel are exactly the same, and the price of the 7 horsepower semi-Deisel is such a saving that we are justified in recommending its purchase.

The small electric light plant for a fishing boat is part of the Motor Mechanics third Year course and it is infinitely better to learn its operation in gas boats than to continue the use of unsafe coal oil lamps which many Indians use.

While not an expert, I have personally seen and examined the engine and the lighting plant recommended by Mr. Edwards and feel satisfied we could not do better. They are good value.

The above, with what was supplied the Motor Mechanics Department last year furnishes sufficient equipment for instructional purposes in the first, second and third years course.

At the interview to which I referred, I carried away the impression and was encouraged to believe that, when needed, this material would be provided by the Department from a fund you have for such purposes.

I have no hesitation in recommending a grant of $425.00 be allowed for the material, tools and equipment as above outlined.

Let me thank you for the interest you have taken in the past in this enterprise of teaching Indian youths, who will most of them be fishermen owning their own motor boats for fishing, how to run their engines and make their own repairs. Such training is certainly essential to their happiness and prosperity. To my mind the success of this branch of technical training warrants further development.

Thanking you for your continued interest.

Yours very truly,

G.H. Bailey,
Principal.

Owing to the impossibility of getting an outsider for the manual training at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, the Department has kindly provided for part salary of a special man on the staff, Bro. Wiseman, who is about 40 years of age, was trained as carpenter in an Industrial School in the East, and as such has spent over 10 years in Kuper Island.

In the course of the year about 30 pupils have been receiving manual training instructions, each pupil one half day a week.

Besides this general course 6 pupils have been receiving special training in carpentry. In the manual training shop the pupils have made useful things for in and around the house, such as ladders, step-ladders, tables, benches, desks etc. The carpenters have to their credit an addition to our gym 35/40, with a complete gymnastic outfit; some of the things had been previously supplied by the Department, others are home-made.

In the past year 5 tons of cement has been used for all kind of improvements and 6 boys have been taught how to mix this properly. They also were taught how to make forms for general building purposes and for more artistic work.

Re gas boats, the bigger boys take turns, at least twice a week, in running a boat, for the regular trips we have to make to Ogemminus.

Finally 4 boys take turns in the bakery under the direction of a man in charge.

The girls too are properly prepared for their future life, by competent sisters both in the kitchen & sewing room. Pupils over 14 take regular turns in the kitchen where they are taught gen. cooking and baking bread, cakes etc.

In the laundry the bulk of the washing is done by machine; but besides this every wash day there is always some hand washing and hand ironing.

In the sewing room the girls do all the darning and mending. The older more advanced girls learn machine sewing. They make all their own dresses and also the shirts of the boys. In fancy needle work and crochet they compete most favorably with the whites as has been proved by the many exhibition prices.
All the pupils are keenly interested in this kind of work. The best articles produced, sent to the local exhibition, have given a real name to the school. The Indians are proud of their children and their work. And sometimes you hear the whites express the wish to have a school like Kuper for their children.

The results more than justify the expenditure.

Principal.

Vocational Training:

There is little to add to previous reports on the Vocational Training given at Kuper Island.

The girls make all their clothes with the exception of underwear. Of course all mending, darning, sewing, is taught with great care by the Sisters in charge. The Boys' shirts are made by the Girls and the Singer sewing machines are in constant use. There are only two good Singer machines and one Singer Tailor Machine supplied during the past few years which are of much use now. The other machines are quite worn out. In view of the very good work being done and the large quantity of clothes made up here, I would strongly recommend the supply of ONE NEW TAILOR SINGER MACHINE at the present time. I have in mind letters received from the Department in the past with regard to the number of machines thought to be necessary in these schools, but am of the opinion that another heavy machine is badly needed here.

The work in Manual Training is still under the charge of Brother E. Wiseman. I inspected the Manual Training Shop, though there were no boys working there at the time. The work done during the year appears to be much the same as has been reported on previously. The M.T. Class under guidance reshingled the roof of the Gymnasium Building. The Department supplied the shingles. The work looks as if it had been very well carried out. While inspecting the M.T. Shop, I noticed that the shavings had been swept under the benches which are against the walls. This is a very bad arrangement. It is very untidy, and a spark might cause a fire. I asked the Principal to see that the shavings after a day's work be swept up before the boys left and that these shavings be placed in a box or barrel kept for this purpose. They could then be taken to the Boiler Room and used to light fires, etc., or just burned if not wanted. I would suggest that if the Department were writing to the Principal my suggestion be endorsed and instructions given that the M.T. Shop be kept clear of saw dust and shavings when the boys are not working there.
Ottawa, March 1st, 1935.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Barry's report regarding his visit to the Kuper Island Indian Residential School on January 29th and 30th, last.

The Inspector reports that, while inspecting the manual training shop, he noticed that the shavings had been swept under the benches, which are against the wall.

The Department considers this a bad arrangement owing to the fact that a spark might cause a fire. I have, therefore, to request that, after each day's work, the shavings be swept up before the boys leave the manual training room and these shavings should be placed in a box or barrel kept for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Ottawa, February 11, 1937.

Dear Father Geurts:

I am deeply interested in vocational instruction and in the best ways and means of promoting this instruction in our residential schools and also in our day schools.

I have read very carefully a report submitted by you to the Department on April 17th, 1934, in which you referred to a number of pupils in your school and the progress they were then making in carpentry work. This report indicates that vocational instruction in your school was very effectively organized when you wrote this particular report.

I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to supply me with information, indicating just what progress has been made by the students who took this course of instruction, after their departure from school. I should also like to have from you an expression of opinion as to the attitude of the students to this work and also the attitude of the Indian parents. The Minister of the Department expressed the view in Parliament, a few days ago, that our courses of study should become gradually and steadily more vocational in character. In seeking this information from you, I am simply making an attempt to carry out the policy the Minister has in mind. Any additional suggestions you may care to offer would be very much appreciated.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Jos. Geurts, S.M.M.,
Principal,
Kuper Island Residential School,
Kuper Island, via Chemainus, B.C.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa.

Re: Manual Training Instructor
Kuper Island Residential School

I have been informed by the principal of the above mentioned school that the former Manual Training Instructor, Mr. W.H. Morris, has resigned.

Attached is an application from the Principal for the appointment of Brother Wiseman as Manual Training Instructor. Inspector Davey has had an opportunity to see some of Brother Wiseman's work and he appears to be a capable craftsman. Unfortunately, due to a rheumatic condition he is unable to take the boys for sports. He also has a pronounced French accent and his English is none too good. The Inspector feels however that Mr. Wiseman would make a satisfactory substitute in the manual training shop for the remainder of the current academic year and I would recommend that he be classified in the lowest bracket for salary purposes.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
25th March, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, the Department approves the temporary appointment for the balance of the current academic year of Brother Wiseman as Manual Training Instructor at the Kuper Island Residential School. An allowance of $75.00 a month will be paid towards his salary.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Re: Vocational Training Equipment
Kuper Island Residential School

Attached is a letter from Superintendent Moore dated May 3rd and a requisition from the above mentioned school for two sewing machines, one planer with a 2 H.P. motor and one band saw.

The Reverend Principal has indicated that the planer will make it possible to salvage a considerable amount of lumber from a building which is to be dismantled at the residential school. It is felt that although the cost of the planer and motor will be approximately $500.00, according to quotations received, this expenditure would be recovered through the use of salvaged material. The supplying of power tools to this residential school is justified in that there is an opportunity for graduate pupils to make use of this type of equipment when they leave school. On the reserve adjoining the school property an Indian has established a boatbuilding business in which he makes use of power equipment of this type.

It is recommended that the purchase of the above items be authorized, with the exception of the sewing machines with which the school appears to be adequately supplied.

It is considered that this expenditure is a legitimate charge against the B.C. Special Vote.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Kuper Island Residential School.

A letter recently received here from the Principal of the above school, stated that he was submitting requisitions for Manual Training shop equipment and sewing machines, as discussed with Mr. Davey during his last visit.

I may say that this is the first intimation I've had about the Planer, and no mention was made of anything like it last year, when the Estimates were being prepared. I think the Reverend Principal has misunderstood, but in case the Department will buy this for him, without it being included in the Estimates, I will send it forward, anyway. Should it not be in order now, I will appreciate its return so that I may hold it until the Estimates are being prepared for next year.

The two sewing machines asked for are badly needed, I understand, as their present machines (eight of them) are not in good repair and insufficient for the school's requirements.

If in order, I would recommend approval of all the equipment asked for, as it is impossible to get an instructor to go to that school to work without equipment. The planer would save a lot of money in the price of lumber, as well as good training for the boys.

R. H. MOORE,
Superintendent,
Cowichan Agency.

PLANNER

This item would occasion considerable savings for the reason that old material could be salvaged and turned in for good use in the shop; also because rough lumber is always available at low cost and could be planed in the shop in sizes to suit the purpose.

It is this requirement of lumber in small widths or sizes that bring up the cost of lumber for cabinet work.

As there is a prospect of having to tear down old buildings, much of the lumber salvaged could thus be used for various projects.

A 3 H.P. motor would be required to operate this planer.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of 22nd instant,(Z-II-2) stating the Department are not prepared to make a grant towards the salary of Mr. John Carlsen, whose appointment as Manual Training Instructor at this school was recommended by Inspector Davey. I presume this is due to the fact that Mr. Carlsen could not produce a certificate for woodwork, and I can well see that this is very much required. It is however the intention of Mr. Carlsen to obtain this as soon as possible through a correspondence course if possible. He tells me he has had training in woodwork in an Institution for deaf and dumb in Vancouver and later taught woodwork there.

I beg to state that otherwise Mr. Carlsen is most qualified in handling boys on the playground and elsewhere and is well liked by the boys. An all-around athlete and capable of coaching any line of sports, he would be the right man for this school, considering that his defect of hearing which does not handicap him to much extent with his hearing aid, makes that he is satisfied to isolate himself on an island, having no desire to associate with others outside, which makes it most convenient in a place like this. If he could better his position as a woodworker and obtain the certificate required, I feel some consideration should be extended him, for it is no easy matter to find a good playground supervisor who is also a good shop instructor and willing to live on an island.

Therefore may I kindly ask if the Department will consider maintaining the Instructor we have had these past years, Brother Wiseman, an experienced carpenter, at the salary granted for the term ending June last, and this for the next three months, during which time Mr. Carlsen will endeavor to obtain a certificate.

Yours very truly,

J. Camirand

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir,

The Stanley Frank deceased today was brought to me on March 1st with a note from the doctor at Chemainus stating that he had tubercular meningitis. I sent him to St. Joseph's Hosp. at Comox and did a spinal puncture the following day and examination of the fluid confirmed the former diagnosis.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

To the Honorable the Minister of
the Interior, Ottawa, Ont.

The Petition of the Indian Council and
Chiefs of Port Simpson B.C.

Humbly Sheweth:

That hitherto there has not been any
boarding-school for Indian boys at Port
Simpson which has received support from
the Dominion Government, but a small school
has for some years been maintained and a
school building erected by the Charity of the
Methodist Church through its Missionary Society
and friends.

That during at least six months in
each year mostly our people are engaged in
fishing and hunting which make it necessary
for them to be away from Port Simpson during that
time and they are obliged to take their boys with
them, thereby depriving them of educational facilities.

That the Mission at Port Simpson was started
twenty-two (22) years ago by the Methodist Church
and the Indians here are almost all Methodists,
and are a peace-loving, law-abiding, and loyal
people, so that during all that time no serious
breach of the peace has occurred, whereas at the
Mission of some other denominations there has
been frequent disturbances which entailed expense
and trouble upon the Government.

That the existing private Institution
maintained in Manner aforesaid is entirely inade-
quate for the requirements of the large Indian
population of Port Simpson which appears
by the Annual Report of the Department of
Indian Affairs, 1896, to be 476 (see p. 559).
Our people do not wish to send their children away to be educated at a neighboring village when the boarding school is under the supervision of another denomination when there are so many children at Port Simpson, but they desire a school where the boys can be kept during this long absence as afforded and where they can be educated under the direction of a teacher of their own denomination.

Your petitioners therefore pray that a boarding school for the education, care and maintenance of Indian boys be established at Port Simpson under the supervision of the Methodist Church.

And your petitioners will ever pray,

Vancouver, February 1st, 1905.

Geo. Morrow, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

As instructed by the authorities of the Methodist Church, I beg leave to apply, through you as Indian Agent to the Department of Indian Affairs to grant that the two Boarding Schools at Fort Simpson, known as the Crosby Girls Home and the Port Simpson Boys Home, be combined into an Industrial Institute with all the larger powers and privileges pertaining thereto and thus the better enable it to meet the needs of the very large school population of Port Simpson and the surrounding territory.

In support of this request I most respectfully present the following reasons for your consideration and that of the Department.

1. Port Simpson as a town has the largest Indian population in British Columbia, numbering between 700 and 800.

2. It is the acknowledged centre of the Queen Charlotte Island Indians E.G. Skidegate and Massett and of the Nass River Indians, E.G. Kincolith, Greenville etc., aggregating in all about 2300 Indians.

3. In these communities there are scores of large boys and young men as in Port Simpson who need the advantages of just such trades as are taught in an Industrial Institute and which are not now afforded them.

4. The Indian Population are keenly alive to this need and feel the urgent necessity of having this Institute established in their midst. This need they have felt for years past and have been constantly clamoring for such an Institute and are earnestly asking for it now.

5. The above mentioned Government Boarding Schools are well equipped, well patronized and doing excellent work, but their efficiency would be immensely increased and the needs of the situation would be very much more completely met were they unified and expanded into an Industrial Institute. It would also be in harmony with the fitness of things that the largest Indian Community of British Columbia should receive this recognition of its needs when so many smaller places have so long been thus favored by the Indian Department.

Trusting that this petition on behalf of the Indians as well as the Department will receive most earnest and favorable consideration both from you and the Department,

I remain most respectfully yours,

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the letters from Messrs MacPherson and Sloan, Members of Parliament, who forward communications addressed to them by the Rev. R. Whittington, Superintendent of Methodist Missions in B.C., regarding certain applications made by him to the Department for grants for the establishment of an industrial school at Port Simpson and assistance towards the erection of a Principal's dwelling at Coqualeetsa Institute, and to the reverend gentleman's remarks relative to applications which have been submitted to the Department by the Roman Catholics for additional aid to their schools, I beg to say that the Department is not making any increase this year to the Roman Catholic schools or establishing any new institutions for them.

On the 16th March last, Mr. Supt. Vowell forwarded a letter from Mr. Agent Robertson covering an application from the Principal of Kuper Island Industrial school for an additional allowance for 25 pupils at that institution. Mr. Vowell was informed that the Department could not entertain this application favorably at present.

In February last Mr. MacPherson, M.P., left a petition with the Department from the Chiefs of the Squamish tribe for the conversion of the Squamish
boarding school into an industrial institute, and on
the 13th of that month, Mr MacPherson was advised that
the Department could not comply with this request
as it considered it inadvisable to increase the num-
ber of industrial schools in B.C. at present. Mr
MacPherson replied on the 22nd Feb., that he was very
sorry for the stand taken by the Department in this
instance and he would like very much if it would take
the matter up and ask the Agent for a report. In com-
pliance with this request, Mr Vowell was written to,
but up to the present no reply has been received.

As I understand the situation in B.C., it is
not the Department's intention to increase the number
of industrial schools in that province at present.
If it is ever thought advisable to add to their num-
ber, the Methodists would be fairly entitled to con-
sideration, as out of a total population of 25,234, they
have 3,130 adherents with one industrial school,
while the Church of England with 4,017 have three
industrial schools and the Roman Catholics five for
11,555 members of their church, making nine industrial
schools in all. In addition to the industrial schools
there are eight boarding schools and thirty day
schools in operation. The eight boarding schools are
equally divided between the Methodists, Roman Catholics,
Church of England and Presbyterians, two to each.

When Dr Whittington was in Ottawa last
winter he discussed the claims of his church with you
in my presence and it was decided that he should re-
ceive a sufficient grant to complete the Port Simp-
son day school building and that the question of con-
tributing towards the erection of the Principal's
residence at Coqualeetza, although decided against on
several occasions, would be again considered when the Supplementary Estimates were being dealt with. I may state that $1500.00 is placed in this estimate for this school.

The question of converting the Port Simpson boarding school into an industrial school was also referred to and I understood him to say that he was willing to let it remain in abeyance for the present.

I consider it unwise to make any changes in the existing schools until a definite school policy has been decided upon.

OTTAWA, 9th May, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the petitions hereunder from residents of Port Simpson and Chiefs and Councillors of the Port Simpson Band for the amalgamation of the Boys and Girls Boarding schools at that place into an industrial school, transmitted to the Department by Rev. Mr. Grenfell, resident Methodist minister at that place, I beg to say that Rev. Mr. Whittington, Superintendent of Methodist Missions in B.C., submitted a similar proposition to the Department a few months ago personally and again by letter of the 18th March last, when he was informed that the Department regretted that it did not at present see its way clear to meet his wishes in this direction, and Mr. Macpherson M.P. and Mr. Sloan, M.P., who had written the Department in behalf of Dr. Whittington's project, were similarly informed.

Dr. Whittington in support of his application claims that Port Simpson is the largest Indian centre in B.C., and the town has an Indian population of 703 all of whom are Methodists, who have Indian adherents in the North-West Coast Agency to the number of 204. He claims that there are scores of large boys and young men in this district (including Port Simpson) who need the advantages of just such trades as are taught in an industrial institute, and which are not now afforded them. He says that the
Indian population feel the urgent necessity of having this institution established in their midst.

I think he has reserved his principal reason for the last. It is that the largest Indian community in B.C. should receive recognition when so many smaller places have so long been thus favored by the Indian Department.

With regard to the needs of Port Simpson which is the principal settlement in this Agency, I may say that there were 157 children of school age at this place. There are three schools now in operation at this point; the Day school with an enrollment of 62 last quarter; the Girls Home with 45 and the Boys Home with 24 pupils, making a total of 131 children attending school, which is not a bad showing for Indians. I doubt if this showing can be equaled in many white settlements.

The Women's Missionary Society of the Methodist Church established the Girls school (which is called the Crosby Home) nearly thirty years ago and put up expensive buildings costing the Society from $8000.00 to $10,000 with accommodation for about 50 resident pupils. This school was conducted solely at the cost of the Society until the year 1892 when a grant for 20 pupils at $60 per capita was made by the Government. This number has now been increased to 35 and the school is still conducted by the above named Society, which works independently of the Methodist Missionary Society, which is carrying on the Boys Home and the Day School.

The Boys Home was established in 1888 under the auspices of the Methodist Church and it only
received the Departmental grant of $60 per cap. for 10 pupils on the 1st July 1902, and last year this was increased to 20.

A new day school building is under construction at Port Simpson, which will accommodate all the children in the town and the Department has agreed to pay the cost of the materials used in its erection which will amount to about $1900.00.

At present all the Indians in this Agency make their living by fishing and hunting, chiefly fishing. They make good wages and are much better off than the usual run of Indians, and I fail to see what special benefit the establishment of an Industrial school would be to them, as their present occupation affords them ample means of subsistence, and any trades instruction they might receive in such a school would never enable them to compete with white mechanics.

The whole object of the petition, as I see it, is to obtain more money. The per capita allowance to boarding schools in B.C. is only $60 per head, while the grant to Industrial schools is $130.00 for each pupil. Of course the increased grant would be a great relief to the Women's Association and the Methodist Missionary Society, which are now taxed to keep to keep the two institutions in operation with only $60.00 a head.

There are 9 Industrial schools in operation in B.C., and the Methodists have control of only one, the Roman Catholics having 5 and the Ch. of England three. The census returns show that out of a population of 25,234 Indians, the Methodists have 3,130 adherents as against 11,556 Roman Catholics and 4,017 Anglicans in the Province. The Presbyterians
have only 303, and the religious belief of the 3500 nomadic Indians is not given. Basing their claim on the census, the Methodists would be entitled to more industrial schools if it were the policy of the Department to increase their number. It is for the Department to decide whether the Industrial school offers sufficient superior advantages over the other class of schools to justify it in establishing more.

Port Simpson, B.C. February 16th, 1918.

To the Government of Canada, & the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church of Canada—

We the undersigned male members of the Port Simpson band of Indians, humbly present our petition for the erection of an Industrial School on the Port Simpson Reserve.

We would bring forward for your consideration a few of the reasons why we think our petition should be granted.

1. This is the largest Indian village in all of northern British Columbia, having a population of over 700 Indian people.

2. We have had a Boarding School for boys for a great number of years, which has been closed recently, because the buildings were no longer suitable for the purpose. This School was always supplied to its capacity with boys.

3. We now have a Boarding School for girls, under the management of the Nomans Missionary Society of the Methodist Church, with accommodation for 40 girls. This School is full, & girls on a waiting list. We feel strongly that our boys should receive an equal training with our girls.

4. No other School on the Coast or in the Interior can adequately minister to our needs, & we have in Port Simpson & tributary Indian villages, enough children to supply such an Institute.

5. Because we are within 25 miles of Prince Rupert,—the Western terminus of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway,—this village should be an outstanding one, of which the residents, the Government, & the Church can be justly proud, & to which we can welcome tourists & others, & show them the adequate provision that has been made for the advancement of the younger generation of Indians.

6. The labor conditions yearly becoming more acute, insist that our young people should be more thoroughly equipped to take their just position in the development of this Northern country.
1. The Chiefs & adult males of the Fort Simpson Band of Indians, this day, in meeting assembled, unanimously agreed to set aside six acres of the Reserve, for the use of such an Institution, the Government to select the site of such school.

2. Our Reserved lands are not suitable for the pursuit of agriculture, so that the training provided at the Coqualeetza Institute in farming, is in great measure lost on our boys. A similar Institute, if built at Hazelton, would be open to like objection. We require, here on the Coast, an Industrial Institute where training can be given in engineering, mechanics, boat building, carpentry, etc.

3. There is a Hospital adjoining the Reserve, so that the pupils could have close medical supervision, and hospital care when necessary.

4. While the soil here is not as productive as that of the interior, it is well suited to the growing of various produce. Freight rates on the Steamer from the Southern Cities, are quite reasonable, so that the expense of operating an Institute would probably be no greater here than in the interior. The question, primarily, is not one of land, but of the education of children, & we believe that our children would be best served by a coast Institution.

5. If conditions remain as at present, the girls graduating from the Girls' Hose, will not find the boys of the village, with inferior training, congenial, & the tendency will be away from marriage, with the attending dangers of a nearby Coast city.

6. The Government & Church know, by past experience, that a boys' Hose can be successfully maintained at this place, & we feel a school should be reopened here, before other Institutes are undertaken elsewhere.

Address of Joseph Bradley.

Mr. Chairman, Friends of the village & Chiefs.-

We thank God & the King. We are thankful to God for sparing Rev. Mr. Arnup to come and meet with us
in Port Simpson. I have the pleasure of asking him what authority he has. You remember this world is all a great race. It is many years past since the Tsimsheans started to run a race against two countries—the Japanese & Chinese. The Japanese are ahead of us—here we are behind. We are thankful to the Government for sending us teachers to train our children. We greet every skilful worker. First Ministers were sent amongst us and also Schools, and we have always wished our children to have more education. We are standing still while the Japanese are distancing us in the race. We are asking for a long time for an Industrial School. I have travelled considerably, and have seen various countries and schools, and I would like to know why we haven't one here? I saw one at Tacoma which was excellent. Why cannot we have as good a one as the Americans?

Address of Matthew Johnston.

I wish to speak to you about the School. When Mr. Ferrier was here last he said the Government was going to build an Industrial School here—a better one than the one at Chilliwack. I would like to ask Mr. Arnup what kind of a School the Government intends building here?

When Mr. Ferrier came he wanted a block of
land for the School. The second time he came he wanted six acres. It was not our fault at that time that the School was not built,—Mr. Ferrier changed the amount of land he required. He told us that the building would be of brick, concrete and woodwork.

We want a good school. We will give the six acres for a good school, as Mr. Ferrier has asked, and we would like to have the school right away. We have plenty of Indian carpenters here to help put up the school, so that white carpenters will not be required. We also have a blacksmith shop.

I am glad to meet you, Mr. Arnup, with a smiling face. We smile back at you. Mr. Raley did his best to have the school while he was here, and now I think Doctor Spencer should be well pleased.

Address of Moses Johnston.

Mr. Chairman. I wish to return thanks, on behalf of the audience, for the privilege of talking with Rev. Mr. Arnup of the Missionary Society, for sending the Gospel all over the country. We now can tell what is right and what is wrong. These last few days our thoughts have been fixed on the new School, which we have long talked about. It is the earnest wish, Mr. Arnup, of the village, that you will tell us whether
this school has been passed over to some other place, or how it now stands. I believe, Mr. Arnup, that this will bring the question to a conclusion. If you will answer this, we can then go on to further discussion, if it has not been passed over to another village. We thank you for your kind attention.

Address of Rev. J. H. Arnup, B.A.

Mr. Chairman and members of this meeting,

I do not need to tell the men how glad I am to be among them. If I did not wish to be among them, I would not have come so far to meet them. It has been my wish to visit the Coast ever since I entered the employ of the Missionary Society. When Rev. Dr. Chown and Rev. Mr. Farrell were here, I wished to come, but was prevented. About a year ago I hoped to come, but was disappointed. So you can understand why, when I did come, I had a wide smile on my face. I am not used to smiling on people I do not wish to see. Also, since I came, the Missionaries and the people have all smiled on me.

You wish me to talk about the matter of the School which has brought us together. My interest in this question is all the greater because for a number of years I taught school myself. The people who neglect
the education of the children are like those who in the spring time neglect to cultivate their garden, and in the fall find nothing has grown. I was glad to hear you thank the Government and the Church for the schools you have. It is well for us to remember that we first had the Missionary,- afterwards the schools, which at first were supplied and paid for by the Church. Now the schools given by the Government for the people are assisted by the counsel of Mr. Ferrier, who waits upon the Government each year and makes suggestions re the better assistance to the Indian schools. All the Missionary Officials are in favour of Port Simpson having a School. Mr. Ferrier has advocated it for years. Dr. Wrench and Mr. Raley have both told me they thought Port Simpson should have an Industrial School. Dr. Spencer and Dr. Large have told me they thought there should be a school here. This is the position of our Church.

The Government is also concerned in this question. Mr. Ferrier first brought it to the attention of the Government when he first asked the people for the small piece of land. The Government thought,- and I think they were right,- that a small piece of land was not sufficient for the kind of school they wanted to build. After discussion, the Government promised to build the school if more land was granted. Mr. Ferrier came and asked for six acres, but the people voted
against it. It was a great disappointment to Mr. Ferrier and the Missionary Society. Mr. Ferrier had to go back to the Government and say, the people would not give the land. This was after the plans had been partly drawn and the money granted. The plans had to stop, and the money used for other purposes.

You ask me if this school has been passed over for another place, and I will tell you exactly what I think. We needed two or three schools in British Columbia. Mr. Ferrier thought the Port Simpson school should be built first, and that is why he asked the Government for it. When he was unable to get the land for the Port Simpson School, he asked the Government to go on with one of the other schools.

As you know, for many years we have had land at Hazelton, which Dr. Crosby got for school purposes. Mr. Ferrier thought the Port Simpson school should first be built, but when he failed here, he asked for the school at Hazelton. The Government said they would go on with it, and if the war had not broken out the school at Hazelton would have been started. But the war called for so much expenditure that all building of schools was left until after the war. So far as I know, it was not intended that the school at Hazelton should minister to the children at Port Simpson. In that way it is true to say that the Simpson school has not been passed
over for another place. After the war when the Government starts again to build schools for us, they will have this record.

1.- A school which they planned for Port Simpson, but which was stopped because of not having lands available.

2.- The school at Hazelton for which they had land. I do not know which of these two schools the Government will go ahead with first. They will not build both at once. It is your business as a people's Counsel to show the Government why they should go ahead with the school at Port Simpson. You have taken the first step in passing unanimously yesterday at your meeting a resolution to grant the land. I think you should restate this in a resolution from this meeting and that copies should be sent to Mr. Ferrier, the Government, and the Missionary Society. I think also you should draw up a petition setting out the reasons why you think the first school built, would be built here. In dealing with the Government and the Church, the people who show the best reasons, will get their request granted. No one can state your needs better than yourselves and the Missionaries with you.

I do not know what action the Government will take and therefore I cannot state which school will be built first, but I can promise that I will tell what I
have seen and heard of the needs here, to the Missionary Board.

One has asked me what authority I have. If that means what authority I have to do, I haven't any. My position is to get the facts for the Missionary Board, and explain to them as their representative these facts so that they will know what to do. That is why I have come here. And when I go back and tell them how you have smiled on me and about this meeting they will feel better than they did when word came that the people of Port Simpson would not grant the site for a school.

I am sorry for having spoken so long, but I wish to place the matter clearly before you.

I thank the Chairman, Interpreter, Chiefs and people for the careful hearing they have given me.

This is a centre, and the tributary places would send children here,- as they look to Port Simpson for leadership. I think we should have a petition drawn up and signed, so that Mr. Arnup may have a copy for the Board.
We have granted the six acres on the understanding it is to be an Industrial School that will be built.

MEETING OF FORT SIMPSON DISTRICT: METHODIST CHURCH OF CANADA.
HELD AT PRINCE RUPERT, B.C., September 1919.

RESOLUTION
MOVED BY Rev. J. K. Macdonald, B.A.
SECONDED BY Rev. J. H. Macdonald, B.A.

WHEREAS it has been apparent since the closing of the BOYS' BOARDING SCHOOL at Fort Simpson, B.C., by the Department of Indian Affairs and the Methodist Church of Canada, that no provision exists in Northern British Columbia and north of Alert Bay for the residential school accommodation of Indian boys for whom a boarding school education would be preferable to that of an Indian day school;

and whereas it is probable that considerably over 100 boys could be secured for enrolment if such facilities were available;

and WHEREAS the Crosby Girls' Boarding School at Fort Simpson, having accommodation for an enrolment of 40 grant earning pupils in residence while there is always a larger number seeking admission, and the building is old, poorly lit and insufficiently ventilated;

and WHEREAS Indian boys are being sent over 500 miles to the south to attend boarding schools, often contrary to the wishes of parents who would wish to see them in a school nearer home;

and WHEREAS it is deemed to be in the best interests of Indian education in these parts to have a larger building or buildings for the accommodation of about 150 or 200 pupils of both sexes, either under one roof or separately as may be most desirable;

and WHEREAS a desirable site for such a building can be located either within or outside the Fort Simpson Indian Reserve:

BE IT THEREFORE RESOLVED that this meeting of the Fort Simpson District representatives of the Methodist Church of Canada go on record as being favourable to the establishment of such an institution; and that notice of the resolution be sent to: The Women's Missionary Society, Toronto;
The Supt of Indian Education (Mr. Ferrier);
The Deputy Superintendent Gen.of Indian Affairs,
The Indian Agent and
C.W. Peck, V.C., M.P.

Carried unanimously.
Sir,

In accordance with the terms of the attached resolution I herewith enclose such resolution for your perusal.

The District Meeting is in urgent hope of speedy action in this matter and I therefore beg leave to heartily commend this to your very favourable consideration.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Secretary.
November 30, 1919.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with regard to the establishment of an Indian boarding school at Fort Simpson. I am fully in sympathy with the spirit which actuated the District Meeting in this matter, and I greatly appreciate the devoted interest which the Methodist Church has shown with regard to Indian education. I regret, however, to inform you that I am unable to see any present prospect of undertaking the erection of such a boarding school.

We are of course prepared to keep up our present establishment for Indian education throughout the country, and to support our schools to the fullest extent that our parliamentary appropriation will allow, but the erection of new school buildings, which would involve such a large initial expenditure at this time, owing to the high cost of material and rates of wages, will have to be carefully considered in connection with the present financial situation.

The present need for public economy places stringent limitations upon our expenditure, which, as you will readily understand, are very difficult, and in some cases, impossible to surmount. I regret that I am unable to give you more encouragement in this matter.

Yours truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. T.H. Nuttall,
Pastor,
First Methodist Church,
Prince Rupert, B.C.

On behalf of the people of Fert Simpson, we are petitioning for a school such as will educate the children of this and surrounding villages. (By this we mean boys & girls)

We believe that it met the policies of the Govt. and that it is met for the welfare of the community, that we still remain illiterate.

We may mention here, that the younger generation, at the present time, are more or less illiterate and that more progress was made by the older generation, (whose ages range from 35 to 40 yrs.) and the younger generation have not attained the same standards as the older.

This through no fault of their own, the main fault being, "There are no boarding schools in this vicinity, at which they can attend. The nearest school, being at Sardis, which has many drawbacks, to discourage pupils from here. One of the chief drawbacks being, "To acclimatize the students from the north to a different locality. Many have returned only to become invalids, so that it seems useless to try and educate a student, in surroundings in which it is difficult for them to maintain their proper health.

With suitable Industrial School, one that teach, students, occupations that are suitable for his or her surroundings or locality; will be, for bettering of the country and will turn out a citizen that will be able to meet the requirements of this competitive age.

That Fert Simpson, being the central Village in Northern B.C., and serves as head-quarters for the surrounding Tribes would be the best place to build such a school.

The people of Fert Simpson remember that when this subject of a school, was placed before them, they rejected the idea at that time, without considering the injury they were inflicting on the community, and further, the people that rejected the proposal could hardly be called representatives of the people as the majority of the people were away, at their spring fishing.

There is only one solution, that is, to build a suitable Industrial School such as will keep the students at school the whole year round. Thus leaving the parents without excuse to educate their children.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Enclosed find a petition from the people of Port Simpson, signed on their behalf by about one hundred of their leading men. This petition as you will see requests the Government to build them a large industrial school for the education of both boys and girls. As the co-education of their children was involved in this petition, which was presented to me last February, I thought it only courtesy on my part to present it to the Women's Missionary Society of our Church, they owning and operating a girls' school at Port Simpson. The Board of the Women's Missionary Society met the last week of September, and they unanimously reached the conclusion that they would heartily cooperate with the general board in the management of a school for the education of boys and girls and would render any assistance possible to the Government in the
erection of the same.

I presented this petition to the General Board of Missions which met last week in Toronto. The Board acceded to the principle of co-education and also to the wisdom of selecting Port Simpson as a place suitable for the erection of a large industrial school.

When I received this petition from the people they appointed a deputation to show me the land that they would be willing to give; it is about a mile and a half down the coast from the village. They offer all the land we require from one hundred up to four hundred acres if necessary. I also required that they would build a dock, dig out the foundations of the main building, put in a dam for water supply which would be about half a mile up the mountain-side, dig a ditch and put in the pipe. I may say that these terms they did not agree to. I have written Mr. Lawson who was Secretary of the meeting telling him what I have done with the petition, and also rehearsing the conditions that I would like them to comply with. I have pointed out to him that not only is the Women's Missionary Society and the General Board of our Church sympathetic to the movement, but the Deputy Superintendent General is also. At the same time I have assured him that
it is a question of time as to when we will be able to get the money, since the Government has a large number of schemes that call for large expenditures.

I would take it as a favour if you would write a letter to the Secretary of the meeting that presented me with the petition, setting forth the Government's viewpoint.

Yours sincerely,

T. F. Ferrier

Sir,

Whereas we are informed that the new Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, opened last October at Sardis, B.C., is now filled to capacity, with an attendance roll and waiting list including many children from the north-west coast of British Columbia;

And whereas, at the present time, the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada, in conjunction with the Department of Indian Affairs, are continuing their long-established and most effective efforts among the Indian girls at Port Simpson, - no provision, however, being made by any organization, of boarding-school facilities for the boys of that district;
that district.

And whereas the undersigned missionary workers and friends interested in the welfare of the native people do declare that the moral and social conditions especially among the boys and young men of the Northern tribes give rise to great anxiety for the present, and great apprehension for the future, - many such young people giving evidence of certain developments which will not only bring about race degradation and extinction, but which, if unchecked, will produce a moral and social menace to the adjoining Canadian white population;

And whereas it is our strong conviction that such undesirable conditions can only be met by granting to our Native people such Educational facilities as accrue from a local Boarding School;

And whereas it is generally conceded that few native tribes, if any, in the whole of the Dominion of Canada, manifest a higher standard of social and intellectual progress, than do those British Columbia tribes included in the Nass and Queen Charlotte Agencies, - the children of the Tsimsean and Haida tribes especially, responding most readily to influences of Education and social uplift;
social uplift.

And whereas in Port Simpson; Skeena River; Nass River and Queen Charlotte districts, there is at present a concentrated field containing several hundred children eligible for entrance into a Boarding School, but who are at present denied requisite Educational facilities owing to the nomadic habits of their parents, and owing to the great distance at which Boarding Schools presently available, are situated;

And in view of that practical and most sympathetic attitude which has always been manifested by the Department of Indian Affairs in native educational problems such as this;

Dear Dr. Wilson:

RE PROPOSED NEW INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL IN THE NORTH.

I had hoped to have written to you before this on the above matter, but have had an unusually busy trip South to Smiths and Rivers Inlets for the last two weeks and found no time for writing en route as I sometimes do.

I talked the matter of a site for the above school with Dr. Darby and Mr. Gibson, and should have done so with Mr. Deans, but forgot it yesterday when in to see him. I shall take it up with him later. Dr. Darby was strongly in favor of a site at Old Town, near Bella Bella. Mr. Gibson was not so strongly favorable at first, but came round to that view later, I think. I was not at first much impressed with the suggestion, but every day since it has appealed to me more strongly. Of course, there is the undoubted fact that the Presbytery, through the recommendation of the Fort Simpson delegates, endorsed the request that the new school be located at that place. Then there was a request that the school go to Hazelton, but I do not think there was any great unanimity of heart on the question, seeing there was really no other proposition forthcoming. I shall try to set forth the pros and cons of the thing as I see them, and think I shall be ready to support my view at Presbytery when it meets.

(1) Fort Simpson: Possesses undoubted power as an historic centre; Has also a large native population in itself and nearby. Is close to the Queen Charlotte Island peoples, and has a good Hospital nearby, etc. But, on the other hand, as I understand it, there is no good farming land nearby, which is a fundamental requisite for such a school. Again, it has only a weekly boat service, and is off the main lines of boat travel. It is also at one end of the territory to be served, and close to territory served by the Anglican Church. Some mention is being made of the fact that the Tsimshians are old time enemies of the Haidas of the Q.C.Ids., and Port Simpson would therefore not be looked upon as a favorable site by the latter people. I do not know whether there is much in this argument or not. I don't think such a spirit should be countenanced although it may have some practical bearing on the problem for the meantime.

(2) Hazelton: Has a fine site with all kinds of good land available for cultivation. It is the centre of a fair number of our United Church Indians, for example at Kishpiox and at Kitzegucla (Skema Crossing). On the other hand there is a large centre of Anglican Indians right at Hazelton itself. We have a fine Hospital there, and the Anglicans have only a church and resident pastor, which we have also, of course. But, Hazelton would not appeal to the Indians of the Coast, I fear. It would mean a boat journey and then a train journey as well with a stopover in Prince Rupert. It would however, have the advantage of being too close to any site, or proposed site for an Anglican School as would Port Simpson, I feel, for seeing the Anglicans have a school now at Alert Bay, if they purpose a further school, it could only naturally be in the North.

(3) Bella Coola: Has all the advantages of being near a good sized village of native people. There is a good Hospital, partly in connection with our Church and there is good land available, although it would have to be cleared at a probable cost of at least $500.00 per acre.

Against this are the facts of a weekly boat service, and the situation being to one side, although central from the point of view of north and south. I do not think it would make any strong appeal to our native people, or to the Church at large.
Bella Bella: I have come to the conclusion that this is the logical centre for a new school for the following reasons:

1 - It is central, both for the East and West and North and South.

2 - It has the best boat service of any place on the Coast, all S.S.Co's have it on their list of ports of call. It has from three to four boats a week each way, during the summer months, and at least two and usually three boats each way in the winter.

3 - It has all the drawing power of historic associations that Port Simpson can have, and is without any of the old lingering tribal objections so far as I know.

4 - The site is far enough away from the present village to ensure privacy and the best environment for the pupils, and I understand the land is good for agricultural purposes, and is practically cleared and ready for occupation.

5 - In view of the fact that there is some likelihood of the Anglican Church asking for another school on the Coast, Bella Bella would be the logical place for our own Church. It has long been the stronghold of United Church work, made sacred through the work of men like Dr. Large and now our own Dr. George Darby. It is far enough away from Alert Bay to cause no lessening of the functions of that school, and it is central to our own work, especially, to those parts that have been neglected so long, namely, Smith's and Rivers Inlets where the Indians constitute a problem for our Church at the present moment. I feel that Bella Bella would appeal very strongly to the Indians of these two localities. Kitammat, Hartley Bay and Bella Coola are not far removed, and in the summer these peoples are always in the Bella Bella area during the cannery season. It is much more nearly in the centre of our Native work than any other point proposed as a site for a school. As I have said before, if there is likelihood of the Anglican Church asking for another school it could only go in the North, either at the Nass, Metlakahtla, or Port Simpson, and while there may be room for two schools there, yet it seems to me the United Church School at Bella Bella and the Anglican one in the North would be the more reasonable arrangement.

6 - Steamships of the C.N.S.S.C., from the Queen Charlotte Isds. pass right by Bella Bella giving a direct connection with the villages on the Islands.

I think this is about the best I can do on the problem and trust that in the musings of a multitude of counsellors there may arise wisdom for the guidance of our Church in this important matter.

With all good wishes,

I am,

Sincerely yours,

(SGD.) R. C. Scott.
Dear Doctor Wilson;-

Your communication as regards the new Residential School received by last mail and at the earliest opportunity it was brought before a large gathering of our people. Indian Agent Fougner in the Chair. The gathering was pleased to know that our Church recommended that a new Residential School be erected for the benefit of our Northern Indians.

Our people unanimously urge that the proposed new school be erected at Bella Coola where there is an area of over 3000 acres of arable land, and support this contention with the following reasons:

(1) We ourselves have at present over 100 children in the village; 65 of these being of school age.

(2) Our day school is full up; besides those of our children at Alert Bay and at Sardis.

(3) The parents find that our school at Sardis is too far away; and the fares too expensive; while the one at Alert Bay is not under the charge of our Church.

(4) Bella Coola is in a central position from Rivers Inlet people, Bella Bella, Klemtu, Kitlope and Kitaamat, and also the stick Indians back of us who have no school facilities wish their children sent here.

(5) Bella Coola is quite a centre for United Church work. We have two Churches, a fully equipped hospital and day school manned by our Church.

(6) We have a regular weekly mail service; beside other connection, with local points.

(7) Bella Coola can offer what no other Indian Reserve can tender - 50 acres of agricultural land, and more if necessary on which to erect our new Residential School.

I cannot recall the Presbytery where a resolution was passed asking that a school be erected at Port Simpson, though at a meeting of the Workers amongst the Indians held some years ago, before Union, did recommend a school at Port Simpson, but since that time conditions have changed entirely. A school at Port Simpson will not help us at all - 275 miles away in a severe climate.

As soon as the site is decided on in Bella Coola, our people will at once begin to clear the land. A portion of the land is covered with a good growth of wood, making excellent fire-wood.

I trust the Church may see its way clear to erect the school in our midst where it is greatly needed.

I am, sincerely,

(SGD.) T. EDW. RENDLE.
Missionary to the Bella Coolas.

Your letter of November 4th came to hand November 28th regular mail. In reply to your queries - you will remember in my former reply re centre for proposed Central School or Schools for Indian children I said I was not so well acquainted with the geography of the district as to be able to name a location not only central but socially furnished for the highest upbringing and welfare for the present and future of our Indian people and children.

My brief experience with the Indians is - bring them out in contact with our white population, and the best of them, if you are ever to benefit them and lift them out of the deadening past. They meet now with white men, as they go out to work in canneries or engage in fishing, to their great detriment. White men, I have heard myself, that would poison the good in Saints. My policy is, then, - bring the Indian (or any other backward people) into the open, into open welcome contact with the very best, purest and noblest in the Human Sphere.
