To the Rev. Dr. Cochrane;—

We, the native residents of Port Simpson, B.C., represented by our Chiefs and Councillors, lay before you our humble request that you and the United Church of Canada will use your influence on behalf of the Tsimshian people in establishing a residential school at Port Simpson.

In requesting this we will endeavour to show you some of the difficulties that we are laboring under at the present time, making it impossible to give even an elementary education to our children, owing to the fact we must at different seasons of the year leave our homes and taking with us our children to our various fields of our activities at which points there are no way of educating them.

In asking that you use your influence for us with the proper authorities to establish a residential school in our village, we would point out to you the central location of Port Simpson, which is the central point of a group of Tsimshian, Nisga'a, Gitksan, and Haida villages serving over a large population, over three thousand people and in the village of Port Simpson alone there is over a hundred children of school age who cannot get a proper education owing to the present mode of living of the natives here, this would be overcome with the establishing of a residential school here at Port Simpson. All of these villages are located within a radius of twenty four hours from Port Simpson at the farthest points, making communication between parent and school easier and not costly.

At present some of our children are being taken care of at Sardis, but the distance from home which in some cases is over six hundred miles, making it almost impossible and costly to the parents in sending their children to and fro and very often the children are not able to acclimatize themselves to the new surroundings, which tends to discourage us in sending them such a distance from home, thus placing a hardship on the children over which we at present have no control, owing to our present mode of making our living.

We also wish to point out to you that educating the children right in their own district amidst his own environment and in suitable industries for their own future welfare in the district they will be a credit to themselves and the people they represent.

We wish also to mention that in the past when matters of school came in our midst there was always some little dissensions in the matter of lands and locations. We can assure you at this time the people are all one in their request and will co-operate with you and the authorities in supporting any reasonable request for lands and location.

We wish also to point out to you our location is right on the paths of the regular steamers and also the splendid Church and Hospital right here in our midst.

We earnestly ask that you give our humble requests your very careful consideration and we trust we will have your support in them.

I don't think it wise to say that each Church shall recruit from its own constituency, for we have a number of our children at Alert Bay, and they are doing very well. Alert Bay is very close to us. In fact, when we are talking Church Union, why separate Indian Children.

Dear Dr. Wilson:

Your letter of the 4th inst. received, and contents carefully noted.

After consultation with Dr. Large and others of our staff and white group here I beg to submit the following reply, in which there is general concurrence.

I.

We believe the school ought to be placed on the coast, and not inland. The Residential Schools that are placed inland naturally give considerable time and attention to farming, which is useful to natives of the interior, but is almost wholly wasted on our northern coast Indians. This is a serious consideration with us, and ought to carry weight in any deliberations of the board as to the location of the school. This northern coast region, which contains so large an Indian population, is in no sense a farming country. And the young Indians of these tribes ought to receive their education and training along lines that they can utilize after their school days are ended.

Our people require an academic education that will create in them an intelligent interest in literature and art and science and history and citizenship and public affairs and the general cultural aspects of civilization.

The young men require an elementary business education that will enable them to compete on a somewhat equal footing with white men.

And on the Industrial side they would profit by carpentering, boat-building, gas oil and electrical engineering, and general machine shop practice.

Another industry that we believe might wisely be undertaken, in at least an experimental way, and might in time grow into a major source of income for our people, is fur farming. The trapping industry, at one time so lucrative on the northern coast, is decreasing year by year. Where a trapper brought in 100 skins 20 years ago, he now brings in ten. But fur farming, under proper direction, ought to be rewarding; and it might in time be a source of income for our Indians comparable to reindeer raising in Alaska; which has made the natives there so eminently prosperous. This latter is only a suggestion, but certainly worth looking into.

II.

Now as to the location of a Residential School on the northern coast, - we believe that Fort Simpson is the logical place; and for the following reasons:
(1) The central and accessible location of Port Simpson. We are situated between the two northern rivers, the Skeena and the Naas, with their Indian villages. And we are within 3½ hours' run by gas boat of Prince Rupert.

(2) Port Simpson is much the largest Indian village on the coast. There are about 600 Indians resident in Port Simpson. There are also about 20 families belonging to this village living in Prince Rupert.

(3) Our fine new Government Dock, built during the past two years, affords convenient accommodation for the landing of boats at all times of the year, and for the handling of freight.

(4) There is plenty of land available at Port Simpson for school purposes, either (a) by extending the mission holdings on the Indian Reserve, or (b) by purchase from the Hudson's Bay Co. The Hudson's Bay property of almost 107 acres immediately adjoins the Mission property and the Indian Reserve. A considerable area is levelled and sown to grass. And it has a wide harbour frontage. The whole property could, I understand, be purchased quite reasonably at the present time; and there are certain store buildings, now in use, that could be purchased and used for shop purposes if desired.

(5) There is already at Port Simpson a fine commodious Church; which has been newly painted this year. And there is a hospital of 35 beds, with Dr. and nursing staff. Also the Crosby Girls' Home, a substantial modern building, built by the Women's Missionary Society a few years ago as a temporary measure until the Residential School, which was at that time promised, would be built. This latter building could be used as a teacher's residence, or such other purpose as desired, in connection with the School.

(6) The native people of Port Simpson have for many years looked forward to the establishment of a Residential School at their village; and are themselves eagerly asking for it.

We believe, therefore, that the Mission Board will be acting in the best interests of the United Church Indian constituency on the northern coast by deciding to build the new Residential School at Port Simpson.

Yours sincerely,

(SGD.) M. F. EBY.

PETITION:

The Petition of the Native Communities of Naas River, British Columbia, ethnologically known as the NISHKA INDIANS, herein humbly sheweth that,

Whereas nearly half a century has elapsed since the Dominion Government assumed paternal responsibility for our "upbringing" and education, nothing commensurate with such responsibility has yet been undertaken for the benefit of the Nishka people.

For we consider that the policy of establishing Village Day Schools is a good and necessary in itself, lends virtually no effectual aid, being unsupplemented, as it is, by a higher and more technical institution as an educational terminus.

We admit that, hitherto, this need has not sufficiently impressed us; though in this way, we did perceive; but now, as the world around us, the need has become more visible and clamant, resolving itself into an earnest desire on the part of our people to have an Industrial Boarding School on the Naas River for the benefit of our children, both now and in the days to come.

And Whereas, hitherto, as far as we were conscious of the need of higher education for our children, we sought to obtain it by sending them to institutions remotely situated in various parts of the Province, with results, however, far from satisfactory to us:

For, firstly, the mortality among those so sent has been abnormally high; and secondly, the difficulty of getting both boys and girls back to school after vacation to complete their terms has been found almost insuperable, owing to the inevitable tendency to return to conditions in various ways distasteful to those same institutions being inevitable in institutions where racial antipathies are allowed free scope, nor frequently existant relations among the children, and whereas the climate of the north, which may not be the soother church of all the children, tends to the gathering of indisposition rather than reverence; while, thirdly, the majority of families of these institutions are located in the midst of, or almost adjoining, some Indian settlements, which, though not necessarily harmful especially, while perhaps carrying with it advantages for those natives to that particular place, is pitiful of dangers for those coming from elsewhere. For, always also such an environment is, generally speaking, morally unhealthy.

And Whereas our views on this question were laid before the Royal Commission on its visit to the Naas in 1915, when the various native communities on the river united in presenting a petition for the establishment of an Industrial Boarding School for the Naas district, which petition the Commission promised to lay before, and recommend to, the Government:

Yet, notwithstanding the assurances thus given, we regret to hear now that it is proposed to erect the school we asked for at Port Simpson (entirely outside our Agency) instead of on the Naas River.

We think it ought to be clearly understood by the Authorities concerned in this decision that the Nishka people would prefer a school situated within a short distance than one situated at Port Simpson. And for this reason, the Tsimshians and Nishkas, while of certain racial affinity, are divided by the use of two different forms of speech. It is therefore intolerable to us to find our young people return from school with an outside dialect upon their tongue. We desire to send them to school to learn English, and to receive something of a literary training, and not to become further steeped in the idiosphere of Indian口语.

We feel compelled therefore to state that, in our opinion, and from our point of view, the establishment of an Industrial Boarding School at Port Simpson will in no way benefit the Nishka people. It would be outside of our country; it would be outside of our Agency; it would be outside of our...
desires, our church and other interests, as we see them.

And whereas duly qualified medical supervision is to be considered as an essential factor in the establishment and carrying on of such an institution as this petition has in view, not only with regard to the health of the children individually, but in the matter of hygiene and sanitation generally, and especially as to the steps to be immediately taken in cases of emergency for the prevention of infection and the spread of disease:

We beg to draw attention to the fact that, already, the Indian Department has substituted a school at Mass River as one of the means so that at least this most essential prerequisite for the establishment of such a school is already on hand.

And whereas the entire native population of the Nass being now separately constituted on distinct Indian Agency; and being religiously members of one distinctive church, viz., the ANGLICAN; and being of one language and one racial mentality; and being also sufficient in population to assure a full complement of scholars for such institution from term to term,—

We consider that the best interests of our people, and the benevolent desires of the Government on the subject should be harmonized by providing for the establishment of one central industrial institution for Indian boys and girls on Nass River (at a point to be determined upon having that near Simpson or any other point on the coast or interior of B.C.)

THEREFORE, and because of the reasons herein severally set forth, we the undersigned NISHKA INDIANS of Nass River, British Columbia, do hereby present our humble petition to the Government of Canada to grant us an INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL for the more complete up-lift and educational advancement of our people; and that this School be centrally situated on some suitable place on the NAAS RIVER.

And your Petitioners shall ever pray:

We consider that the best interests of our people, and the benevolent desires of the Government of our nation, would be most effectively served by the establishment of one centrally located institution for native boys and girls on Nass River (at a point to be determined upon hereafter) than at Port Simpson or any other point on the coast or interior of B.C.

THEREFORE, and because of the reasons herein severally set forth, we the undersigned NISHKA INDIANS of Naas River, British Columbia, do hereby present our humble petition to the Government of Canada to grant us an Industrial School for the more complete up-lift and educational advancement of our people; and that this School be centrally situated on some suitable place on the NAAS RIVER.

And your Petitioners shall ever pray:

MEMORANDUM:

MR. D. C. SCOTT -

The attached letter and petition addressed to the Minister were received this morning.

You might be good enough to prepare a suitable acknowledgment for the Minister's signature and take whatever action you think advisable.

Enclosures.
Ottawa, Ontario,
May 11th, 1921.

Dear Sir -

I have received your letter of the 28th ultimo, with which was enclosed Petition from the Nishka Indians requesting the establishment of an Industrial Boarding School in the Nass District.

While I appreciate your desire to obtain better educational facilities for the Indian children, it will not be possible for the Government, owing to present financial conditions, to consider the provision of such an appropriation at this Session of Parliament. I shall, however, request the Deputy Superintendent General to note your Petition and, while I cannot promise that any grant will be made in the near future, you may rest assured the matter will be given sympathetic consideration.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

C. B. Barton, Esq.,
Kincolith,
B. C.
May 17, 1921.

Dear Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, forwarding a petition, signed by the Indians residing at all the principal villages on the Nass river, requesting the establishment of an industrial boarding school in their district.

In reply I beg to inform you that a copy of this petition was also sent to the Superintendent General by Mr. C. B. Barton, of Kincolith. I am inclosing herewith a copy of the Minister's reply to Mr. Barton.

Yours truly,

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B.C., Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, November 21st, 1933.

Reverend Sir,

In a report regarding his inspection of the Port Simpson Indian Residential School on May 29th, 1933, Inspector Barry writes, in part, as follows:

"Water Supply:- The source of the water supply is makeshift. Though sufficient for domestic purposes, there would not be enough pressure to fight any sort of fire.

"Fire-Fighting:- There are four large 'Soda Type' extinguishers. These are tested from time to time. There are about six small hand extinguishers. With reference to my report of last year under this heading, I am glad to be able to report that regular fire drills have been held this last year.

When Colonel Pragnell was with me during the inspection of this school last year, we came to the conclusion that a fire escape was necessary for the use of the children in the new dormitory. I beg to recommend again that such a fire escape be erected on the end of the new addition. I have gone into this matter again during the present inspection and am satisfied that this is the best place for such an escape. It will be the least expensive place to erect such an escape, which should be constructed from the dormitory window right to the ground where the hill rises behind this dormitory; a fairly short escape is all that will be required. I would suggest that the Department take this matter up with the United Church authorities, as was done in the case of the Kitamaat Indian Residential School.

The only possible thing to do in a school of this type in case of fire would be to get the children out as soon as possible. Any serious fighting of fire is out of the question owing to lack of any pressure in the pipe lines.

"Lighting:- The present Electric Lighting plant, a 650 Watt 32 Volt Delco, is ten years old. It is far too small for the school. New batteries are required but as I recommended last year this machine should be sold to the Indians for what it might fetch, and a proper sized plant substituted. This recommendation was contained in a special letter to the Department last year; but I understand that my suggestion has not been accepted. I would now suggest that the contents of this report as far as it is of vital importance to the United Church Board of Home Missions be communicated to them, with a view of having the more urgent work at this school attended to in the near future."

I should appreciate if you would bring our Inspector's report to the attention of the officers of the Women's Missionary Society.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Kenneth J. Beaton, B.A.,
Associate Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
United Church of Canada,
Toronto, Ont.,

Fire Protection:

I would ask that the following be read in reference to and continuation of my report on Page 2 forwarded from Victoria on October 18, 1935.

The four large type Soda Fire Extinguishers have been refilled since my last inspection. There are also some half dozen Pyrene Extinguishers at this school.

I am told that Fire Drills are held regularly now, but this is very difficult to believe. The Fire Drills held are obviously not of the type we understand as such. My reason for saying this is that I have now at last discovered why the Principal did not want a fire drill held on September 19, 1935, and why it has been impossible to hold these drills regularly as the Indian Affairs Branch has instructed. THERE ARE FINE WIRE MESH SCREENS NAILED OUTSIDE THE WINDOWS LEADING FROM THE DORMITORIES TO THE ESCAPES.

The Principal tells me that to hold a Drill down the escapes FROM THE DORMITORIES the screens have to be taken off by a skilled man or the window frames suffer.

Water Supply:

The source of the water supply is muskeg. There is not quite sufficient water in a dry year, and there is of course no sufficient supply to fight even a small fire. The pressure in the pipes is very low.

I would recommend that the extension of pipe line from the school to the Mission House put in a few years ago be disconnected and the school permitted to make use of all the available water. The Mission House can arrange for a separate supply. The school requires all the water it can get, from its own pipe line.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Letter of May 23, 1937, addressed to Indian Commissioner MacKay, submitting above report.

Miss Deacon asked me, in confidence, to try and have the pipe line disconnected below the school and so that the Mission House could not draw on their supply which is none too plentiful for them and they need it in the drier seasons. The Mission House can arrange for its own supply and in any case has nothing to do with the school. The present time is considered suitable as the Missionary is expected to leave soon for another sphere of work and it would be hard to cut this line when there was a Missionary in residence.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report for the month of May as follows:

CROSBY GIRLS' SCHOOL

During my inspection of the school, particular attention was paid to the window exits leading to the fire escapes in each of the dormitories. Window screens have been made to open outward on hinges which can be easily manipulated by the pupils. Two senior girls sleep in each of the dormitories their duties being to take charge of the smaller children in the event of a fire. Fortunately as the school stands on sloping ground, the distance from the fire exit windows to the ground in one of the dormitories at the rear is only a matter of a few feet and the children can easily be lifted to the ground without the use of the fire escape, if necessary.

I found the several departments of the school in excellent order. In the classroom, pupils under Miss Lincoln, teacher, have made good progress.

W.E. Collison,
Indian Agent.
Mr. J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert B.C.

Dear Sir:

For several weeks past our electric light plant has been giving great trouble and I have been wondering if the Department of Indian Affairs would consider coming to our assistance in the purchase of a new engine.

The Delco engine and generator capacity 850 watt, 32 volt has been in operation since 1923 and the estimated cost for a general overhaul and repair would be about $100.00 with always the doubt if such an expenditure would be advisable.

There is also the danger of fire as the engine back fires badly and during the winter months especially and the heavy strain on the plant, which is small, its just a gamble whether we have light or not. Mr. Gosnell has managed to keep it going so far this fall, but he says he can't guarantee that it will last all winter, he is getting a few minor repairs in the meantime.

Anything you can do in our behalf will be greatly appreciated here, and also by our W.M.S. Board in Toronto.

Very many thanks,

Yours truly,

Bessie French

Principal

Dear Sir:

Re: Repairs, Crosby Girls' Home,
Port Simpson Indian Reserve, B.C.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of
the 13th instant and also quotations and correspondence
relating to repairs at the above noted school, sent
forward therewith.

I must again express regret that it has not
been possible to proceed with repairs at this school
until this comparatively late date. It is noted that
Indian Agent Gillett received a quotation from Telegraph
Cove Mills, Limited, on shingles, and that this quotation
is dated June 5, 1943. I find it somewhat difficult to
understand why this information was not sent forward to
us at that time.

In view of the lateness of the season and
our desire to have this work undertaken and accomplished
at the earliest possible date, we are sending this letter
forward by air mail. You should have Indian Agent Gillett
make the best possible local arrangements for the purchase
of the supplies necessary for this repair work. We are
sending him a cheque for $200.00, the amount he estimates
will be necessary for Indian labour.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

REPORT ON SKEENA RIVER AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Schools;

All schools in the Agency are now functioning. The Port Simpson Indian Day School has only one teacher at present. Rev. Wilding is still substituting at the Crosby Girl's Home. There are a number of Indian Children attending white schools at Prince Rupert and Inverness.

The shingling of the Crosby Girl's Home was finally completed. We had quite a problem in securing the necessary labour.

Mr. J. Gillett, Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

On September 27, 1943, you were forwarded, by air mail, an accountable cheque for $500.00 for labour in connection with repairs to the Port Simpson Indian Residential School. I acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th inst., relative to an accountable cheque for labour on the Crosby Girl's Home at Fort Simpson.

We experienced great difficulty in securing labour for this work but it has now been completed. Unfortunately, as soon as the work was finished, one or two of the labourers went trapping and we have not been able to contact them to make payment. I believe, however, that we may do so this week. I will forward the pay sheet as soon as completed.

Ottawa, April 11, 1945.

Dear Madam:

Last year pilot biscuits were sent to the Port Simpson School, on the understanding that the school management would pay the cost of transportation. Evidently you sent a cheque for $5.40 to Union Steamships, Limited, Vancouver. However, we are now in receipt of a letter from them, dated March 21, stating that the correct charge was $5.80, and consequently they request an additional 40¢. It would be appreciated if you would forward this amount to the company.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Indian Agent Gillett has submitted an account from Boultee Limited, Vancouver, B.C., in the amount of $103.90, covering cost of repairs to the lighting plant in the Crosby Girl's Home, Port Simpson, advising that the Women's Missionary Society has asked if the Department would assist in paying for these repairs, and recommending that the Department meet half the cost.

Mr. Gillett advises that the plant was purchased by the Department several years ago and I concur in his recommendation that the Department pay $51.95 of the amount. If this recommendation meets with the approval of the Department it would be appreciated if you would advise how the Department would like the matter handled, whether by the submission of a voucher or if the amount will be paid directly to the Women's Missionary Society.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

An extensive examination of the Crosby Girls Home was recently made by the Agent accompanied by the Executive Secretary, Women's Missionary Society, Mrs. Isobel M. Loveys, of Toronto. The plumbing and sanitary condition in the School were in a frightful state, and after an extensive conference, and a further inspection by a competent plumber from Prince Rupert, Mrs. Loveys authorized repairs and alterations from Women's Missionary Society funds to a total of $1500.00, as per the attached list. A complete new staff has been engaged at this School, and from present indications there is hope for a much improved standard throughout the School.

The lighting plant is in very bad condition indeed, and is totally inadequate to meet the needs of the School. It was leaking raw gas whilst I was there, and I consider its present condition a grave fire risk to the School. It took at least 20 minutes to get it started, and it has a very bad knock, indicative of either a worn crank-shaft bearing or main bearings gone. The plant is a Briggs-Stratton, 750 watt plant, 32 volt and was put in by the Women's Missionary Society many years ago.

An examination of the load potential was made, and it is recommended that a 110 volt AC plant of 2000 watt be installed to take care of an estimated load requirement of 1400 watts. Under present conditions the lights are kept to a minimum, but even then they go so dim as to be of little use in the school. The dulness and dinginess of the present light is such as to have an unhealthy effect on the children's minds.

Mrs. Loveys asks that in view of her action in sanctioning the sum of $1500.00 for plumbing, baths, more toilets and overhaul of the furnace, that the Department meet the cost of the proposed
new plant.

Bid on an Onan plant is attached. It is considered that the 2 K.W. plant at a cost f.o.b. Vancouver of $596.55 would provide a most suitable plant for this School.

The Hudson Bay Co. at Port Simpson have a competent electrical man who would install this plant, and check all present wiring for $100.00. The present plant is battery operated (16 /2 volt storage cells). These are 10 years old and are absolutely dead and beyond further use.

The new plant suggested can be started manually but is equipped with a remote control stop and start switch, which can be installed in the Matron's room. The plant also permits 4 - 12 volt (10 watt) night lights, to be operated from the starting batteries. The Hudson Bay Co. would install these in their one charge of $100.00.

It is considered that the installation of this plant is an urgent requirement and the plant is recommended for immediate purchase.

On September 24th the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church, which body operates the above-noted School, wired me that funds to the extent of $1,000.00 were available for repairs to this building. I would refer to my letter of August 1st, 1947, following up my letter of June 14, 1947, and your reply of August 19th, also to your subsequent telegram of August 29th, 1947. Rightly or wrongly, I inferred from this correspondence that the Department was not opposing the re-opening of the School for the current academic year, and on the strength of this information proceeded to arrange for repairs and the admission of pupils. At the time of writing there are eight children in residence and more have been called in. Practically all these children are orphaned in part or children from anti-social surroundings and their care in an institution is imperative.

The School is in charge of Miss Moats and from my observations I would say she is competent to manage the School. Her co-workers are elderly but seem anxious to do their best. There are three workers only at the time of writing. The question of classroom work comes into the picture. At present the day school with some adjustment of grades can handle these children. If the pressure gets too heavy, it is recommended that Miss Moats be asked to teach them on a half day basis at the Crosby Home.

In view of all the facts, it is recommended that the School be re-opened as from October 1st; that pupilage be
limited to girls of 12 and under; that a maximum of 20 be enrolled and that as long as there is available room these children attend Day School in the village. And finally, that the situation be reviewed when Inspector Davey makes his annual inspection next spring.

A review of our files indicates that the question of continued operation of the school was the subject of discussion between the Department and the W.M.S., and when this office was advised by the local representative of the W.M.S. that a teacher was proceeding north to open the school we naturally assumed that such action was the result of the discussion referred to. A memorandum dated December 1st from District School Inspector Davey is attached wherein he concurs in the recommendations made by Mr. Anfield regarding the age limit, number of pupils to be enrolled and the proposed attendance of the children at the day school at Port Simpson. Under the circumstances there would appear to be no alternative but to recommend approval of these arrangements.

Dear Major MacKay:

Re: Port Simpson Building

The Woman's Missionary Society owns a large house or institution, formerly known as the Crosby Girls' Home. As you know, the Home is no longer in operation and consequently the building is deteriorating. I have been asked to communicate with you to ascertain if any use could be made of this building, with the suggestion that it might be used as a home for aged persons who cannot otherwise be cared for.

I should be glad if you could let us know, first, whether there is need for such a home, to accommodate probably fifteen or twenty persons. It is obvious that those to be accommodated must be members of the Band at Port Simpson, or not too far away, because old people usually do not want to be removed too far from their home people.

The second question has to do with finance. If these people were not Indians, the old age pension which they would receive would probably finance the expenditure for maintenance, but the Government policy does not seem to contemplate anything except a very meagre allowance for old Indian people. I do not suppose that you are in any position to venture a prophecy as to whether the Government will make a change, so that the principle of the old age pension may apply to Indians as well as to white people. In any case, the question of the financing of such a home remains. I do not think it would be looked upon with any favor that the Church should do any more than provide the building, and probably the salary of a competent person to manage the affairs. In other respects, the venture should be self-sustaining, as all expenditure for maintenance, including the upkeep of the building, should be met out of the resources of the people.

This is just a bare outline of a possible use of the building which has been discussed. If you have any other suggestions, we should be very glad to have them.

With kindest personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Your 12-11-1 of June 10th, 1949, having reference to the possible use of the former Crosby Girl's Home at Port Simpson, has been received with copies of correspondence with the Director and Dr. G. E. Dorey of the United Church.

For several years I have been exploring the possible value of homes for aged Indians and have surveyed this building and the old Mission House at Port Simpson with such a project in view. From this study, I have reached the conclusion that the institutionalizing of old Indians is an unsound procedure and that they would be better taken care of in necessitous cases by placing them in private homes on a monthly grant basis.

It is considered, however, that the Crosby Home at Port Simpson has definite values as a T.B. Preventorium and it is recommended that this phase of endeavor be explored by the Indian Health Services. I would say, however, that from practical experience in building and operating a preventorium for years at Alert Bay, I can see where the Crosby Home has a definite use along these lines. Apart from the crowded conditions at Miller Bay's children's wards, there are, I am sure, sufficient T.B. suspect children to fill two preventoria in this district. This is, of course, a medical problem and not within my jurisdiction. From the physical point of view, the building is still sound though a new furnace, lighting plant and complete wiring job would have to be installed to make the place habitable. In addition to this, complete decoration and repairs to the roof would have to be done.

I see no practical use to which this building could be put within the ambit of our welfare service. It is, however, recommended that the possible use of this building by the Indian
Health Services be fully explored. It is just possible that if a preventorium was started at Fort Simpson, with it could be combined the present nursing facilities.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

For some time past I have been trying to get the Port Simpson Indians to commit themselves in regard to a site for the proposed new school.

When you were in Port Simpson in the spring if you remember we examined three, one of which, if you look at the rough diagram in part of lot 9, Range 5, Coast District. This is adjacent to the Girl's Home bordering on the south line of their lot and a very desirable location.

A second site is exactly opposite across the Government trail in a westward direction and on the Indian Departments plan of the Port Simpson Townsite is marked Block XVI. This joins the present mission property on the south side. This also is a desirable location.

If neither of the above suit or if we could not secure the one adjacent to the Girl's Home there is the present site, which would certainly be a last resort.

I am inclined to think the first impossible. It is owned by a Victoria liquor seller, who said a few years ago that he would not sell any but he would sell all his holdings viz., 20 acres in a block. He asked $25,000.00. I have tried to see him in Victoria but failed. Now have written him in regard to the matter, so that we shall have some basis to work upon when the site is decided upon.

In regard to the second site the fact that the Indians are willing to give it to us shows two things, their desire for a school and their confidence in the Methodist Church. The Indians are incensed over the present conduct of the land question, they have refused to "Lose Land," turning down all applications even though good money has been offered them, until their grievance is settled and I had to assure them before they were willing to consider the matter that the granting of the land for educational purposes would make no difference to the legal aspect of their claim. Their promise is in writing. I thought it would do them good to commit themselves to paper, the letter they sent is important and should be kept on file. I kept a copy but it has not their signatures.

Might I ask that in your acknowledgment of the letter to Mr. Dudowad nothing is said of the site off the reserve. At present they do not know that we are even thinking of that.

Sir:

As regards a site and size of same for the proposed Boarding school, I beg to say that, being unaware of the requirements of the Department, I am not able to furnish it without further knowledge of the Department's proposals. It would seem that whatever arrangements have been entered into between the Methodist Church and the Department have taken place without the matter being officially referred to me.

Some time ago, when visiting Port Simpson, I met Rev. Mr. Ferrier, with whom I casually took a walk to what Mr. Ferrier regarded a possible site for a boarding school. Later at his request, we looked over the townsite plan to see how the selection of such a site would affect the surveyed lots. On another occasion, Rev. G. H. Raley, the principal of the old school, whilst preparing suggestions to be embodied in a specification to be placed in Mr. Ferrier's hands, to be later considered by the Department, asked me if I would spend a little time with him in considering such suggestions, to which I consented. Neither of these interviews were considered by me to be official, as I had received no instructions from you in regard to such matters, and I simply obliged these gentlemen by acceding to their requests. At the same time, I reported them to you.

I have been given to understand that the Church authorities have found difficulty in endeavouring to secure from the Port Simpson Indians their approval to the establishment of a new boarding institution on a site proposed by Rev. G. H. Raley at the suggestion of Rev. T. Ferrier. I am informed that Mr. Raley very recently met the chiefs and asked them to give their consent to the setting aside of six acres, to which proposal the Indians would not agree.

Several such interviews are said to have been had with the chiefs, individually and collectively, but I have not been made officially aware of any of them by the Church authorities; and, not having received any instructions from the Department, I did not feel that it was my duty to be inquisitive in the matter.

I would suggest that (unless it is the intention of the Department to expropriate a site for the proposed building) a meeting of the Port Simpson Indians be convened, to acquaint them with the Department's intentions, officially, and if there are any objections coming from the Indians, to find out what they are, before so extensive an undertaking be commenced.
The site proposed by the Church authorities, seemed, at the time of Rev. T. Ferrier's visit to Port Simpson, to be the best in view of the desire on the part of the said authorities to have a building upon or closely adjacent to the Mission reserve. A considerable sum of money will have to be spent to make the site a really desirable one for a big institution. Many better sites exist, and it would seem to be a favourable time for the Department to purchase outright a desirable piece of land.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Charles C. Perry,
Indian Agent.

Sirs,

I beg to draw attention to letter to you of the 27th May, and your reply of the 6th instant, relative to your account for school desks which you shipped to British Columbia for the Crosby Girls' School at Port Simpson. In the Department's letter quoted it was pointed out that the freight charges on the consignment amounted to $19.80. It should have been stated that those charges amounted to $19.18. You were reminded that under your agreement with the Department you were to pay the freight charges, with the result that when your account of $83.98 was received, it was paid at $64.80. Apparently you did not read the letter sent you carefully as you seem to be under the impression that the railway company charged freight on the shipment before making delivery. In this you are mistaken. I shall be glad if you will again peruse the Department's letter of the 27th May in a careful manner.

In the last paragraph of your letter you request the issue of a cheque in your favor for $19.80. I may point out that the freight receipt which you have forwarded shows that you actually paid only $16.30 freight charges, although you have shown $19.18 in your account as paid, and you are asking the Department to pay $19.80. In view of the agreement made at the time you received the order it is you and not the Department who should make payment of the freight charges. You will therefore understand that it is not proposed to issue a further cheque in your favor.

Ottawa, August 16th, 1935.

Dear Madam:

The Field Auditor of the Treasury Branch, Department of Finance, recently visited your school in order to make an examination or audit of the books. This is in accordance with a letter No.C150-46, which was sent to you under date of May 27th, 1935.

According to the report submitted by Mr. Holmes, the Auditor, it is necessary for you to be supplied with a Cash Book as furnished to other residential schools by this Department for the purpose of recording accurately the receipts and expenditure of the school's business.

Perhaps you have seen or used one of these books at other schools and will be familiar with its correct use, but in case you have not the following is an outline showing the manner in which it should be kept.

The headings to the columns are, to a large extent, self-explanatory. On the debit or left hand side you will observe all the cash receipts are recorded showing the dates upon which they were received. These receipts are classified under Government per capita grant, Church grants, farming and garden proceeds (if a farm is operated) and proceeds from other sources.

You are requested to ascertain from the W.M.S. the exact amount of the per capita grant which is sent to you and also the amount of the Church grant, if any, when those remittances are sent to you. This will
be necessary in order to keep the Cash Book correctly and to give the desired information to the Department at the end of the fiscal year.

You will, from time to time, deposit these funds in the Bank Account, which by the way should be in the name of the school and not your own name or any other individual. The receipts shown in the Cash Book should agree with the total of the deposits which appear in the Bank Pass Book over any given period, the only exception being when you have cash on hand and have been unable to deposit it in the Bank.

The credit or right hand side of the book is used for expenditure where the expenses are recorded under the various column headings, such as salaries, clothing, food, etc. The enclosed specimen Cash Book sheet which has been written up and balanced as a guide for you covering a month's transactions and by this you will see that all the totals of the different columns of expenses agree with the total on the extreme right hand side of the sheet.

You will also observe that although one cheque may be written for more than one item of expense when it is made out to the same Company or individual the total of the cheque is extended and all cheque numbers must be recorded in the extreme right hand column provided for that purpose.

By recording the cheque numbers carefully you will find that you will save yourself much time when referring back over several months or years for a certain cheque and finding how it was made up. Also when you come to check your Bank Pass Book it is very simple and convenient to be in a position to compare the cheques presented and

cashed
cashed by the Bank with those you have recorded in the Cash Book. In this way you are in a position to know which cheques have not been presented at the Bank, and which should appear as outstanding at a month end or a fiscal year end. This also facilitates checking should your books be audited either by a Church official or the Field Auditor.

At the foot of the attached specimen sheet there has been prepared a Bank Reconciliation statement covering the close of the same period of business for which the cash sheet is written. It is quite simple and very easily followed and if carried out correctly will be satisfactory to you knowing that the Cash Book record agrees with the Bank balance shown in the Pass Book.

It is customary for the principals to assemble the cancelled cheques after they are paid and received from the Bank each month end, in numerical order, and you may also attach the invoice or voucher to the cheque which pays it. Another method which also proves satisfactory is to file the vouchers and invoices alphabetically and write the cheque number which pays it on the face of the account. Either method you will find will help you considerably for reference purposes.

The Cash Book will of course be closed off and totalled at the end of each month and the balance of the total receipts, less the total expenditures, will be carried forward to the following month. These totals of all the headings may be summarized each month at the back of the Cash Book, then when the twelve months' totals have been recorded your financial statement is complete for the fiscal year end (March 31).
The procedure for handling Petty Cash has been written separately and is attached hereto.

Trusting that the foregoing and the attached statements will be of some assistance to you,

Yours truly,

Acting Superintendent of Schools.

You will also observe that although one cheque may be written for more than one item of expense when it is made out to the same Company or individual the total of the cheque is extended and all cheque numbers must be recorded in the extreme right hand column provided for that purpose.

By recording the cheque numbers carefully you will find that you will save yourself much time when referring back over several months or years for a certain cheque and finding how it was made up. Also when you come to check your Bank Pass Book it is very simple and convenient to be in a position to compare the cheques presented and cashed by the Bank with those you have recorded in the Cash Book. In this way you are in a position to know which cheques have not been presented to the Bank, and which should appear as outstanding at a month end or a fiscal year end. This also facilitates checking should your books be audited either by a Church official or the Field Auditor.

At the foot of the attached specimen sheet there has been prepared a Bank Reconciliation statement covering the close of the same period of business for which the cash sheet is written. It is quite simple and very easily followed and if carried out correctly will be satisfactory to you knowing that the Cash Book record agrees with the Bank balance shown in the Pass Book.

It is customary for the principals to assemble the cancelled cheques after they are paid and received from the Bank each month end, in numerical order, and you may also attach the invoice or voucher to the cheque which pays it. Another method which also proves satisfactory is to file the vouchers and invoices alphabetically and write the cheque number which pays it on the face of the account. Either method you will find will help you considerably for reference purposes.

The Cash Book will of course be closed off and totalled at the end of each month and the balance of the total receipts less the total expenditures, will be carried forward to the following month. These totals of all the headings may be summarized each month at the back of the Cash Book, then when the twelve months' totals have been recorded your financial statement is complete for the fiscal year end (March 31).

Dear Mr. Allen,

Submitted herewith is report covering my examination of the books of the Crosby Girls' Home, Port Simpson, B.C.

I was informed by the Agent at Prince Rupert about noon of July 22, that the Principal of this School was leaving on holidays the following morning. I, therefore, proceeded to Port Simpson that afternoon and was shown the books, but as time would not permit more than a hurried examination, I brought such records as were considered necessary back to Prince Rupert. After as thorough an examination as was possible, I met the Principal when passing through on the boat and secured some necessary explanations.

The Principal is Miss L.M. Deacon and while she kept records which were apparently satisfactory for her own purposes, for audit purposes they were not satisfactory.

As there is no branch bank in Port Simpson, the account is kept in the Bank of Toronto, Vancouver, under the title Crosby Girls' Home. All grants are forwarded by the Women's Missionary Society direct to the Bank, without any notification to the Principal as to what they constitute, her only information being that obtained from the statement from the Bank. Cheques issued do not bear much relation to the actual accounts as many cheques are issued to the Hudson's Bay Company for cash, and accounts may be paid all in cash or by cheque or part cash and part cheque. The Bank forwards all paid cheques with statement of account monthly, the statement being checked by Miss Deacon and the receipt signed and returned to the Bank.

The School has never been supplied with the Departmental Cash Book for use at Residential Schools. A small Day Book is used in which the balance at the beginning of the month is debited followed by entries for revenue and on the credit side each individual payment is entered. At the end of each month a summary of expenditure under the headings used by the Department, is made and both debits and credits transferred to a small book used as a Cash Book. Cheques were numbered but the numbers were never entered in the books of account and cheques dated one month might apply to expenditure of a previous month and be so included in the books.

The Principal stated she thought this School was on a different status from other Residential Schools, in that it was more completely controlled by the Women's Missionary Society. For this reason and the fact that the Departmental Cash Book had not been provided, I did not issue any instructions with regard to bookkeeping procedure. If the Cash Book is to be put in use I thought that when forwarding it that instructions might be issued as to its use and the proper bookkeeping procedures.

In order to provide some information as to receipts and expenditures, statement #1 attached herewith was prepared to show Receipts and Expenditures for the fiscal year 1934-35.

The total receipts for the year were $7,079.38 made up of $6,689.38 as the Per Capita and Church Grants and $50.00 as a grant for a scholarship, forwarded by the Women's Missionary Society and $340.00 paid by the teachers for board and room, being at the rate of $10.00 per month each for three teachers.

The total expenditures were $7,080.83.
Of this total $2,291.52 was for Salaries of teachers, $320.73 for Clothing and $1,779.07 for Food.

Under the heading Phone, Light and Fuel, the total was $896.58 of which $727.75 was for coal and wood.

Furniture for Buildings and Repairs amounted to $804.78, of which $266.43 was for bath-room fixtures and installation, $229.90 for repairs to the furnace, $85.00 for repairs to the roof and $52.55 for calamine in the School building. The Principal stated that no added allowance was made by the Department for any of this expenditure.

Expenditure for House Equipment amounted to $600.59 of which $250.00 was for the purchase and installation of a small Delco system for lighting purposes, the balance for cleaning materials and utensils and dishes and kitchen utensils.

Expenditure for Extra Labour amounted to $195.20 which is made up of payments for domestic service and the services of a handyman.

Of a total of $138.76 under the heading Miscellaneous, $50.00 was for the payment of the scholarship as provided for in the receipts to the School, about $50.00 for Hospital and Medical expenses for the pupils and the balance for newspaper subscriptions and other incidentals.

The cost of operations as shown by statement #2, is based on the actual cash expenditure only as there are no farming operations carried on.

The averages are based on an attendance of 27 pupils.

The Per Capita could not be separated from the Church Grants for, as explained before in this report, the Women's Missionary Society forwarded funds direct to the Bank without notifying the Principal as to whether they were Government or Church grants, and it is therefore impossible to show the amount allowed by Government grant per pupil per day.

Submitted herewith is report of an examination of the books and records at the above-mentioned Residential School covering the period of sixteen months dating April 1, 1935, to July 31, 1936, completed on September 3.

The account for the School is kept in the Bank of Toronto, Vancouver, as there is no bank in Port Simpson. This is another school where, due to inconvenient banking facilities, much of the expenditure is made by cash which is obtained at the store of the Hudson's Bay Company, where cheques are cashed for the School. Such cheques are usually in amounts of $25.00 to $50.00, while payments were noted for amounts as high as $65.00.

A record of cash receipts and payments is not kept. The Principal informed me she kept a statement for each month at the end of which expenditures were classified and entered in the cash book and the statement destroyed.

A small Day Book was used as a cash book until January 1, 1936, when the Departmental Cash Receipts and Expenditures Book, which had been received in November, was opened. This book had been written up to June 30th.

Receipts were never secured for cash payments and the monthly account of the Hudson's Bay Company was the only detailed account covering payments by cheque.

In order to illustrate the proper keeping of the records I wrote up and balanced the cash book for July and instructed the Principal regarding the system of bookkeeping and filing of records which the Department was endeavouring to establish at Residential Schools, and in order to confirm verbal instructions prepared memorandum attached herewith as Exhibit A, a copy of which was forwarded to the School.

Bank and Cash Book Reconciliation.

From date of last audit receipts as shown by the cash book were compared to credit entries in Bank statements and cancelled cheques to debit entries in Bank statements and expenditure entries, when entered in the cash book. Additions, extensions and balances were checked.

Bank and cash book reconciliation at March 31 and July 31, 1936, is shown in statement #1. Cash on hand at July 31 was $281.00.

RECEIPTS and EXPENDITURES.

Statement #2 shows receipts and expenditures for the year April 1, 1935 to March 31, 1936.

Receipts - Total receipts amounted to $7,087.52 of which $6,767.52 was received from the Women's Missionary Society and $320.00 in payment for board by the staff of three, at the rate of $10.00 per month each.

As the Women's Missionary Society transfer funds from Toronto direct to the account of the School in the Bank of Toronto, Vancouver, and notify the Principal stating only the total amount of such transfers, it was not possible to definitely establish the amount of the per capita grant. The amounts shown in the statement were estimated by the Principal from attendances during the different quarterly periods.

Expenditures - Expenditures as shown under the various classification headings in statement #2 are shown in detail in Statement #3.

As accounts were not available for analysis the break-down in statement #3 was made from information supplied by the Principal from memory.

Under Buildings and Repairs as shown are amount of $156.80 for repairs to dam and pipes for water supply. In explanation of this expenditure, I was informed that the water for the School flows down from the hills and is dammed back at a certain point in the stream, from which it is piped to the School. During last winter the pipes burst as a result freezing and in the spring part of the dam was destroyed due to flood conditions.

The payment for extra labour consists principally of a monthly wage averaging about $10.00 paid to an Indian for performing such manual labour as is required about the School, as there is no male member on the staff. Additional expenditure under this heading was for saving wood for winter's use.

Sufficient details could not be obtained to analyze Miscellaneous expenditure. I was informed it consisted of subscription to one newspaper, church papers and leaflets, drugs, postage and stationery.
COSTS OF OPERATION.

Statement §4 shows costs of operations for the year based on an expenditure of $7,010.03 and an average attendance of 27.75 pupils.

The average cost per pupil per day was 69 cents, while the amount allowed by the estimated per capita grant per pupil per day was 42.4 cents.

A small garden is planted but the amount of produce raised is negligible. The cost of supplies is increased considerably by freight costs.

The staff, occupations and salaries at September 3 are listed, the salaries per annum being $2,295.00, of which about $300.00 per annum is repaid to the School for board.

Memorandum

Miss L.M. Deacon,

This memorandum covering bookkeeping procedure as the Department is endeavouring to establish it at Residential Schools, has been prepared to confirm verbal instructions issued when at your School.

Payments should be made by cheque whenever the cashing of same would not greatly inconvenience the payee.

All cheques should be numbered and those in payment of accounts or services entered in the Cash Book, those issued for cash should not be entered in the Cash Book, but should be accounted for through a Record of Cash Payments.

Cash Book

All revenue to the School should be entered on the Dr. side of the Cash Book in the appropriate column and in due course deposited in the Bank.

Cheques entered should show the cheque number in the outer right hand column for the month in which they are issued. Expenditures should be classified and entered in the appropriate column. Detailed accounts should be secured on which the number of the paying cheque should be entered and the accounts filed by cheque number.

Record of Cash Payments.

This record should be started as from August 1. On the Dr. side the first entry will be the amount of $22.50, shown as cash on hand at July 31, by Bank Reconciliation statement, followed by cheques issued and cashed for the month. Such entries will include date, cheque number and amount.
On the Cr. side (right hand page of book) will be entered each item of expenditure, the entries to show date, name of payee, what the payment covers and amount. Receipts should be secured for payments of $2.00 and over and filed together in order of payment.

At the end of each month the account should be added and balanced, the balance being carried forward to the following month. Expenditure for the month should be classified and entered in the Cash Book under the appropriate classification headings.

Bank Reconciliation.

As cheques issued to obtain cash will not be entered in the Cash Book, it will be necessary when reconciling the Cash Book balance with the Bank balance at the end of each month, to include the balance of cash on hand as shown by the Record of Cash Payments. This is illustrated in Bank and Cash Book Reconciliation at July 31, statement #1.

Dear Sir,

Re: Crosby Girl's School

Submitted herewith is report of examination of the Books and Records of the above named Residential School covering the period of thirteen months, dating from the 1st of April, 1926, to the 30th of April, 1927, completed the 9th of June, 1927.

As mentioned in the last report, the method of obtaining cash through the Hudson Bay store on account of inconvenient Banking facilities, continued, the Creditors in many cases refusing to accept cheques in payment of indebtedness.

Receipts are now being obtained for paid accounts and same are being carefully filed away in good order.

The Principal, however, did not seem to understand that cheques issued in payment of accounts should be written in the Cash Book immediately in numerical order opposite the creditors account, but, waited until the end of the month and then wrote in the cancelled cheques only, as returned by the Bank; then listed her outstanding cheques below and deducted same from the Bank Balance, which showed a net balance agreeing in each case with her balance after she had deducted the distributed expenditures for the month from the debit side of her Cash Book. I went into this matter with her and I believe she now understands exactly what to do. Apart from the foregoing, she is satisfactorily complying with the instructions as issued by Mr. Holmes.

Bank and Cash Book Reconciliation.

From date of last audit, receipts, as shown by the Cash Book, were compared to credit entries in Bank Statements, and cancelled cheques to debit entries in Bank Statements and expenditure entries. Additions, extensions and balances were checked.

Bank and Cash Book reconciliation at March 31st and April 30th are shown in Statement #1 attached; Cash on hand the 30th of April being $173.45. No Bank Statement for May had been received at time of my visit and very few accounts paid, so that definite figures beyond 30th of April were not available.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit a report of an examination made of the books and records at the above school on October 12 - 1938. The examination covered a period of 17 months dating from April 1 - 1937 to August 31 - 1938.

Bank Reconciliation (Statement 1)

The cash book was written up to the end of August and statement from the Bank of Commerce, Vancouver, gave a balance of $1607.82 as at that date. The outstanding cheques amounted to $103.50, and with cash on hand of $22.01 as per petty cash journal gave net balance of $1576.97 which agreed with cash book.

All receipts as per cash book are deposited in bank. Paid cheques were examined and compared to cash book entries. Vouchers were all on file by months and these were compared to synoptic entries and petty cash journal by test. A decided improvement is shown in the cash book and a reconciliation is made each month, and balance carried forward.

Receipts and Expenditures

This statement was prepared from a recap of the monthly synoptic totals and statement 2 gives the expenditures in detail.

The total receipts for this period amounted to $1049.28. The per capita grant is shown as $7094.75, but this is only the matron's estimate as the cheque goes to the W.M.S. Toronto and the per capita and church grant is received in one cheque at the school. The head office in Toronto should notify the school as to the amount received from the Department from the per capita grant.

The expenditures amounted to $9274.78 and are self-explanatory. The cost of clothing at $11.94 per child is not high but the cost of food at $68.76 per pupil is above normal and due to some extent to the location of the school. The cost per child per year was $233.31 and is very high for a residential school. It is apparently very necessary for the church to contribute about $2000.00 a year to finance this school.

The average attendance was 28 pupils and the staff of three carry on all the work.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit a report of an audit made at the above School on February 26th, 1940. The audit covered a period of 17 months dating from September 1st, 1938 to January 31st, 1940.

Bank Reconciliation - Statement 1.

The bank statement as at January 31st, gave a balance of $1,959.28 and the outstanding cheques amounted to $289.78. The cash on hand as per petty cash book showed $30.09 and the net balance of $1,699.59 agreed with cash book. Cheques were examined and compared to cash book entries and vouchers. Very few cheques are issued due to practically all the larger purchases being made at one place, and petty cash used for all small local purchases.

The petty cash book was examined and compared to vouchers. The per capita and church grants are mailed from Toronto to the bank in Vancouver for deposit.

The total receipts for this period amounted to $9,723.37. The per capita grant and church grant are sent from Toronto in one amount and are computed as to their total by the principal. I would recommend that the principal be advised as to the proper amount to credit to per capita.

The expenditures amounted to $9,600.75 and are shown in detail on Statement 3. All expenditures are about normal and the extra labour of $434.38 takes care of all male help required during the period.

There are no farming operations carried on at this School and no livestock. The cost of operation per pupil at $250.99 is very high and requires considerable aid from the church. It is impossible for a school of this size to operate on its earnings. The cost of clothing at $9.63 is rather low, and cost of food at $67.76 per pupil above normal. The average attendance of pupils was 27 and the staff numbers 3.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit a report of an audit made at the above School on February 24th, 1941. The audit covered a period of 12 months ended January 31st, 1941.

The Statement from the Bank of Montreal, Vancouver, gave a balance of $451.48 as at January 31st. There was one outstanding cheque in the amount of $20.00 and cash on hand was shown as $2.97. The net balance of $414.45 agreed with cash book.

The cheques from Toronto are sent direct to the bank in Vancouver. All cheques were compared to cash book entries and vouchers were checked to synoptic. Practically all supplies are purchased from the local Hudson's Bay store by cheque. Petty cash is used for small purchases from Indians.

The total revenue for this period was $3746.23. The per capita grant as received from Toronto was $3700.00, but does not include the total earnings for the year.

The expenditures amounted to $5031.37 and are shown in detail on Statement 2. There is a large decrease shown in all expenditures this year. The food costs show a reduction of $13.87 per pupil and clothing a reduction of $5.18.

The cost of operation shows a reduction of $4.79 per day and $77.50 per pupil. The full grant of $175.00 would appear to be being paid to this School. The average attendance was 29, an increase of 2, and the staff remains at three.

There is no farm or garden at this School and extra labour is done by the Indians.

The books and records were in very good condition and up-to-date. While the cost of operation is very low this period, the supplies on hand are small and expenditures will be heavier. The school would appear to be in a good financial condition.

The cost per pupil per year was $189.88, an increase of $16.39, but is not high in comparison with other small schools.

The principal advised that there were no unpaid accounts, and the school would appear to be in good financial condition. The books and records were in good shape and up to date.

The small amount of Sundry Revenue was used to reimburse petty cash, and not deposited. Cash expenditures are not particularly heavy, and are unavoidable owing to the lack of banking facilities at Port Simpson.

The Cash book was written up to date and in balance. The synoptic distribution was reasonably correct.

Revenue & Expenditure

Dear Sir:

RE: Fort Simpson Residential School

I submit herewith the report of an audit made at the above School covering the period June 1, 1946 to July 31, 1947.

Bank Reconciliation - (Statement #1)

The Bank Statement and cancelled cheques had not been received for the month of July 1947. The Statement from the Bank of Toronto at Vancouver showed an overdraft of $46.05 as at June 31, 1947, and outstanding cheques as listed amounted to $353.68 in June and $18.96 in July. Cash on hand was verified in the amount of $19.76 for a net overdraft as per Cash Book of $398.93 at July 31.

The overdraft as per Cash Book as at June 30, 1947 was $660.81 while expenditures in July amounted to $38.12 and receipts amounted to $300.00 thereby reconciling with the net bank balance. The $300.00 was credited by the bank in June but was not entered in the Cash Book until July.

All cancelled cheques for the period together with those outstanding from the previous audit were examined and checked to the Cash Book entries. Vouchers were on hand in support of expenditures and as examined by test, appeared to be in order.

The per capita grant constitutes practically all the Revenue and is mailed directly to the Bank of Toronto at Vancouver by the Women's Missionary Society, (United Church of Canada) Toronto.

Cash Reconciliation - (Statement #1)

Sundry revenue amounting to $294.07 was received but not deposited, being used for petty cash expenditures. A further $30.00 was received for this purpose from the bank account and total expenditures supported by voucher amounted to $364.03. The balance of $19.76 was verified as being on hand. Cash expenditures are unavoidable owing to the lack of banking facilities at Port Simpson.

Revenue and Expenditures - (Statement #2)

A total of $11,024.42 was received during the period, not including a refund of a Travel Advance as per contra. The
per capita advance accounted for $10,740.35 and the balance of $294.07 represented sundry revenue. No deductions were made from staff members for board.

The disbursements amounted to $11,498.35 showing a comparative increase in the cost of operation over the last corresponding period. The following summary shows the relative increase or decrease per month under the various synoptic headings.

| Miscellaneous 17.01    | 9.51                   | 7.50  |
| Monthly Increase 582.35 | 821.31                 | 304.34|
|                       |                        | 65.38 |

The fluctuations in the costs from year to year are due, for the most part, to the practice of charging expenses in total to the period in which they are paid. In the previous audit, for example, coal purchases were negligible, due to the large inventory at the beginning of the audit period resulting in a corresponding decrease in the fuel costs.

Cost of Operations - (Statement #3)

The breakdown of the costs shows an increase in each category over the previous audit while the attendance has decreased.

The cost of operation per pupil per year has risen from $307.24 for the last period to $473.83, an increase of $166.59 and has more than doubled in the past two years. The average pupil attendance from the four quarterly returns ending June 30, 1947 was 20.8, a decrease from 26 in the previous year.

General

The books and records were fairly well maintained and have been kept up to date. Operations apparently ceased in July 1947 and at the time of the audit the school was closed and no staff were available, as a result it has not been possible to determine if there are any contingent liabilities.

I submit herewith the report of an audit made at the above School covering the period August 1, 1947 to August 31, 1948. This school was officially closed in June, 1948.

Bank Reconciliation

The certificate of the Bank of Toronto, Vancouver, B.C., Statement - 2, shows a credit balance of $431.96. There was one unrepresented cheque for $3.50, leaving a bank balance of $428.46, which with the cash on hand 34 cents equalled the cash balance of $428.82 as showing in the Cash Book.

The Secretary:

In further reference to Mr Devlin's application for the establishment of schools for the Indians of Douglas, Skookum-Chuck, Sam-ah-quan, Homalke, Ela-Hoose, Sechelt, Squamish and Pemberton Meadows the undersigned begs to say that in a former communication from Mr Devlin he asked for the establishment of three boarding schools with accommodation for 50 pupils each to be located at the following places: Pemberton Meadows, Sechelt and Squamish and he claimed that when Mr Reed, the late Deputy Superintendent in British Columbia, he agreed to recommend the establishment of a school at Squamish although Mr Reed claimed that he was under the impression that he only agreed to provide for a day school.

A special application was again made for the establishment of a boarding school at Squamish by the Roman Catholic Bishop of New Westminster and a memorandum was prepared by Mr McKenna addressed to the Minister in reference to this application to which the Minister replied that nothing could be done at present and Mr Auley Morrison, M.P., was so informed.

Mr Agent Devlin's application for the establishment of three boarding schools would entail
an annual expenditure of $3000.00 each for maintenance alone. Buildings would also have to be provided which could not be put up for less than $500 each. And equipment and incidentals would bring the total cost of this application, if granted, up to $30,000.

Although there are a number of Roman Catholic Indian children in the District referred to, I think if a boarding school were opened at Squamish, it would meet the present requirements and would necessitate an expenditure in the neighborhood of $10,000 for buildings equipment and maintenance.

Mr Devlin expressly stated in his first application that day schools would be of no use in the districts referred to and that boarding schools were the kind required.

OTTAWA, 4th December, 1901:

The Secretary:-

Mr. Supt. Vowell forwards a letter from Agent Devlin who states that the Sechelt Indians complain that they are not provided with a school for their children and suggests the opening of a boarding school for the Indian bands in that neighborhood and another for the children of the natives of the Pemberton Meadows locality. Agent Devlin states that there are 42 children of school age resident at present on the Sechelt reserve, not one of whom can read, write or speak English. Mr. Supt. Vowell recommends the application made by the Agent on behalf of these Indians to the serious consideration of the Department in order that a boarding establishment for the large number of children in the district may be opened as soon as possible.

The principal reserve of the Sechelt Indians is situated on a reserve of that name, which I have shown on a rough sketch herewith. There are 234 Indians in the Band with a school population of 42 as above stated. They are all said to have comfortable dwellings and are industrious and well behaved. Their principal resources are fishing, hunting and hand-logging with a little gardening.

It seems to me that if a day school were opened on this reserve it would afford all the educational facilities required. These Indians are all Roman Catholics and are ministered to by Rev. Father
Chirouse, who has put up a fine church, which is shown in the Passion Play held last summer, photographs of which were sent you by Mr Agent Devlin. A very interesting account of this Passion Play is given in the Christmas number of the Metropolitan Magazine, a copy of which is in the Department.

Applications for boarding schools in British Columbia are becoming very numerous but I fail to see why they are considered necessary there as the Coast Indians especially are all well-to-do and able to provide for their children, and to teach them while they are young the pursuits they will have to follow in order to obtain a livelihood in after life. Of course assistance should be given them in the matter of education but I would not advise its going any further than provision for day schools, as it would be quite possible to increase the existing accommodation at Industrial and Boarding schools, if necessary.

The want of a knowledge of English is not so great as might appear as all the Indians of this locality speak Chinook, which is understood by all residents on the Coast.

To the Honorable Mr. Sifton
Chief of the Indian Affairs in Ottawa

Honorable Sir,

I will make use of this little schooling I received at the school of the Father of St. Mary's mission, to let you know what we want; we have a great number of children who ought to go to school but they cannot go because we have no school. We have over seventy children who are old enough.

Now we come to ask you to help us to have a school; if you will you can help us right away. First help us to build our school house where our children can be looked after as we have to go far away from our village to make our living; our children ought to be kept at a boarding school while we have to go to our work—we are sometimes four and five months away.

Then we would like that the government could give what is given elsewhere for boarding our children at school.

We have the promise of our bishop who has already done much for us to get sisters to look after our children at the school our children are growing up and they do not learn anything.
it is too bad—but what can we do if the government does not help us? Long ago the government who came here, Governors Douglas and Seymour told the Indians of this country to be quiet and not make trouble because their land was taken away. They gave their word coming from the queen that the Indians would be well treated, that they would get tools, seed, medicine and doctors' help and especially school in exchange for their land. Now, we have a right to a school, if the government does not wish to give us a school then give us back our land and we will get our school. We write you this now because we know that you as the principle chief of the Indian Department in the government of Canada, can help us—we have good hope in you and we expect that you will help us now; we know that the King has a governor in Ottawa but we will not write to him now, we will wait help from you first.

Another Governor from Ottawa who came here once, Governor Dufferin said that the Indians of British Columbia have not been given their right yet, they never got anything for their land—that is true today. Now we think that the government ought to something for us right away, we hear that...
The Methodist School of Chilliwack gets ten thousand dollars every year, now we know there are very few Methodist among the Indians there, why is that. Here we are so many Catholic Indians, why should we have no school—the School at St Mary Mission cannot take our children, the school is too poor.
