Memorandum:

Chief Julius of the Sechelt Band, B.C., writes under date of the 1st inst., applying for the establishment of a boarding-school on the Reserve. A similar application was received in November, 1891, from Mr. Agent Devlin through Superintendent Vowell, and I consider that the memorandum I then prepared covers the ground. The Minister decided that no action was then necessary.

There are two Roman Catholic Boarding-schools to which their children could be sent provided there was room for them, and, rather than open another boarding-school, I think it would be better to provide for more pupils at these boarding-schools if it was deemed necessary to secure boarding-school accommodation for some of the Sechelt children. As they are wholly without educational facilities, I think that a day-school might be allowed them.

OTTAWA, 10th February, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In further reference to the application of the Sechelt Band of Indians for permission to expend the sum of $1,000.00 from their funds in the purchase of furnishings for their new school building, I beg to say that a detailed list of the articles required has been forwarded by Mr Agent McDonald to the Department through Mr Supt. Vowell amounting to $1016.36.

A resolution was passed by a majority of the male members of the Band for the expenditure of $1000.00 for this purpose on the 19th Sept. last and is turned out herewith. These Indians have a sufficient amount to their credit to meet this outlay and they have put up a school building themselves at a cost of about $7000.00. The Department was not consulted on this subject, although applications had previously been received for the establishment of a boarding school on that reserve, which were endorsed by Mr Devlin, the late Agent and Mr Vowell.

The last time this matter was before the Minister was in December 1901, when he decided that no action could be taken and Mr Vowell was so informed. Two communications were subsequently received from the Chief demanding the establishment of a boarding school, but he was informed that the Department could not accede to his request. The Indians, as I said...
before, have built the school, which is to be placed in charge of the Roman Catholic Sisters, and the expenditure they now wish to make out of their funds will equip it for 50 pupils.

The Department has never recognized this school in any way and no provision has been made for its maintenance. It is now completed, however, and will be ready for occupation when furnished and the Department will no doubt be expected to give it the usual support granted to boarding schools. It would appear that whoever is at the back of this movement is desirous of forcing the hand of the Department into recognizing this school. The Band has the requisite funds to its credit and claims the right to spend it in equipment. If the Department authorizes this outlay, it will be tantamount to recognizing the school.

To the Honorable Clifford Sifton, M.P.
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir:

We, the undersigned chiefs and Indians of the Sechelt tribe come to lay before you our needs in the matter of the education of our children and to beg you to grant our requests.

We have often before asked of the Government through our agent that we should be given a school for we see our children growing up around us without any learning. Our children don't know how to speak or write the English language.

Last Spring we wrote directly to yourself; but so far we have had only refusals.

This is very hard to bear, for we think of all the things we have had to lose since the white men came and we were forced to give up all but a few small strips of our lands.

The Governors sent out by the Queen always promised that we would have some return for what we gave up, that we would be helped in many ways. We were told that we would have schools; but up to now the promises have been vain. Yet we believe that we have a good right to get help from the Government.

To show the Government that we mean what we say we all combined last spring to get enough from our labor to have a school house put up.

We
We were lucky enough to get a merchant from here, Mr. Whittaker, to take the logs we would cut and in exchange he built the school house we wanted.

We don't know how we shall get through if the government does not help us at once. We need help to complete and furnish the building and we need a grant for boarding our children once at school.

There will be room for fifty children boys and girls. We must have a school wherein our children can be boarded, for, as we have to go pretty far away from our village to make our living, our children must be kept at school while we are away.

As we are all Catholics we love our religion and we wish to have our children trained under Catholic sisters. Our Bishop has gone to great trouble to secure good teachers for us and they are now waiting for the school to be finished with your help.

We pray and hope that you, who understand our needs will hear us and grant our request at once. You may be sure that we will be thankful and that we shall make a good use of what shall be given us to maintain our school.

We remain very humbly

Your wards of the Sachelt tribe.

To the Honorable CLIFFORD SIFTON,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Can.,

HONORABLE SIR,

Some time ago the Indians of the Sechelt tribe, who live about fifty miles up the coast, north of Vancouver city, sent you a petition to the effect that you would give them an annual grant for a Boarding School as well as a grant to help them to finish the school building which they have themselves erected on their reserve.

In this petition they have told you what they have done towards the long deferred realization of a wish to have a school on their reserve.

Now they have requested me to assist them in obtaining what they have asked for in their petition.

Even should they not have asked me to plead with them I feel prompted to do all I can for them for the reason that I, as their bishop, take a hearty interest in their progress, and because I am convinced that the Boarding School, for which they have a grant, will be of great benefit to them.

Now these Indians deserve that the Government should not defer any longer to grant them what they ask.

Apart from their constant docility and submission to the laws of the country and their admirable efforts to become virtuous citizens of this Dominion, for which the Department should have regard, these Indians have shown in a most practical manner that their wish to improve by education is no mere pretense. They have set with a will to erect a school building for which they have partly paid by their industry.

No better encouragement could be given by the Government to these people than by coming to their assistance at once and enabling them to finish their undertaking. You, Honorable Sir, who have their advancement so much at heart, can appreciate their energy and perseverance in the work which they have done so far, because these qualities are precisely those which need most to be developed in the natives.
For my part I have, from the beginning of their undertaking, promised to do my share to help them. I have secured a good staff of Sisters who are prepared to teach the school branches and the various industries. I shall also give every other assistance that I am able to give to place the School on a good footing, as soon as the Government shall have given the needed cooperation for the completion of the enterprise.

I trust, therefore, that, for the reasons given above and for others which are clear to you, who have such a wide experience with the Indians, you will grant the requests contained in the petition of the Sechelt Indians.

Both Mr. Vowell, the Superintendent for Bri. Col. and Mr. Mac Donald, the Agent for New Westminster District, have visited the new premises erected at Sechelt. They find that the building will comfortably accommodate the number of children for which a per capita grant is asked, namely fifty.

Mr. Vowell must have forwarded to the Department the plans and specifications of the school building, towards the finishing of which the Government ought to allow a grant of at least 2500 Dollars, which sum represents about one fourth of the whole cost.

As on previous occasions, when I had the opportunity to lay before you the needs of our Indians, I found you ready to support our efforts towards their advancement, I hope to have the satisfaction to learn that in this case you shall grant the requests of your petitioners, in whose behalf I have the honor to address you today, and that the grants asked for will be placed on the list of estimates which shall be voted during the present session of Parliament.

I have the honor to be,

Honorable and dear Sir,

Your humble servant,

Memorandum:

Deputy Superintendent General.

I beg to say that it appears to me necessary to come to a definite decision in regard to the manner in which the Department will deal with the Sechelt Boarding School, in the Fraser River Agency. If it is decided to afford assistance to the Institution provision for the same will have to be made in the Supplementary Estimates. The case is as follows:

In 1899 the Sechelt Indians applied to the Department for educational facilities for their children. They were informed that the Department could not then accede to their request. They renewed their application from time to time, but the Department did not consider it advisable to establish a school. Finally, without authority from the Department they undertook the erection of a school building. In March last Mr Agent McDonald submitted, through Supt. Vowell, accounts showing that $6306.95 had been expended on the building and stated that the estimated cost of completing the building was $8428.95, of which the Indians have already paid $2798.05. It appears that the Indians proposed defraying the cost of erection by the sale of logs but after they had made their arrangements and the work had begun, the price of logs dropped nearly 50%. They now find themselves unable to complete the building without assistance. Owing to the logs having deteriorated in price they attribute their inability to complete the building themselves and they now ask the Department to assist them to the extent of $2,500.00 in paying for the structure. While the building was in course of construction the Department was asked to pay $270.00 from Band funds of the Sechelt Indians towards the purchase of galvanized iron water pipe and also to authorize an expenditure of $93.75 for a drain pipe in connection with the building. The necessary authority was granted in both cases. Authority was also asked for the expenditure.
expenditure of $1,000.00 from Band funds for furnishings for the school building. Outlay for this purpose up to $601.90 was allowed. The Agent has been told that he must await further instructions before incurring expenditure for this purpose up to $1,000.00.

The building has accommodation for 50 pupils and the Department is now asked in addition to the above to furnish a per capita grant of $60.00 for each of 50 pupils.

I think the Indians are entitled to sympathy for the position in which they find themselves. The efforts which they have made to provide themselves with a boarding school are laudable, but they have undertaken more than they could possibly carry out. I am convinced that they must have been advised towards this course probably by the resident Priest so that no matter how great sympathy be extended to them, the position resolves itself into this: the hand of the Department has been forced by the ecclesiastical authorities certainly should not be permitted. The educational policy of the Department and the right to establish or dis-continue schools must reside with the Department, and the most dangerous precedent which we could establish is the present that we should finally become responsible for the boarding school which we time and again refused to sanction.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr School Inspector Green has reported on the Sechelt boarding school, which was opened in July last and has an enrollment of 46 pupils. He reports very favorably on the school, which is conducted by the Roman Catholics. The building was put up at a cost of nearly $10,000 towards which the Indians have paid over $3000.00; the balance is still due. As the school is not receiving any per capita grant at present, and is being carried on on credit, a large deficit will be piled up before they can receive any Government aid. Provision is made in the estimates for next fiscal year for 50 pupils at $60 per capita and $2500.00 towards the building. This will not be available until the 1st July next.

The school was built without obtaining the authority of or consulting the Department and starts with a debit balance in the neighborhood of $5000.00, even allowing for the $2500.00 which is not yet available. Before any grant, either for maintenance or buildings, is paid over to this school, a clear understanding should be arrived at with the Church that the Department, not being a party to this deficit, is in no way responsible or liable. It would be better to settle this matter definitely before any money changes hands.

They would take heart if they could soon turn their efforts towards rebuilding what they have lost.
You know how important the church was for them. It was their pride, their consolation. They never gathered in their church but they came forth better men and more determined to improve. Truly, it is to their church that we must principally attribute the good that was done amongst them.

Here then is an occasion to do so by lessening the burden weighing on the poor people on account of their heavy debt on the school building. Let the Government grant at least $2000 towards the school debt and the Indians will take heart again. They will renew their efforts to pay off the balance that would still remain, and then turn their energies toward the rebuilding of their church.

I trust that you will use your influence to induce the Department to receive favorably the petition for help which the Indians have already forwarded to the Honorable Superintendent General.

Honorable Sir:

We, the Chiefs and men of the Tecleh tribe, approach you as petitioners in favor of our school, with the confidence that you will do something for us.

Three years ago we built a schoolhouse wherein our children of school age might find shelter and instruction. This building cost us over $10,000.
We had started to pay this sum by putting our work together and we succeeded to raise $3000 before the Government granted us $2500 in 1905.

The help which the Government gave us pleased and encouraged us very much. We were determined to continue paying off the debt, which amounts still to $5000; when a fire completely destroyed our beautiful church. We had no insurance. All was lost.

This misfortune made us all downhearted; we feel as though we have no strength left. We cannot do without a church. Without a church we cannot keep together and practice our duties as Christians and citizens.

Sir:—

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, No. 202, O. S., regarding Dr. Brydone-Jack's report on his recent visit to the Sechelt school and village.

In reply I beg to say that it appears to me the Doctor has given expression to very extreme views in connection with existing conditions amongst the Sechelt Indians, apparently for the purpose of impressing upon the Department his views in regard to establishing a hospital or hospitals for the treatment of Indians.

I consider that the sanitary conditions and surroundings of the Indians of this agency, including those of Sechelt, compare very favorably with those of white people in similar circumstances, and, in my opinion, some people expect too much of the Indians in this and many other respects.

It is quite true that the Indians in general object to dieting, and they will give solid food to the sick when it should not be given, and this practice, I am inclined to think, causes many deaths, especially amongst the children. Their chief objection to being placed in a hospital is because they cannot get plenty of food at all times.

A. W. Vowell, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent, B.C.,
Victoria, B.C.
There are a good many deaths in the Sechelt village every year, mostly children, and I am quite sure that a good many are caused by other diseases than tuberculosis. The only cases of tuberculosis I am aware of at the present time at Sechelt are Chief Johnny, who has been sick for about two years, and Mrs. John Baptist, who has been sick for several months. There is also a little boy, Cassimere, who has been a pupil in the school, and recently a patient in St. Paul's Hospital, but now at home. This boy is now said to have tuberculosis, although, by referring to Dr. Brydone-Jack's letter of the 27th ultimo, which was attached to voucher in favor of St. Paul's Hospital, for treatment of this patient (Cassimere), and forwarded from this office March 30th, it will be noticed that the Doctor stated then that, if this boy had been left in the Hospital, he thinks he could have cured him. It does seem rather strange to me that, if this boy had such a good chance of recovery if left in the Hospital, he should now be in the last stages of consumption, in fact his death is hourly expected. I have always had the impression that consumption is rather a lingering illness; however, I am not a doctor.

In regard to the Doctor's statement that "there are very few families there but have had some time recently a death in the family from tuberculosis." I may say that I am not aware that the Doctor has made more than two visits to Sechelt during the past five or six years, and could not, therefore, have seen many of those who died during that time; and, consequently, this part of his report
report would appear to be based on hearsay.

From the records in this office it is noticed that the population of Sechelt in 1900 was 226, in 1901 - 234, 1902 - 236, 1903 - 236, 1904 - 238, 1905 - 239, 1906 - 230, 1907 - 235, 1908 - 242, 1909 - 244.

The complete isolation of a sick person in a family is a very difficult matter even amongst white people who are considered highly civilized and educated; and it seems to have taken a long time to educate the doctors themselves as to the contagious nature of tuberculosis.

In visiting Indians suffering from any ailment, especially consumption, it is a rare thing not to find by the bedside a dish of some kind, chiefly a tin can or cup, in which they expectorate instead of on the floor.

It is, unfortunately, too true that there are many cases of tuberculosis amongst the Indians, and if it is of the contagious nature now claimed by eminent physicians, steps should be taken to properly isolate such cases as appear from time to time amongst the various bands, not only for the benefit of the Indians, but also for the protection of whites with whom they come in contact in the ordinary course of business.

This complete isolation can, in my opinion, only be accomplished by quarantining those affected, as is done in the case of other infectious diseases, or removing them to some hospital or place remote from the reserves, where they cannot be taken home by parents or relatives.

I fear that Dr. Brydone-Jack's hospital scheme on the reserves would accomplish very little more than has been
been done in the past by those who have been instructing and advising them, as the influence a nurse could have on the Indians would be a very slow process if the Indians were allowed to enter and leave such an institution as they wish, and would not, I think, fulfill the prompt action recommended by the Doctor.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

On Saturday, April 5th, I left Vancouver at twelve o'clock, arriving in Sechelt about six o'clock. That evening I visited the school there and found that the Sisters had done most excellent work in connection with the management of the pupils in their care, both physically as well as mentally. The children that had been there for some time showed marked superiority to any children in the village who had not taken advantage of the school. Sister Therisine, who is in charge, is most painstaking as regards the physical well-being of those under her charge. She is laboring under many disadvantages however, although these are being gradually lessened. It is very difficult to overcome the superstition and ignorance of the Indians who cannot see that everything is being done for their own ultimate benefit and again as some of the children come from tubercular stock and as there are a number of tubercular cases in the village at the present time, it is extremely difficult and almost impossible to prevent the children mingling with the Indians in the village who are afflicted with this disease. The Indians will not permit any isolation and you
cannot make them realize the danger of contact in close rooms for those who are at the present time free from disease with those who are afflicted with tubercular disease, and the consequence is that it will be advisable to visit the school at certain intervals and examine the pupils carefully to ascertain whether any of them have contracted tuberculosis. The pupils are all examined very carefully upon entrance and while they may be perfectly free from any evidence of tuberculosis in the first place, yet they may contract it from associating with those who are suffering from it in the village. Moreover, there are very few families there but what have had, some time recently, a death in the family from tuberculosis. One case, a little girl who was examined a short time ago, was then perfectly well, now there is evidence of tuberculosis commencing. This case I have given sick leave of absence and told them to send her home.

The examination of each individual pupil lasted until 11 or 12 o'clock that night. But with very few exceptions, all were in very excellent condition.

In the early morning I went around the village and saw as many as possible of those who were sick. I found tuberculosis present in quite a few cases. In one family, the father has been suffering from
consumption for the last two or three years and although he has been warned of the danger of giving the disease to others, the warning had no effect. He himself is now in the last stage of tuberculosis and frequently has visitors in a close room and he himself goes around and mingles promiscuously in the different houses and expectorates more or less freely around the different rooms, so that in all probability, the spread of tuberculosis will be very great. In one other family, the mother and two children are suffering from tuberculosis and the father looked as if he would be a ripe subject before very long. The only way that anything can be done with these cases is to provide them with a house up there with large verandas and put in charge a nurse who will gradually impress on their minds the necessity for isolation of these cases. It would be impossible to consider the project of building a small hospital anywhere but just in their midst, because they will not go to it and you cannot compel them to. Even at the present time in cases where the Indians are suffering from tubercular abscesses that require surgical treatment and surgical dressing, we cannot persuade them to remain in the hospital and receive proper treatment. They want to be among their own family and among their own people, even when they scatter the disease amongst those who are free from it.
I would advise the Department to take prompt action in this matter and to immediately give instructions whereby a hospital or small house could be established with a fully trained nurse there who would be able by degrees to persuade those who were sick and afflicted to come in and be under proper supervision and proper care.

Another feature in connection with the Indians is that they cannot be made to understand the necessity of dieting in certain cases. A child may be suffering from typhoid fever. If he should be at home and wanted crabs or anything else that was improper for him to have and if he asked them for it, they would give it to him even if he died the next minute. They cannot understand why they should diet and not have everything they ask for. If a good nurse were put in charge of them, she would gradually teach them, and possibly the lives of many of them might be spared and they might become useful. If the present conditions are allowed to go on, I do not think the Department will be troubled very long with many of the Indians as tuberculosis is gradually but surely killing them out by degrees. These same remarks apply to other districts as well as Sechelt, and I would advise that a small hospital be established at Mission as well.

It took us from early morning until nearly 10-30 o'clock to get
around to all those who were ill and suffering from tuberculosis and other diseases, but tuberculosis was the general disease they were suffering from. I left at 10-30 o'clock and arrived back in Vancouver about 3-30 Sunday afternoon, April 4th.

Should the Department require any further information on the subject or assistance in preparing plans for the hospital and obtaining the services of a trained nurse, I will be very pleased to help them in every way possible.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Scott,

I received your letter dated 12 March 1919 in which you held out little hope that the Government would erect a new boarding school this year in Sechelt. This is to be regretted, but I trust you will use all your influence that the building of the school is not deferred beyond another year. Would the Department be willing to give me a guarantee that it will build in 1920? The reason why I make this request is because I am prepared to build a new cottage for the resident priest once I am assured that the boarding school will shortly be an accomplished fact.

I spent a few days in Sechelt last week and I came away more than ever convinced of the immense superiority of the boarding school over the day-school. In day-schools the attendance of the children is very irregular. The parents are always on the move so that the vast majority of the children receive little or no education. Sometimes when the parents go away they entrust their children to the grandparents or other relatives who are however unable to manage the youngsters. Very often they roam about the village till late at night, even to midnight.

Comparing day-schools and boarding schools it is an acknowledged fact, I think, that the day-scholars never reach the high standard of the boarders. Many then again the day scholars leave school at an early age to work in the logging camps or on the fishing boats. Here they come in contact with the I.W.W. and quickly imbibe their pernicious theories, and so become a danger for the future of the Country.

Religion alone is able to influence their lives for good, as no one knows better than yourself. I consider that in Sechelt the Sisters have done excellent work. It is to be seen plainly in the school and in the young generation of young men and women who have passed through the school. Practically all the children...
Oblate Fathers
- - 59 Blackwood Street -
New Westminster, B.C.

who have attended the school have settled down and married. I do not know of a single case of separation amongst them, only one girl, an orphan, has given cause for complaint.

Sechelt as you will remember consists of five subdivisions, living chiefly in five different places for the greater part of the year; viz. Sechelt, Fender Harbour, Head of Jervis Inlet, Skokum Chuck, and Deserted Bay. Sechelt is the main village, but even here they only congregate on the big feasts for a short period and then scatter in various directions, leaving only a few old people behind them. A day-school in Sechelt would be absolutely useless.

At this moment fifty-five children are attending school. There are about a dozen more of age to go to school, but the sisters have no room.

I will not refer again to all the discomfort they have to endure in Sechelt particularly during the winter months, but I do hope that they will not be called upon to put up with it beyond the next twelve months.

I have the honour to remain,

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 26th ultimo, in which you refer to the boys of the Sechelt Indian Boarding School and their lack of progress with their studies.

Dear Reverend Sister:

In reply to your letter dated September 1923, informing me that only one boy came back to school on the 4th instant, the majority of pupils having gone to Agassiz, and some to Sardis, and others to Jervis Inlet and other camps, and requesting that I would send Constable Bartlett after them and have them brought back to school at once, I beg to say it is unfortunate that this matter was not taken up at the time the Indians were leaving Sechelt for the hop fields, as many of them were passing through and were supplied with tickets by Constable Bartlett and Chief of Police Harding and the pupils could have been retained here had we received information from you at that time.

I received a call yesterday from the Reverend Father Bellot, North Vancouver, who informed me that the Indians to all appearances deliberately took their children to the hop fields because the transportation would be paid by the Hop Company and that they were quite aware that if the children did not return to school their fares back to Sechelt would likely be paid through the Dominion Constable, being sent to round them up and return them to school at the Government's expense.

Father Bellot suggested that if a distribution of money were being made to the Sechelt Indians that it might be a good idea to return the children to school and charge the cost thereof against the respective shares of the Indians as a punitive measure. As no distribution is contemplated, however, this is not feasible.

I am going to the Hop fields on Friday, and I will look into the matter. I cannot say, however, that the Department will be agreeable to paying the expenses connected with the return of these pupils, as the hop picking will be all over in a few weeks and the Indians will return to the village. I will, however, do what seems best upon making further inquiries.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Reverend Sister:

In reply to your letter of the 22nd instant, relative to the children not returning to school after vacation, I desire to inform you that I have addressed letters to Chief Tom, Chief John, Chief Johnson, Chief George, and Indian Constable Roberts, instructing them to require from the Indian parents and guardians concerned the return of their children, who are up to your school without delay. I have told them that if they do not return at once that the court will be opened and all expenses connected therewith will be charged to the parents and guardians.

Kindly let me know if there is any movement in the direction of returning the children. If not, I will immediately proceed against the parents.

I may say that a letter was received this morning from Noel Paul, asking me to tell the school inspector that he wants to keep his son who "got a bad sickness" and cure him. He states that he lost two children from the same sickness, on account of the food that they had in the school. He also states the boy has been in school nine years and he did not learn much.

Of course, I do not take complaints of this kind seriously, as similar complaints have been made of other schools in the past. I would inform you, however, that there appears to be on the part of the Indians as a whole a strong desire to have the affairs at the school investigated. A petition was received last spring, signed by the villagers complaining about the school, particularly the food, secondly that the children were not learning anything and thirdly that they wanted a male principal. This petition was discussed by Reverend Father Welch, Mr. Inspector Cairns and myself and we decided to let matters rest for a while.

Within the past few weeks, however, another petition of a similar nature has been received, signed by practically all the villagers, asking why the former petition was not acted upon and calling upon us to have an investigation of these matters made. This is just where the matter stands at present. It is possible that the Indians in refusing to have their children return to school are keeping these petitions in mind and it looks to me as if there will have to be an inquiry in order to clear matters up. Mr. Cairns is out of the City at the present moment. It is possible that prosecution of the parents may bring about a solution of the difficulties complained of by the Indians.

Sir,

Dear Reverend Father:

With further reference to the petitions of the Sechelt Indians, as brought to your attention in the two letters addressed from the Indian Officer under date August 29th and 31st respectively, I beg to advise you that the attitude of the Sechelt Indians in regard to matters complained of therein has assumed a more serious aspect. It is reported by Reverend Sister Gabriel by letter of the 22nd of September that only five pupils out of an approximate enrolment of eighty who should have returned to school on the 4th instant, have reported at the school; most of the absentees being Sechelt Indians.

It has also been reported by a member of the Squamish Band that an attempt has been made by the Sechelt Indians to enlist the sympathy of the Squamish parents and their co-operation in a boycott of the two boarding schools.

Under the circumstances we deem it imperative that an investigation of the whole matter be made as soon as possible after the return of the Indians from the Hop Fields. While the four chiefs and constable have been urged to use their powers of persuasion with a view to the return of the pupils and the Indian parents and guardians have been threatened with Court proceedings to return their children, we would feel that it would be comparatively easy to deal with a few truants, but the whole band being practically unanimous present a serious problem, which would call for a more diplomatic way of dealing with the situation than by court proceedings.

We, therefore, respectfully request that you be good enough to consent to assist in the inauguration of some plan, whereby a thorough investigation and solution of the present difficulty could be assured. It is our desire to meet the parents only, who may have complaints to make and to ascertain, if possible, if there is any good ground for such, and we would appreciate it if you would accompany us on the occasion of our visit to Sechelt in order that we may have the benefit of your good counsel in these matters, also your co-operation as a representative of the Church interested in the school.

We remain, dear Reverend Father,

Most sincerely yours,

Rev. Father Welch, O.M.I.,
Vicar of Catholic Missions,
New Westminster, B.C.

If no word is received by Friday next, the 19th instant, Police Officers will be dispatched with warrants for the arrest of all pupils.

It is unfortunate that the investigation of this affair has been inadvertently delayed owing to Mr. Inspector Cairns having made arrangements to go to the Nass River, which trip was imperative owing to the early freezing over of the Nass River, making navigation expensive and difficult. Had it been possible for the Reverend Father Welch to have gone to Sechelt in response to my letter of August 29th, no doubt an earlier investigation might have been made on the return of the Indians from the hop fields.

Immediately upon leaving the hop field the Indians began to scatter all along the Coast and it will be with difficulty that they will be reached and the children brought back to school. I am expecting word from the Sisters at any moment and I am hoping that it will be to the effect that the pupils have returned.

I pointed out to Dr. Scott in an interview during his visit to Vancouver that the affairs of the school will be fully and carefully investigated with a view of correcting any condition which may be found inimical both to the interests of the pupils and the staff. I feel at present there is no justification for the attitude taken by the Sechelt Indians and I believe good results would follow a change of policy, whereby children from other villages should be encouraged to enter the school and a number of the older pupils now enrolled discharged and replaced by younger children.

If you will kindly consult my diary for the month of May, it will be noticed that on the 17th day of that month I reported that I had found it necessary to visit the school and severely censure a number of the pupils who had been giving trouble to the teachers.

STATEMENT OF CHIEF JOHN.

I'll say a few words about the school matter. You are inquiring about what matter this school is closed about. This school building is one of the best buildings as we look at it. The school children today are not the same today as they were. Children coming out of this school lately hardly know anything at all. The Band got together and said we may as well stop this and have a better plan." We decided in asking for a different principal and teachers that is why we stop the children from going to this school. 'Tis not because we do not like the Sisters, it is because of the poor education. It is all mixed up. They can hardly put things together. So it was agreed by the Band that they would want a man principal, a man teacher for the boys and the Sisters for the girls.

STATEMENT OF CHIEF JOHNSON.

I'll say a few words to you about this school matter. The School building looks good inside and outside. The teachers are the main trouble. The food too is pretty poor and the children get sick on it. It is a shame for the Government to pay a large sum of money and for children come out of school and know so little or education. When our children speak English half of them English is French. When we want our children to add or count they can't do it. We are tired of this poor business in the school and if the matter is settled it may be better later on and as Mr. Carlson says if the Sachelt children do not come to school, others will. I can say it will be different. We Sachelt people built the first school in this Reserve. We want to follow what the government wants us to go, but we cannot get it out of this school in the way of education. It is not because we do not like the school. It is because we want good food and good education for this school.

STATEMENT OF JOE WILSON, Indian.

I'll tell you a few words about this school matter. You are Inspector of Indian Schools. In regards to school matter, we have a kick about the food. When we start a school in Sachelt the Government pays $5.00 per month for each pupil. We could not kick then if the food was not of high standard. Lately we found out the Government was paying more money. We found out the food in the school was just the same as when it was $5.00 per month. The children are getting mush and tea without milk and without sugar. So our children have been getting sickness with eating such poor food as that. I have known a few kids who have got sick with the food and have died. Our kids have looked well whenever in school, but a few months after looked sick and were not well. About the Sisters they hate all the people of Sachelt, and hate the Priest (Priest present) as much as we. After we had meetings we decided to hold our children till we get better teachers and better food for the children. So this time we have brought our children to school and if the school matters are settled we are ready to put them into school. It has been agreed by the Band to have a man principal, a man teacher for the boys and Sisters to teach the girls.
STATEMENT OF CAPTAIN JOE (Indian)

I got a complaint about my little girl. One day Mother Superior slapped her on the nose with a book and it bled all day. I do not think a school teacher would go that far in punishing kids. I came up to school one day when I came to Schect, and just as I came in the door, the Sister chased me away like a dog. Before that they had chased my wife away the same way as that. I do not like to remember what she said at that time. I would not like to say what the Sister said in the presence of the Mothers and the Fathers and the children. The teachers hate the people here. If any of the women come to school they chase them away. If there is no change of teachers in this school there will be more trouble than there was before with the people of the village.

STATEMENT OF MRS. AGNES ALPHONSE (Indian)

My husband when he was alive came to school to get our boy to cut wood. As he came up behind the school he saw the boy crying and blood coming from his nose. My husband asked what was the matter but the boy would not say a word. The Sister would not let the boy sit and cut wood, so my husband went and got the boy to cut the wood. At last I got the boy down to the house. The boy would not tell me what was the matter. In the evening when going into church they boy began to cry and there was still a little blood coming from his nose. I took him home and put him to bed. I coaxed my boy and asked him what was wrong. He said to him: "Your both eyes are black and I do not know what is wrong with you." By and by he told me what the trouble was. It was at the school and it was after dinner time and it was his job to wash the dishes. A sister thought it was not in his place to wash dishes, so the sister instead of telling him, she came up behind him and gave him a slap on the back of the head with a closed hand. I never told anybody about this. My boy was laid on his bed, but I didn't want to say anything to anybody. Quite a few days after this his grandmother came to the house and saw the boy was sick and asked what was the matter. When she saw it she went to Father Plamondon. (Here Father Plamondon explained that he saw the boy with black eyes but that the boy had told him about this but could not remember the Grandmother having done so.)

STATEMENT OF MRS. NOEL PAUL (Indian)

I lay down before you what I know and what I have seen of the Sisters, and the truth. One day I came up to the school to get my boy to cut wood. My husband and eldest boy were sick. As I came up I seen my boy and the Sisters in charge let me come to see the Superior. I took my boy along with me. I saw the Mother Superior and I could see that she looked mad. She asked me what I wanted. I told her I wanted the boy to cut wood for me. Mother Superior then got mad with both of us. She told me that I had got my boy before, and he had missed the Church Service and for this reason she would not let him go. It could not be helped that time, we were in the woods when the Church bell rang and we could not be in time. It got me very sore. So I told Mother Superior I would not come to get my boy again. At last Sister found that I was mad. She asked me what I wanted to have my boy out of school for. Then we started to fight words with her. She was talking in English and in French, when she was talking French she was saying "O! la la, O! la la." I have an idea what she was saying. She asked me right there if I wanted to fight with her. I got ready and the Sister ran away. As I went towards the village another Sister was running after me. The Sister asked me to come back or she would wire to Mr. Perry, and he would send a Constable to come up.
STATEMENT OF SAM JULIAN (Indian)

It is a long time since I first heard of trouble with this school. I used to come up and see my children two or three times a year to see my children. I had to fight with the Sisters. Two or three times we had trouble. There are two parties in this Reserve. The Sisters are one party and the people in the village a party too. Sometimes when we have celebrations we come and try to have the Sisters enjoy it with us, but they would not come. This is where the trouble begins. The Reserve belongs to the Indians. The Sisters are working for the Government. The Government has given us a good school and no good has come out of this school the Government has done for us. There has been more trouble every year. I put my time in in Sechelt this Spring and every day there were school boys and girls running away from School. We spend most of our time running around looking for the kids. Two times I took my kids back to school. I couldn't help it when the kids ran away each time. I got a few kids here and it proves the Sisters cannot give them a good education. Women cannot give them sense enough to get anything education. When the kids come out of school they would not listen. They go out into the world and please themselves. Why do the teachers not teach the children to obey their parents, the law of God. That is one thing that makes the people of Sechelt sore and should be cut out right now.

QUESTION BY INSPECTOR CAIRNS:
Why do the children run away?

Answer: They were treated too rough by the teachers.

A.Voice: Over-punished.

STATEMENT OF MRS.ISAAC SHIELDS (INDIAN)

A few words in regard to the food of the children. My little girl was sick and I came up one day just in time for dinner. I had fried some fish to take up to my little girl for dinner. Just as I came up (it was in the old school building) the Sister was taking in the dinner for the sick girls. It was salt fish. It must have been old and it smelt rotten. When the Sister walked away I took it away and gave the girl the fish I had brought. The girl told me that if she didn't eat the Sister's fish she might be punished. So I took it away myself. There is no sugar in the tea and the tea very light just like water.

Inspector Cairns here addressed the Indians, at length.

"You cannot say you own this building which was built primarily for the education of Indians. You must have some regulation to ensure order and to prevent chaos. Sister Superior has responsibility. You must treat her with respect, as she represents authority and order. I am a tax-payer in the City for instance. The Mayor is the head of the City and represents the people. Things must be done in an orderly manner."

(It was impossible to take down Mr. Cairns entire speech, as I could not write shorthand...C.C.F.)

This concludes the charges against the school.
Rev. Sister Gabriel insisted by Inspector Cairns to make any observations that she may desire upon the statements of the Indians, stated as follows:

We always put some sugar in the tea, also milk when the cows produce it. There has been no sugar put in the porridge of the pupils since the war, but nobody has complained. The children each morning return their plates for a second helping. The doctor never said the children died of poor food. He, on the other hand, has been most careful not to allow a boy to be in school in a weak condition. The food has been improved of late and the dietary scale has been approved by the Department.

As to chasing the Indians like dogs, the contrary is the case. It is the Indians who have chased us. There must be discipline and the Indian cannot do as they like. We never had a child whose nose bled for a whole day. Morris has black eyes because he had been fighting with a big boy.

With reference to obedience the teachers encourage the children to obey their parents every day. We need the cooperation of parents. If parents do not teach their children to obey their teachers, the parents cannot expect the children to obey them.

We do send the children to participate in the rejoicings of their parents and people.

Concerning the fish—the Indians say the fish was no good, the Indian parents salted the fish themselves and we were obliged to throw away seven barrels, as it went bad.

The Indians say the Sisters make money out of the Indians, but it is different. Since January last we have purchased cord wood from the Indians amounting to $640.65 besides this we have paid engineers and gardiners expenses.

We discipline the children often in penance at their own choice. They usually choose the strap. They are disciplined reasonably and are not treated roughly. The Indians insult me when I refuse to allow them to take their children. How can they become educated if the parents are allowed to take their children away?

Following the statement of Sister Gabriel, Tom Julian, the Indian interpreter, who had interpreted all the proceedings desired to speak. The following is what he said.

There are four points. Education, food, treatment and hatred. These have been discussed at all the meetings held by the Indians.

At Deserted Bay the Chiefs get letters from Chief Inspector Ditchburn and the Indian Agent and they go to the Ex-pupils of the boarding school and ask them to explain the letters to the old people and they could not do so.
A letter received recently from Mr. Ditchburn through the Indian Agent regarding fisheries matters could not be interpreted.

There was better education under Mother Theresa. Some of the young people now write letters to Father Flanondon, which are so poor they cannot be read. As to the food, I put nine years in this school and know how on some occasions the food was poor and couldn't be eaten. I have seen kids go out after meals and throw up their food to prevent being sick.

As to discipline, in some cases the treatment goes too far. There are some bad ones, but others do not deserve it. There should be a different system. The boys should have someone who should rule them. Sister St. Juan is laughed at by the boys. She is too old. My mother is old. Sometimes I laugh at her. That is like the Sister. I can correct my boy when my wife can't. There is distance and lack of sympathy between the people and the Sisters and it is getting worse. I know this myself. We are ambitious for a good school.

The Reverend Father Flanondon, desiring to address the Assembly stated as follows:

Before God I am bound to be impartial, fair and just. This trouble is of long standing. I have been here a long time. Many times the late Indian Agent Byrne spoke to me about the complaints he had received from the Indians regarding the food, discipline and education at Scotch Boarding School. When Mr. Cairns came here Jan. 1921, he informed me there had been a meeting in Chief Julius' house at which complaints had been made to him re food. The petitions sent to Indian Agent Perry were never shown to me by the Indians. The Indians said "Father, we are tired and want an understanding, on the question referred to." I see there is friction between the Indians and the management of the school. I didn't until lately go into the dining-room. I knew what they had in the old building and was well satisfied, but when I saw the poor food given to the pupils by the present Sisters, I told Father Welch myself that I was sorry for the children who had that mush with no sugar and milk. The result of this condition was that on September 1st only one boy came back to school. A priest came from Westminster last fall and said he would like to see the food of the pupils and when he saw it he said to me "Father it is a shame for the Sisters to give those children heavy mush with no sugar or milk." He also said that potatoes, soup and bread so frequently used was of little use to these children. He told me it was my duty to come and see every meal and taste it. I mentioned this to Mother Gabriel and told her that the big boys need lots of food and that if we could not feed them properly it would be better to close the school for else ask the Government for more money as we are responsible before God. What reflects on the Sisters, reflects on the Church and Priest. We must not starve the children. The climate in this country demands good food and plenty of it.

As to education, Mother Gabriel invited me to the school when Inspector Cairns visited last January. I went to the classroom and considered the work was not up to standard. Father Welch admitted to me at the table
"They do not know much"

As to discipline the Sisters are scolding the children from morning to evening. Sometimes the Sisters could be heard shouting at the children from as far away as the wharf. I told the Sisters they should not kick, slap and shout at the children. I must speak the truth for I know that I will be judged. I said to Mother Superior "These children are slaves. They used to have a Christmas tree and more recreation" (The Sister here answered "I never have anything like that".)

I know the Sisters intentions are good, but they may have been brought up like that. They are watching the children too closely, allowing them no latitude, and visiting priests have remarked about this. They are watched in Church and faced everywhere. I know they have to be watched but not to this extent. I told Father Welch over and over again. Mother Theresa used to visit the sick, but lately the Sisters have not visited the sick Indians. I told Father Churchill this and we agreed that we must love the Indians if we desire to serve them. Last fall there was no stove in the Church. At that time there were not more than seven or eight Indians in the village. One day there was snow on the ground and these few people and I wanted to use the school chapel. Sister Gabriel became very angry and she said to me "Look, Father, I cannot stand it any longer. See what water they have made all over the floor." Her intentions no doubt were good, but there seems to be no understanding. There is room for improvement. The Indians are not wholly to blame. There should be co-operation and understanding and this should be possible. A sister here insisted that they (the Sisters) themselves had eaten much and long all through the year. Father Flanndon retorted that is perhaps what you were used to in France, but in this country more food is required.

The Indian Agent next addressed the meeting in an endeavour to council the Indians and all parties concerned with a view to better understanding, also promising that the statements etc., would be carefully analyzed and discussed with the school staff and hoped that there would be no recurrence of this trouble in the future.

The singing of the National Anthem concluded the proceedings.
Vancouver, B.C., Oct. 30, 1923.

Sir,— With further reference to the trouble at the Sechelt Indian Boarding School, as outlined in a file submitted to the Department under cover of letter dated Oct. 17th ultimo, we, your Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia and Indian Agent of the Vancouver Agency, hereby concurrently report for the information of the Department, as follows:

By correspondence (copies of which are herewith submitted) and interviews, it was arranged that the Rev. Father Welch, O.M.I., Vicar of Missions and ourselves would visit Sechelt on November 1st, for the purpose of holding an official investigation into conditions as complained of by the Indians.

Notice of the proposed meeting having been sent to the Indians scattered at remote camps along the Coast, through Dominion Constable Bartlett, it was imperative that we should not break faith with the Indians. Further, we had come to the conclusion that the seriousness of the situation had not been fully apprehended by the Church Authorities to whom it had been pointed out that delay would not improve the situation.

It is unfortunate, as will be noted by the correspondence that the Reverend Father Welch was not free to accompany us to Sechelt on November 1st. Previous to our investigation, a special effort had been made by Rev. Father Flemmond to have the Church represented at the investigation, by an official apart from the resident Missionary and Staff, which failed.

We proceeded to Sechelt on the first instant where we were met by Dominion Constable Bartlett who had visited the Camps and had urged the Indians to keep the appointment at Sechelt on November 1st. There were thirty-eight school children in the village with their parents and friends, they having all arrived that morning from Jervis Inlet.

It pleased the Indians that your Agent should first hold a meeting with the Hunaechin Band of the Sechelt Tribe, and in the meantime they would call the people together for a meeting in the Boarding School Assembly Hall, which room was placed at our disposal by the Reverend Principal.

After meeting the Hunaechin Indians, and disposing of their business, we repaired to the Boarding School classroom where all the adult Indians

The Secretary,
Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Ontario.
and several children were assembled. Present on the platform were the Principal and Institution Staff, The Reverend Father Plamondon, Resident Missionary and Chaplain, Mr. R.H.Calhoun, Inspector of Indian Schools, Indian Agent C.C.Ferry, and Dominion Constable Bartlett. Your School Inspector occupied the chair and Indian Agent, C.C.Ferry acted as Secretary and took the minutes, assisted by Dominion Constable Bartlett. Evidence as submitted herewith was taken and duly read and approved by the meeting. After testimony of the Indians having concluded, the Chairman invited the members of the staff to make any observations they may desire upon the statement of the Indians, whereupon the Reverend Principal Gabriel made his statement, which is submitted with the evidence. Following this the Reverend Father Plamondon, made a statement during which Reverend Sister St. Dennis interjected a few opposing remarks upon which she was heckled by the Indians to some extent. The Indians desiring to have Father Plamondon speak.

While we have noted that the testimony of the Reverend Father Plamondon is reflected in the evidence of the Indians and while we regretted very much to observe the embarrassment of the Reverend Sister, who listened to the evidence of Reverend Father Plamondon, in the presence of the Indians, where the Reverend Father deemed it meet that his sentiments should be delivered, we feel that the Reverend Father was sincere in his statement, for we have hitherto found him a pious and worthy Missionary, whose representations would not, we believe, be without reasonable grounds.

The evidence thus taken was of such a nature as to lead us to the belief that friction exists between the staff and the resident Missionary-Chaplain on the one hand and the staff and some of the Indians on the other hand, which circumstance would appear to call for the attention of the representatives of the church to look into the matter with a view to action being taken for the creation of an atmosphere of harmony and cooperation. We are convinced that the Indians of Sachelt were not justified in taking action as a Band, to force the recognition of their grievances which might easily have been remedied had the aggrieved parents presented them to the Principal of the School or to the local officials of the Department, individually. This, however, was not done.

The evidence of all the parties concerned having been completed, on the first instant, we decided to visit the school the following day to discuss with the Principal and staff, the several points at issue between the staff and the Indians. Every phase of the situation was thoroughly gone into with the result that it was decided to institute immediately with the assistance of the Department the following program:

1. The dietary scale to include for the time being an addition to the breakfast porridge, of the pupils, of Pacific canned milk and sugar, pending the slaughter of the old cows at present in use and the purchase of three good milch cows to take their place;

2. The slaughter of two old cows, a scrub bull and two ill-nourished calves for meat for the institution

3. This discontinuance of stock-raising at this school.
on account of insufficient accommodation and pasturage, etc.

4. To recommend that the Department provide three good milk cows for the school.

5. The school Inspector and Indian Agent to write a joint letter to the Principal setting forth for the regulation of the Indians visiting the school the times and conditions under which the pupils may be visited by their parents.

6. Suggestions left with the Sisters to make provision each day for proper and sufficient exercise.

7. In disciplining the pupils the Sisters were advised to use great care and discretion. In this connection we found no serious grounds for complaint.

8. With reference to the clothing of pupils, it was decided that while it was not desired that parents should be discouraged from making gifts of clothing, shoes, etc., to their pupil-children, provision for the comfort of the pupils in this regard to be made by the staff, in accordance with existing regulations.

9. It was decided that the annual summer vacation should commence on August 1st each year and continue until the opening of the public schools for the Province.

10. That a male teacher be appointed for the boys' classroom.

The foregoing adjustments, it is thought, will remedy in the main any grievances the Indians may have against the conduct of the institution.

In addition to the suggested arrangements referred to, the question has arisen on the part of the Church Authorities regarding the payment of the salary of the resident Engineer, who looks after the boilers and electric lights. The Reverend Father Welch, Vicar of Missions, has suggested that provision be made by the Department for the payment of this salary, which amounts to $900.00 per year. He has further suggested that the per capita grant for this Institution be increased by the Department. These suggestions open up to us a rather difficult problem, for, having no data which would enable us to make comparisons, between the various educational institutions, as to their mode and cost of operation, it is difficult for us to determine whether or not the Department should be asked to follow the suggestions made by the Reverend Father Welch. We would gladly do so, however, if it is found, upon investigation, in the Department where the records would likely be available that the grant at present being paid towards the operation of this Institution falls appreciably short of those made to other institutions.

In conclusion, we desire to say that when meeting the Indians we made very clear to them the fact that the Department is exceedingly anxious that this school should be conducted along efficient lines; that there should be harmony and co-operation between the Indians and the officers of the School. We advised them also that should any occasion for complaint arise in the future, representation in this regard should be justly and properly made, first to the Principal by the aggrieved parent or guardian individually. We made it clear that we felt they were not justified as a band in taking the drastic action they did; also that it was not likely that the Department would, in the future, allow an institution which costs...
which costs so much to build, furnish and equip to be detrimentally impeded in its operation through the caprice and whims which may seize the Sechelt Band, particularly as there are in the Province of British Columbia many Roman Catholic children, whose parents would gladly have them enter this institution as pupils. On the other hand we advised them that the complaints made by them on this occasion would be thoughtfully and carefully considered and the Reverend Sisters gave their assurance that any causes of legitimate complaint would be effectively remedied, which they did, resulting in the return of all the pupils who were that day in the village, numbering in all thirty-one, immediately. The Indians further promised that the remaining pupils, bringing the enrolment up to seventy-four would be returned by the parents, who were residing at the Camps along Jervis Inlet.

We are daily expecting to receive word from the Reverend Principal that the balance of the pupils have returned, the Indians appearing to be quite satisfied with the investigation made.

We beg to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

R.H.Cairns,
Inspector of Indian Schools
for British Columbia........

The Honorable Duncan Scott

Honorable Sir,

Doubtless you are aware that so far not one Beekelt child is in the school and the Indians refuse absolutely to send them back unless a thorough investigation is instantly made into the management.

Their grievances are of long standing; they have reported them over and again to the late Mr. Peter Byrne, but the good old gentleman, who died not like the idea of annoying any, specially the sisters, always managed to send the poor Indians home with the promise that he would take the matter into consideration.

On the 5th of January 1921, taking the occasion of the official visit of Mr. Burns, Inspector of the Indian schools, they held a meeting in his presence in chief Julius' house and exposed to him their complaints against the school.
In the summer of the same year they made two petitions, one to Mr. Evans and the other to another principal of St. Paul's school North Vancouver as she is the head superior in charge of the sisters, requesting that a change be made into the staff of the school.

Last winter they wrote to their new agent, Mr. B.C., Percy, asking again for a change or acceleration in the way of feeding, educating and correcting these children. During the last vacations I am told that they notified the authorities that unless they gave their instant attention to their reiterated grievances they would not send their children back to school.

I spoke myself many times to my own superior, Rev. Walter J. Welch, who is supposed to look after the interests of the Indians of the ever-increasing bad feelings which the Indians have towards the management of the school. But the good holy priest, much in the same low disposition as was the late Peter Byrne, thinks almost impossible for the "good sisters" to be unfair, were unintentionally, to the Indian children. As missionary priest of Sechelt and chaplain of the school, looking after the spiritual...
spiritual interest of both the Sisters and the Indians; my position is quite a crucial one. I see and hear everything; we must be fair, impartial and just. The Indians are not to blame altogether. There is something defective, and very defective in the management of the Sechelt boarding school regarding the food, the education of the boys and discipline. The food is what it should be and what the Indian Department wants it to be in the quantity and quality. For instance, for breakfast the whole year round, one plate of thick mush without milk or sugar, but salt with one single piece of dried bread, no butter or anything else on it, and a cup of tea. The same is said of the supper or any other meals, never more than a poor plate of soup with one piece of dried bread, no matter how big or hungry may be the child then or sick. The teacher of the big boys is an old French Sister (they are French) over 65 years of age who can hardly speak English and have been since the opening of the Sechelt school in 1904. The discipline is by far too rigid & do not think that the penitentiary guards of Westminster handle their convicts more roughly than some sisters do the Indian boys here. The Indians are very well satisfied with
with Sister Gavina, teacher of the girls and speak highly of her, only they would like to have the girls learning cooking before leaving the school.

I must apologize for my liberty of writing you and such a long one for the first time in my life to the Indian Department, though I have been for over 25 years in charge of Indians in B.C. I hope you will understand that I think it important to do justice done to everyone, no matter his race, his color or creed.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your respectful and humble servant

[Signature]

P. V. Lamondon

Dear Mr. Scott:

In reply to your letter of December 7th, in which you ask me to make recommendations relative to management and finance at Sechelt, I am pleased to say that I have gone fully into these questions, and am satisfied that a promising solution has been reached.

The week before Christmas Messrs. Ditchburn, Cairns, Perry and myself spent a whole afternoon in the Indian Agent's Office discussing the Sechelt situation. The resolutions passed at this meeting will doubtless be submitted to you by Mr. Perry. It was left to me to interview Mother Gabriel and Mother Amy, and also the Indians to try and arrive at a settlement with them. This I did without delay.

As regards the Indians the main difficulties were the diet and the management. They insisted particularly on having a male principal. On two different occasions I went thoroughly into this matter with Rev. Mothers Amy and Gabriel and they finally completely agreed with me that it would be in the best interests of the school for the Oblates to take over the management and place the school on the same footing as Kamloops, if they were acceptable to you. But let me assure you that I was not anxious to assume this responsibility. In consenting to it my sole purpose was to put an end to the friction which has arisen between the present staff and the Indians, and at the same time to meet the wishes of the Department, and yourself in particular.

With this object in view I have carefully looked through this Province for a competent principal and manager, and now respectfully request you to approve of the appointment of Rev. Anthony Swenceski, O.M.I. He is of Polish descent, 40 years of age, but came to British Columbia when a mere child, so that practically he has lived all his life in this province. I may say that he is quite a mechanic and a carpenter and in these capacities will devote himself to the technical training of the boys. What Father McGuire is doing in Kamloops, as far as conditions will permit I believe Father Anthony will accomplish in Sechelt.

You ask for a qualified teacher for the boys. Unhesitatingly I recommend for the bigger boys and girls Mother Gabriel. To assist the Principal in maintaining discipline I purpose giving him Brother Joseph who has had considerable experience with the boys in the Cariboo School.

The Indians have promised to send all their children back to school after the Christmas holidays, and to wait
patiently pending the arrival of a male principal.

In conclusion let me say that I take it for granted that the school will be placed in Class "A", and that you will approve of the suggestions submitted by Messrs. Ditchburn, Cairns and Perry.

Thanking you for your Season's Greetings which I most sincerely reciprocate, I am,

Very respectfully,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 7th instant, No.4167-18-1, with reference to the desired suggestions as to better management and financing at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

In reply thereto I beg to inform you that the whole situation has been carefully discussed with the Reverend Father Welch, Mr. School Inspector Cairns, and the Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies, Mr. W.M. Ditchburn, both individually and in conference. Every phase of the present situation has been carefully considered with the result that we have reached a decision as to our recommendations in this connection to be made for your consideration. These are as follows:

1. That the Institution be placed in Class A, with the status of an Industrial Boarding School, with the maximum grant.

2. The school to be placed under the Principalship of a male principal to be appointed by the Oblate representatives of the Roman Catholic Church, the school to be no longer under the Principalship supervision of Sisters. This has been agreed to by the Sisters themselves. Under this arrangement the Reverend Principal will be assisted in the training of the pupils by the resident priest, who himself has considerable experience along the lines of manual and carpentry work. It is proposed to place Rev. Father Anthony, who is now at Fernie, in charge of the school, this Father being, it is believed, the desired qualifications to fit him for the position. With this program the proposal to have a male teacher in the classroom will be eliminated and the institutional and classroom work will be done by Reverend Sisters, under the supervision of the principal, with the understanding that every effort be made to raise the classroom work to a higher standard of efficiency.

3. That a piece of land in area approximately two and a half acres be acquired by lease (subject to survey) from Dan Faull, the recognized owner, at Swycaise Reserve No. 1, in George Bay, at a rental of $25.00 per acre per year for at least three years, to which proposal Dan Faull has agreed. The entire three years rental to be paid in advance as soon as

Duncan C. Scott, Esquire,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
the area of the land has been ascertained. This land will be used for necessary garden purposes.

4. That the sum of $1000.00 be immediately made available to the Indian Agent for the purpose of blasting stumps and clearing an additional acre for garden purposes at the school grounds, in order that the same may be placed under cultivation for the supply of vegetables etc., for the school. This recommendation, as well as No.3 is made with the assumption that the Department will proceed with the proposed Water Supply scheme which, it is understood, has been the subject of correspondence between Mr. Chief Inspector Ditchburn and the Department. As soon as additional land has been cleared in the immediate vicinity of the school and a suitable irrigation arrangement has been installed, the land referred to in recommendation No.3 would be vacated and the immediate school grounds further cultivated.

5. That a small boat with an engine, to cost approximately $600.00 be furnished this school, the same to be used under supervision of Rev. Father Flamondon for the purpose of carrying fish, primarily, for the school supply, and in order that the boys of the school may be taught by the Reverend Father how to operate and care for marine engines, which knowledge will be useful to them after they leave the school, as most of the Indians make use of motor boats in connection with their fishing.

Up to the present time the girl pupils of the school have received no training along the lines of baking although the institution is equipped with valuable bakery apparatus which has never been used. Under the proposed industrial status of this school, attention will be given to the training of the girls along this line as well as laundry and other household arts.

It is believed that the carrying into effect of the foregoing recommendations will result in the entire elimination of the present difficulties surrounding this school as well as the attainment of higher standards of efficiency as desired by all concerned. We would recommend that these proposals be given the earliest possible consideration and, if approved by the Department, their immediate application would ensure the certain response of the Indians, which seems to so vitally affect the future usefulness of this institution.

We have the honour to remain,

Sir,
Your obedient servants,

H.H. Cairns,

Memorandum:

I have carefully examined the suggestions of Mr. Inspector Cairns, Mr. Indian Agent Perry and Rev. Father Welch, for the future of the Sechelt Indian Residential School, and I wish to recommend the following action:

1. That the school be placed under the control of the Oblate Fathers and have as its principal a resident Priest. The Rev. Father Svecoski, O.M.I., is available for this duty and would be given by the Order a lay Brother to assist in boys' activity.

2. That the Department make a grant of $1,000 for the purpose of clearing land at the school for garden purposes and that in the meantime a few acres on Porpoise Bay (Reserve No. 3) be rented.

3. That a small boat, to cost approximately $600, be given the school, to be used for the purpose of securing fish, which are not found in the immediate vicinity, and for the training of the boys in the care and handling of such craft.

4. That the new principal be urged to use all the equipment in the building, that is designed for the purpose of instructing the girls in the domestic activities and that organized instruction be given the boys in gardening, the care of stock, fishing and the handling of a boat.

5. That the per capita grant be increased to that of the Industrial School class.

I am hopeful that this program, if carried out, will permit the Sechelt Indian Residential School to give adequate instruction and care to the pupils and to finance successfully on the per capita earnings. The present management of the school has agreed to the appointment of a principal from the Oblate Order.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

The Sechelt Indian Residential School, in British Columbia, has lost during the past year or two some of its popularity with the Indian communities. Investigations have revealed the fact that a change in the management is desirable. The Sisters who have been in charge and the Provincial of the Oblate Order are agreed that the appointment of a resident priest as principal is desirable. Changes are being made in the instruction offered; and the institution is being placed in the Industrial School class and will receive a larger per capita grant. The preparation of a larger garden is imperative and I shall be pleased to have your authority to allow a grant of $1,000 for clearing purposes. The work will be performed under the supervision of the Indian agent. A small boat with an engine is required for the supplying of fish, which are not to be found in the waters immediately in front of the school; it will be useful in the training of the older boys in the handling of marine boats and engines. It is estimated that $600 will secure suitable equipment.

I shall be pleased to have your authority to authorize this expense. Funds are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Duncan C. Scott

I have the honour to forward the returns of the Sechelt Indian Boarding School, for the quarter ended Dec. 31st last. Father Welch.

I would inform you that while about forty pupils have so far returned to school, following the trouble, there are still Indians who refuse to return their children until their demands which were embodied in subsequent recommendations to the Department have been met. The Indians, at a very strenuous and tense meeting, further demand the removal of Sister Gabriel and Sister St. Dennis, and have threatened to empty the school completely unless this demand is met.

It is our intention to again go into this matter very fully with Rev. Father Welch after which Mr. Cairns and I will make a joint report. It is anticipated from an interview, of Mr. Cairns and myself, with Rev. Sister Gabriel that the latter will leave the institution in July next, and it is expected that new appointments of teachers to this school will be the outcome of our interview with Rev. Father Welch as referred to.

While we feel that the Indians' demands as such ought not to be encouraged for obvious reasons, the fact remains that the trouble at this school will not be over until further arrangements of a mutual character are made, having in view the better conduct and control over this institution.

Every effort.
