Dear Sir:

On May 27th, 1917, all the buildings of the Sechelt Indian Boarding School were burnt down. I had insured the main building for $3,000.00, and the furniture for $3,000.00 also. I paid the insurance for many years. After the fire had occurred, the Insurance Co. gave me $6,000.00.

As, for a moment, the reopening of the School was uncertain, the Indian Department asked me to send to Ottawa the amount of the insurance on the building, that is $3,000.00 to be put to the credit of the Sechelt Band.

The $3,000.00 of the furniture were left to us, being our own property, since we had furnished the house with everything; all we saved from the fire was above.

Soon afterwards, however, it was decided that the School would continue and that temporary buildings would be erected for the boys and the girls, as well as a well-built cottage for the Staff and the sick children. The Government, left for that purpose, the sum of $3,000.00; amount of the insurance on the building and granted $300.00 as a help.
We need also for the temporary buildings, the cottage and furniture, our $3000.00, together with the donations of relatives and friends, as shown by the enclosed amount.

We had when the fire occurred six good cows, about sixty hens and seventy chickens, which, of course, were left for the use of the School.

As we have no longer the direction of the Sechelt School, we earnestly beg the Government to settle this matter and to refund to us the value of our belongings on the School.

We have run this School for twenty years, working with an untiring devotedness for the welfare of the children and their parents. When we started in June 1864, the main building alone was standing, there was nothing in it, and no land cleared around. With the boys' help we did ourselves the clearing and planting of the garden and orchards. From 1864 to 1872, the Grant being only $5.00 per capita, we could not take any salary, we were even helped by our Community in France.

After 1872, when the Grant was increased, we took a very small salary, as can be seen in the accounts of the Sechelt School, just enough to buy our clothes and meet the necessary expenses.

Late Dr. Green, Inspector, and Mr. P. Byrne, Agent, knew all our hard beginnings; Mr. Hutchburn and Mr. Cairns have seen us for many years and know how hard we have worked.

We are confident that you will kindly take all these things into consideration and recommend our petition to the Government.

As I am going back to France by the middle of August, I would ask you to be kind enough as to send payment to Mother Amy, Superior Provincial and Principal of the Squamish Indian Residential School, North Vancouver, B.C.

With anticipated thanks, I remain, dear Sir,

Very respectfully yours,
Sister Therese, Superior General
Ex-Principal of the Sechelt Indian Board School

With reference to your letter of Sept. 29th last, No.167-18-1, in connection with the suggested purchase by the Department of the building adjacent to the Sechelt Indian Residential School, as reported upon by The Very Reverend Sister Therese, Superior General of our Order and the Sisters of the Child Jesus, and requesting a report from me as to the building and its necessity as an adjunct to the school, I beg to say that my visit to Sechelt has been somewhat delayed owing to the fact that the Indians visit Sechelt only at certain times of the year, during the festivals of the Roman Catholic Church and as the Indians were all assembled at Christmas and all the business of this nature was undertaken at that time, I thought it would be satisfactory to investigate the matter of this building during my visit at Christmas time.

With regard to this matter, I now beg to report that I have made a very careful examination of the building and find the same to be in most excellent condition and the description given in the correspondence already in the Department relating to its conveniences and construction are in all points correct. The building is almost as good as new as it has been kept since the time of construction in excellent condition.

I consider this building to be a necessary adjunct to the School as its rooms and general facilities adequately and not with difficulty accommodate the male members of the staff who are working in connection with the school, and for whom there is no convenient accommodation in the school building proper. In addition to the reverend principal there are four men occupying the rooms of this building and I am heartily in accord with its acquisition by the Department in connection with the institution.

Sir:

May I respectfully enquire whether, as Principal of Sechelt Residential School, I have authority to compel attendance at school of our pupils, till they have arrived at the age of eighteen years? I find that in the past the parents have withdrawn their children as soon as they reached the age of sixteen years. Whatever may have been the conditions that demanded or sanctioned this custom, I am of the belief that it is objectionable, and for the following reasons, viz., that it is not to the best interests of the children themselves and that the interests of the school as an institution require that they remain longer in residence.

In the first place, at the age of sixteen they are physically, mentally and morally unfit to face life as maintains among their people. Experience has taught us that, especially among the boys, they have been, with few exceptions, idlers, for all of two years, after having left school.

Along this rock coast of British Columbia, they can find no other occupation, than what is offered in the fishing and logging camps. Because of their youth, their inexperience and their all-too-often undermined constitutions, they are not wanted in these industries. At best they can obtain only temporary employment in the canneries, at certain seasons.
So far, none of our children have made progress further than the sixth book, which hardly corresponds to fifth grade work. From the age of sixteen on is, therefore, more vital for such progress in school work. From the moral point of view, they have barely begun to grasp the significance of Christian principles, when they are snatched from our influence. It is a noted fact that the Indians have little or no control over the children in the home, after a certain age. The school discipline, as you know, makes for a better and more orderly citizenry, and thus the years under restraint are invaluable from the point of view of law and order later on.

The girls of our school are trained in needle work, domestic science and the like, while the boys do gardening, shoe repairing and cleaning of the land, of dead-wood and timber. On account of the restricted (eighty) number of our pupils, comparatively few are of age to participate in the heavier work. For instance, this year we have five boys who will have attained the age of sixteen by the first of August current; not one of them, is fit to leave, and take his place in the world, and in sheer justice to themselves, should remain longer at school.

In view of the foregoing, I would beg of you to issue to me the necessary authority to retain these five boys on the roll of the school.

Very Respectfully,

Reverend Sir,

I am directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant in connection with the age at which children should be discharged from the Sechelt Residential School.

You will note from an examination of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act that, legally, the Department can only enforce the attendance of Indian children at school from age seven until they reach the age of sixteen. However, the Department agrees with you that the majority of residential school pupils will considerably benefit by remaining in such schools until they reach the age of eighteen years and, in some cases, it might be advisable to have them remain even longer. Indian Agents, Principals and others interested in Indian education are expected to make every possible endeavour to persuade parents to leave their children in residential schools for a longer period than that prescribed by the Indian Act. The cases of any parents who insist on the discharge of their children at the age of sixteen should be referred to the Department through the office of your local Indian Agent.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sechelt School ------- Reverend Father McCaffrey's reply was not as satisfactory as I would have wished, as he was of the opinion that it would be a mistake to give Coast Indians any technical education as it might induce them to migrate to the more populous centres where they would have to compete with white labour. He is of the opinion, however, that a properly equipped plant for the repair and making of shoes for the pupils would serve a useful purpose. Father McCaffrey, however, is a new man in the Indian work and what I have seen of him leads me to conclude that he is more studious than practical. In view of the attitude of this School, I am of the opinion that no manual training equipment should be purchased as the phase of technical education at present being dealt with has reference to manual training only. Possibly next year the Principal may become possessed with a broader vision.

With reference to Department letters under number 167-18-4 dated March 27th and April 10th 1931 I beg to report that I gave special attention to this case, and also to the general cleanliness of the children at the school.

It is quite true that there is not sufficient bathing facilities at the Sechelt Residential School. As above reported this matter is now in the hands of Mr Indian Agent Ball.

I am sorry to have to report that as far as I can gather from the correspondence on the above subject, the Department was not made acquainted with the full facts in this case.

The Rev. the Principal of Sechelt Indian Residential School has made a very full statement to me. He states, in part, that the three boys mentioned had formed a "Gang" that they had made a practice of stealing in the Indian Village of Sechelt. There appear to have been a number of cases of theft. The Provincial police caught these boys, who are reported to have confessed to a number of thefts. The Provincial police took the case to a stipendary magistrate, who convicted and sentenced the boys; The Principal does not appear to have much to do with this part of the case.

The Principal states emphatically that previous to the departure of the boys for Vancouver, they were given baths and clean underclothes. He states that in addition the boys were provided with new shoes and new suits of clothes. He also states that the sores to which reference is made in the letter from the Superintendent of the Provincial Industrial School, dated February 24th 1931, were of in one case a syphilitic nature, and in the other case of a tuberculous nature. These boys had been treated daily by the Sisters at the school for these sores.

I regret to have to say that I do not consider that the letter from Mr Indian Agent Ball to the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia in any way covers the facts of the case, as stated by the Rev. the Principal.

The Principal told me that he had been assured in an interview with The Superintendent of Indian Education at Ottawa that he would have the support of the Department in dealing with this very difficult school. He feels that he has not had such support. I asked him why he did not ask for a full enquiry, if he thought himself badly treated. He replied that he knew that the Inspector of Schools would be inspecting his school shortly, and that the Inspector would be able to see the true facts of the case.

I consider that the Rev. E. Maillard is doing everything in his power to improve the standing of the Sechelt Residential School.

I do think that as reported above, the children of this school should have a very thorough medical examination in the near future. This will bring to light, no doubt, a number of other cases of a syphilitic and tuberculous nature.

The Indian School

By W. H. Dunlop, P.R.C.S.

Father Mailiard (who gave his name to Mailiardville) met me with a welcoming smile at Galiano Island where I called on him in the neat little house on the edge of sunny Sechelt. Below us the broad expanse of the Bight on which the summer sun played with shifting green waves to the right the Trall Islands, steep in salmon spawn; and the distant approach to Half Moon. The little verandah and the glad eye of the good father invited me to go in.

I had often wished to inspect the interior of the Indian Boarding School—a familiar landmark on that pleasant coastland. The father gladly opened to guests as soon as my visit was understood. I saw an average scale and not a prepared show. I don't quite know what I expected, for the entrance ground did not promise much but I was pleasantly surprised. On every hand there was the evidence of thoroughness. It was early forenoon. The bright dry dormitories were already in spick and span—each bed made up in snowy white, each pillow covered by a clean pillow sham to give a touch of grace; the clothes in the lockers hung or laid with regard for care and cleanliness; the girls told me that the boarders are taught to make up the beds promptly; and as he lifted one or two of the sheets I saw that the work was not a mere routine but really done. The kitchens were the same neat and cleanliness. The little chapel—if that is the proper name—where mass is said daily made me think anew of the revered controversy as to religious exercises in city schools.

As we entered the various class rooms the lesson was halted and the scholars stood in respectful silence not too common among little children; and here and there I spoke a well-merited word of praise and encouragement on the excellent work shown by Indian schools in the remote wilderness.

The discipline, though strict, is, I am sure, mild and easy, aided by temperamental docility and the active respect for the gentleness of the teaching sisters and what I saw at least in that casual visit made me think of the ancient word, "Love casteth out fear."

These boarding scholars, under the control of the school for a period of years, stand many of them have reached a standard that would do honor to city high schools. I was told that during the school year they take the trouble of leaving home for holidays! One reason suggested itself. When at length they must automatically go back to home life, faced with the fact that many of the ordinary channels of community usefulness are blocked by a racial bar, will the education they have had in curriculum and ordered habits persist when it slips to them that the morals and hygiene of the desert are rude, or spoiled fresh contacts, will these young people simply follow the inevitable law of reversion to type? It is a question of some pathos—in a sense, perhaps, of tragedy.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to say that I have just received a letter from the Reverend Ed. Maillard, O.M.I., who is leaving France for Canada on the 8th. instant. You may remember he was Principal at the Sechelt Residential School when you visited there. He left on a holiday about September last and tells me he has been advised by his headquarters at Rome that he will not return to Sechelt School.

I know the Indians complained to the Church authorities that he was too strict with them in the village, and he had some trouble with the Reverend Father Plamondon, an old priest who visits the Indians in the village. Also, Slidell, Sechelt and other Reserves. Maillard accuses him of undermining his authority and making trouble for him among the Indians, which is common talk in the district and probably true. However, that is a Church matter and outside our province to deal with, but the school is owned and operated on the grant from the Department and in this we should at least be consulted.

When Father Maillard took over his duties the school was in bad shape, discipline was lax and the Indians in the village, as the result of some trouble, had even put handcuffs on the brother who was supposed to be managing the school. Crime was common and practically every girl after leaving school came to Vancouver and lived on the streets.

Father Maillard was strict, but just, and he had but one idea, the welfare of his pupils. Whereas at one time pneumonia, bronchitis, etc., were expected every winter and usually deaths occurred every year, Father Maillard went through some winters without even a serious cold among the pupils. This was due to the care and feeding of the children, to which he gave his earnest attention. The school was a model of cleanliness, and the pupils were particularly well-fed and clothed.

It is true he was harsh in his language towards the village people, but they certainly improved in conduct. He is quite excitable and uses extravagant language when roused, but I believe he would do anything to help any Indian, either in the school or in the village, but would do it in his own way.

As Father Maillard feels very hurt on account of his dismissal, I thought it only fair to report that if it can be re-considered, the School would gain by it, and I should certainly be pleased to see him back again.
He may be considered a difficult man to get along with, but his heart was in his work, and he was a real success at the School.

He will probably call upon you on his arrival in Ottawa, and I thought it only fair to let you know what has happened.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[F. J. G. Ball]
Indian Agent

He added that he had heard that Andrew Fahlman (the Principal's nephew) also drilled the boys too much and that the boys were made to run around the grounds in circles.

Mr. Fahlman had previously stated that on one occasion, in an effort to compel the boys to tell who had stolen or hidden a large ring of school keys which had been removed and could not be found, had drilled the boys hard for longer periods than usual by making them hop on one leg. The excessive duration of these drills, however, was not supported by any definite evidence by those making complaint. Mr. Fahlman stated that the boys had undertaken greater fatigue in their voluntary play than he had witnessed at these drills, but that as this particular drill was done under pressure as punishment some of the boys had complained. The keys had not been recovered. Rev. Principal Fahlman stated that he had not been aware of any excessive punishment and that he would do his best to see that the boys were treated properly, since Abe Jefferies had brought it to his attention apart from the petition of the chiefs. Abe Jefferies is a good type of Indian and he agreed that a reasonable amount of discipline was necessary at any school and that he had told his son so. Jefferies said he did not know what was in the petition in which his name had been mentioned. Chief John, a signatory to the petition, who is an old and somewhat illiterate Indian stated that he knew what was in the petition when he signed it but it was only hearsay and he had signed it at the request of Chief Louie Johnny.

Chief Tom, a second signatory to the petition, is an aged, decrepit and illiterate Indian who would sign his death warrant if asked to do so. Neither Chief Tom nor the third signatory—Chief Louie Johnny—was in the reserve and therefore could not be called to explain their views to the investigators. Abe Jefferies and Chief John, however, having heard the explanation of the reasons for the punishment referred to, left the meeting without rancour and appeared to be satisfied that the matter had been looked into.

Mrs. Band's letter

This was dealt with at a meeting held at the School with the Mother Superior and four Sisters. Reverend Father Scannell presided also at this meeting. The letter was read aloud and the Mother Superior and the Sisters were asked if they had anything to say in regard to Mrs. Band's complaints. The complaints were categorically denied by all the Sisters.

Mrs. Band is more white than Indian, but is married to a Squamish Indian. They separated a few years ago and I found the husband and children on the North Vancouver reserve without food and the children neglected. This family is now reunited and the incident is mentioned only to suggest that any alleged lack of "home atmosphere" or quality of food that Mrs. Band may attach to the School could not be compared in favor to Mr. and Mrs. Band with the conditions which I have mentioned as relating to their neglect of their own children at a time when the children were younger and more dependent than they are at present. Mr. Ball did not produce any further evidence to support of Mrs. Band's charges and consequently the matter could not be further proceeded with.

As to music, the Mother Superior explained that the Sister who had taught music had been sick but that she would resume this work in the near future. In any event music is not a compulsory part of the Department's curricula for the schools, although it has been taught in the schools as a matter of course, and possibly Mrs. Band may have been paying for these services.

Dr. Conneld's letter re Medical Services and Hospitalization

The letter was read at the first meeting and was discussed. The Reverend Principal stated that there had not been, to his knowledge, any neglect of children as to Medical attendance or hospitalization, that Dr. Inglis, the Department's medical officer, had been diligent in all such matters and had consulted with the Principal in all cases. The case of a girl who had syphilitic sores on her leg was recovering as a result of Dr. Inglis' care and advice, and there appeared to be no reasonable grounds for the complaints of Dr. A. Lane Conneld. Principal Fahlman added that he had given due attention to the health of the children on all occasions and, should hospitalization be considered necessary by the Department's physician he would always be prepared to abide by the Doctor's decisions concerning admission to...
admissions to hospital, the latter being governed by Departmental regulations and usages. Perhaps it might be reasonable to suggest that since Dr. Connell comes into contact in the holiday and other vacation periods with children from the school and, in fishing time, with Indians of the village of Sechelt, these having during the balance of the year been under the medical care and treatment of the Department's part-time physician Dr. Inglis, it would have been possible for Dr. Connell to confer with Dr. Inglis as to the medical care or hospitalization of Indians who are Dr. Inglis' charges. This would have avoided the circulation of rumours concerning alleged neglect of medical services to the Indians. The hospital at Pender Harbour is under Anglican management while the Sechelt Mission and School are Roman Catholic.

Manual Training Instruction

Agent Ball stated that while it would seem that the question of the appointment of Mr. Morley as Manual Training Instructor to succeed Mr. Tebb whose services had been discontinued, was no longer a matter of issue, nevertheless he questioned Mr. Morley's qualifications and fitness for the position. The Principal replied that the application of Mr. Morley set forth his qualifications with which he was satisfied, and that Mr. Morley had shown in practice that he was familiar with the use of tools, technique of Manual Training and had designed and erected five or six cottages. Neither Mr. Bell nor the Principal produced written matter concerned in the application. The question, however, was believed by the Principal to have been settled at the Department as he received a cheque from Ottawa for the December Quarter in Mr. Morley's name although the work had been done by Mr. Tebb—Mr. Morley started work in January, 1936. The Principal advised that Mr. Morley had been taken ill after his appointment and would soon leave the hospital. He thought he should be permitted to decide as to the matter of Mr. Morley's future services, as he considered Mr. Morley to be the better of the two men quite apart from other considerations, Mr. Ball thinking, however, that any Manual Training instructor who may be engaged at Sechelt Residential School, should know something of boat construction and he doubted if Mr. Morley could succeed in this work. The matter was left for further discussion by Reverend Father Scannell with the Department, it being understood that the Principal is allowed reasonable latitude by the Department as to the choice of his staff, also that the Principal would see that the Manual Training would increase in efficiency.

As to alleged frequent absences of the Principal, the latter explained that in the interests of the Mission of the Church he has been asked to officiate in cases of emergency and has also availed himself of occasions of retreat but not without leaving a responsible person in charge in his absence. Reverend Father Plamondon, who is an experienced and most reliable missionary in charge at Sechelt and who is very close to the hearts and minds of the local Indians, upon being invited to express his opinion of the matters of complaint, (as he did on a previous occasion when a similar inquiry was made by the late Schools Inspector Cairns and myself during the administration of the

Reverend Sisters ....
Reverend Sisters of the Child Jesus, as on record), informed us that he had received no complaints from the Sechelt Indians apart from the rumours in circulation as concerning the alleged harshness of a disciplinarian, the latter, however, not being Mr. Andrew Fehlman as reported. With this assurance, it is felt that the matter at issue will probably dissolve and normal conditions will prevail as a result of the inquiry of which the local Indians will be aware.

Reverend Father Scannell, the Indian Agent and I, in discussing all the issues with the Principal and staff, urged them to safeguard the interests of the Department, themselves and the Indians, by giving the closest attention to the removal of the remotest causes of complaint in order to avoid truancy and co-related troubles. They all agreed to do so and the meeting closed with mutual understanding prevailing.

Conclusion

There is no doubt in my own mind that the present agitation is a recrudescence of an attitude on the part of a few Indians such as has been previously experienced at the Indian Village of Sechelt, and that the same is a result of rumours arising from the unfortunate coincidence of death from natural causes of three pupils in succession, coupled with rumours of alleged ill-treatment on the part of a former school disciplinarian, who is not now attached to the School. These rumours usually grow in seriousness with the circulation of village gossip, fanned into intensity through the unwarranted interference of outsiders having ulterior motives or religious prejudices.

I beg to say finally that it has been a pleasure to co-operate with Reverend Father Scannell in looking into these regrettable complaints. He was most tactful and fair in his approach to and treatment of the matters under review and discussion. He will probably discuss them in person with the Department upon his return to Ottawa.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

C. C. Perry.
Asst. Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Sir:-

In submitting the enclosed report on conditions at Sechelt Indian Residential School, I beg to inform the Department that on May 11th, instant - the day before I left for Sechelt - Mr. Agent Ball telephoned me from Vancouver to confirm arrangements for accompanying Father Scannell and myself to Sechelt. He stated that in his opinion Father Scannell had been "playing for time" and that the "whole thing had been cooked", suggesting that Father Scannell had been in touch with the Church representatives at Sechelt and that very little progress would result from our investigation. I felt disturbed by his remarks and tried to dismiss them from my mind as I was anxious to avoid any prejudicial approach to the complaints to be investigated. Subsequently, I was satisfied that before going to Sechelt neither Father Scannell nor Rev. Principal Fehlman knew anything of the charges to be made by Mr. Ball, except that the Principal knew that Mr. Ball had not approved of the appointment of Mr. Morley.

I wrote the report on the evening of the 13th from my notes and, on the morning of the 14th instant, took it to Mr. Ball's office with the objective of going over it with him. I was reading it to Mr. Ball when he became quite irate and told me that the reason he had written such a report was that I was afraid of the Roman Catholics. He said I had gone to Sechelt with the intention of opposing him and the complaints which he had made. He said parts of the report were untrue, and that my reference to the doctor at Pender Harbour was in the interests of the Catholics and against the Anglicans as Dr. Connell was not prejudiced as he alleged I had inferred. It was obvious that I would be unable to make any point of contact with Mr. Ball on the issues involved, and so informed him. I then left the office. It seems improbable that the Department will esteem Mr. Ball's remarks as being conducive to maintenance of a desired morale in our service with respect to the Vancouver Agency.

If, in view of this report the Department should feel that a wider investigation should be made in order to give Mr. Ball an opportunity to fully defend his charges in the production of further data or witnesses, I shall not be out of harmony with such an enquiry, although I would not recommend that such action be taken as I consider the action already taken will be sufficient to meet the existing conditions for the time being.

Reverend Father Scannell, who investigated the Sechelt School charges jointly with myself, requested me to give him a copy of my report, which was done.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, ONT.

Schools reported many absentees at first and we had some difficulty rounding them up; there is a distinct opposition to residential schools in this vicinity. The reason is that the parents are able to supply their children with better food at home than they are given in the schools. Eventually, the residential schools will be used rather for orphanages and homes for neglected children than as educational institutions for the Indians in general, and day schools on the reserves will be needed. As the Indians become more self-supporting they prefer raising their own children at home, which is a satisfactory situation in many ways."

In the first part of the above report there is an inference that the Indian Residential Schools in the Vancouver Agency are not supplying proper food to the pupils. Please let me know to what school the Indian Agent refers and whether or not you have received any complaints regarding the food.

It might also be inferred from the report that the training that the pupils receive at the Residential Schools in the Agency is not as good as could be expected. Do you concur in this opinion?

Dear Major MacKay:

Acting on your instructions I visited the Squamish Indian Residential School, Vancouver Agency, today, without informing the school authorities or any other person of my intention to carry out a surprise inspection.

I had read a Departmental letter addressed to you by Mr. Hoey, in which portions of a report from Mr. Indian Agent Ball were quoted suggesting that the food supplied to the children at the Residential Schools in the Vancouver Agency was not satisfactory, and that possibly other conditions might be improved.

I arrived at the Squamish Indian Residential School at exactly 11:52 a.m. this morning, and by 11:55 a.m. I was inspecting the Noon meal then being served up and distributed to the different tables in the school diningroom.

This meal was an excellent one and a complete report on the food at this school is given on pages 3 and 4 of the attached school report.

Though my time was of course limited I managed to visit all the classrooms and make a thorough inspection of the whole of the school building.

There is no doubt in my mind that the Squamish School is splendidly conducted by the Sisters of the Child Jesus. As far as I could learn there has been no difficulty with regard to having the children return to school after the summer vacation.

I regret that I am quite unable to understand the Indian Agent's remarks. Is he trying to suggest that the schools are not being properly inspected and that I am not qualified for the position I hold in the Department?

To report that the children (at some school not mentioned by name) do not get as good food as they would in their own Indian homes appears to me to be a little far fetched and hardly a statement that should have been included in an official document. At the Squamish School a number of the pupils are either orphans or from homes which make it necessary for us to educate the children in a Residential School.

Great care is taken in all school inspections and though I of course make mistakes from time to time in my reports, many of which are typed under very adverse circumstances and often like this one late at night, any adverse condition in a school is noted and mentioned in the school report. I do not like these wild suggestions that things are unsatisfactory. I should be informed if there is some definite adverse condition which should be investigated. I am quite confident that the Indian Residential Schools in the Vancouver Agency are being administered in a very satisfactory manner.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Vocational Training:

I have seen the work of the girls and boys in exhibition and at the school several times during the past year.

The Manual Training appears to be quite satisfactory. The girls keep the school, an old building, spotless. They prepare the vegetables and cook the meals. They preserve fruit and make jellies, bake pies and cakes, and in general learn all those arts which will make their own housekeeping a success when they leave school.

Sewing, meant to be of the most practical nature, is undertaken daily. They mend, darn, patch, knit, and make dresses, underclothes, pillow slips, etc. Machine and hand sewing are taught.

Fire Protection:

There are some eight soda type fire extinguishers which I examined and found to have been tested and where necessary recharged in July 1936.

The representative of the North Vancouver Fire Department visits the school regularly and holds simple fire drills. Since my last report I have visited the school several times with visitors and on one occasion at least he has drill down the dormitories down the wooden escape and ladders. To-day the weather was too bad to again test the children in this way, but I am perfectly satisfied that they do have frequent practice Fire Drills. They are very good at this.

Some improvements have been made to the escapes since my last visit and a new door has been placed in the small boys' dormitory which opens out to the fire escape. Doors and windows are not locked but protected by an excellent type of electric alarm which sounds when either door or window is opened. This type of alarm was described in my last report on the St. George's School, Lytton.

Dormitories:

These were all visited and found to be splendidly kept. Floors and beds were perfectly clean. There was no overcrowding of any sort.

The children have plenty of covers.

Dining Room:

I visited the children at their Noon meal. As there have been certain adverse ideas expressed on the children's diet at this school, I arranged to visit the school on this occasion without informing anyone of my intention. Even those in the Commissioner's office did not know where I was going, nor did I make up my mind to visit the school till late this morning. I arrives at the school at exactly 11:52 a.m., when the Noon meal was being served out on the tables. This meal consisted of steaming hot mashed potatoes two slices of pressed beef raw turnip sliced bread, cooked pears. Tea was served with plenty of milk in it and some sugar. The Diet Sheet of the school was examined and is copied into this report, see Page 4.

There is no truth whatever in any statement to the effect that the children are not well fed here, nor is it true that there is any substantial difference in the meals when it is known that I am to visit the school. This has been proved by my unexpected visit to-day at a time when it was impossible to change the meal to any great extent.

Water Supply:

This is abundant and of first rate quality. The water is supplied by the city of North Vancouver under the same pressure as that available in that city. Fire could be fought, but on any outbreak the main thing to do would be to clear the building at once.

The Sister who copied the above for me does not show the breakfasts, which remain much the same from day to day.

In a statement in my possession dated November 16th 1938 the daily breakfast is said to consist of Porridge (rolled oats) or wheateats, bread and peanut butter, a cupful of raw milk.

Bread at 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. with fruit or raw carrot daily.

I consider the quality of the food supplied very good, the variety as shown above satisfactory, and the quantity given to each child more than sufficient.

During certain days and seasons of the Church's year the food would be slightly varied by substituting eggs and fish for meat on one or more days in each week.

The food supplied at this school is better than that placed before the children at other and larger Indian Residential Schools, though it is true that at certain other schools the food shows more variation than here.

I am particularly pleased with the fresh and cooked fruit supplied to the children.
Sanitary Conditions:

The great improvement noted in my report of January 20th 1936 and mentioned again in the report of September 25, 1937 has since then been well maintained.

The whole school from the dormitories to the basements and including kitchens, wash places, toilets, etc., has been again inspected and found to be perfectly clean.

The school is old but a large amount of repair work has been done each year for the past three or four years. Cement floors are being placed in the basements where shower baths have been constructed. Supervised baths are also given to the children at least weekly.

The old floors of the school are kept in a perfectly clean state.

I was particularly glad to find that even when no one knew of my proposed visit the whole of the school was in such perfectly clean condition. Great care must be taken at all times by the staff and children.

In the basements I noticed new saw dust burners which are a very great improvement to the hot air heating system.

General Remarks:

The children look well and very happy.

There was no opportunity for the children to change their clothes for the occasion, and I was glad to note how neat and well dressed they were in their ordinary school clothes.

It has been suggested in the past that this school would be better if the Principal was a man, and that the boys in particular would benefit.

This is a wrong idea, and no experienced Inspector of Schools could agree to such wild statements. The work of the Sisters of the Child Jesus here is quite remarkable. The boys do not remain at school to an age when their control is in any way difficult for experienced teachers and Sisters.

The conduct of the children boys as well as girls is very good indeed; their manners are far better than in many of the larger Indian Residential Schools where the Principal is a man. The local Missionary Priest is the Chaplain of the school. I hope that this school will be continued for years to come under the same excellent administration, for I am perfectly satisfied that the children are being properly cared for from every point of view.

If the Department has had the slightest doubts as to the education of the children being faulty, or the general administration of the school unsatisfactory, I hope that this report, made after an unexpected visit, will set such doubts at rest.

The school will be visited again in the early part of 1939, when a longer time will be spent in helping the teachers with their classroom work.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant regarding my October report with reference to Residential Schools.

I do not refer to either of the Residential Schools in this Agency particularly; as a matter of fact, the percentage of the per capita grant used for food in both the Squamish and Sechelt Residential Schools is above the average, according to the auditor's report, and still the pupils find cause for dissatisfaction.

An institution is restricted to the choice of foods which can be cooked satisfactorily in large quantities. On the other hand, where the parents are earning good wages, they are able to supply their children with a better and more varied diet than is possible in a school. When the pupils return home during the holidays, they notice the difference, and this is magnified to their parents, who use all kinds of excuses to postpone returning their children to school after the holidays.

As more Indians become self-supporting and independent, which is much to be desired, the necessity for residential schools as such will diminish, although they will still be needed where Indian parents are unable or unwilling to provide satisfactorily for their children.

The only definite complaint at Sechelt School was from two of the bigger boys who said they did not want "mush" every day for breakfast as it was not cooked properly. They said they "would like bacon and things like that." Rolled oats with milk and sugar are considered proper food and no fault can be found with the Schools for supplying it. Such things as bacon and eggs for 80 children would be impossible in any case. My report was in no way a complaint, which would be reported specifically if found necessary.

Sir:

I beg to report that on the 8th, 9th & 10th instant I held a meeting of the Sechelt Indian Council. As I have stated several times in the past, it is difficult to get the Council together for a meeting except around the end of the year, as they all meet on their main Reserve at that time. Many return at Easter but we never have a full Council except at this time of the year, consequently it proved to be a long and tedious meeting, extending over three days and from morning till after 7 p.m. each day. A number of resolutions were passed and are reported upon separately.

The Secretary, Ed. John, sent his resignation, and Reggie Paul was appointed in his place. These two men appear to take turns as Secretary.

Considerable time was taken up listening to complaints about Sechelt Residential School, which seems to be a regular thing at each Council meeting. A resolution was passed asking the Indian Commissioner to make the usual investigation, but I do not favour such procedure. One of the complaints was, as usual, about the food. The auditor has just audited the school books, and the amount per capita spent on food is one of the highest in the Province, I believe. The diet sheet showing daily meals appears to be satisfactory, and the pupils do not look undernourished. Another serious complaint was that a 13 year old girl was with children and was corrupting other small pupils. I had the new Medical Officer, Dr. Holm, examine the girl and as a result she has been returned to her Reserve. She states she was raped by an Indian last summer; both parties concerned are from the New Westminster Agency, and Mr. Daunt has been advised. The vice-Principal of the School keeps a record of the weights each month of all pupils, and except in a few instances, they show a small monthly increase. However, in future, the medical officer, who lives near the school, will keep these records, and will also watch the diet sheet, with a view to making suggestions when necessary.

The Reverend Principal, Father Connell, is interested in the welfare of the pupils, and will not allow irregularities in the School. The transfer, a few months ago, of the former vice-Principal, Father McGrath, from Sechelt School, was a blow to the pupils. The Indians who complain are those who no doubt are able to give their children more variety of food than any school is able to supply, they are mostly loggers making good wages. Logging camps generally are famous for the quality and quantity of food supplied to the employees, and I am afraid these Indians are apt to compare the school dining table with what they see in logging camps. Father Connell, however, is making some changes in his staff, which will probably correct any incompetence. Of course, day schools are the solution of the residential school problem, but the Department is committed to residential schools and we must make the best of it.
I believe, however, that if the inspection of Indian schools was carried out by Provincial Government School Inspectors, we would have a comparison between Indian and white schools which might prove most beneficial, both to the school authorities and the Indians. If we want to educate the Indians, we should at least know how our efforts compare with white children, and I think we should be surprised and disappointed with the result of any unbiased comparison.

The resolution of the Secteit Council regarding the School is enclosed herewith, but I cannot favourably recommend at this time that it be acceded to.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to truancy from both Sechelt and Squamish Residential Schools.

The Department agrees with you that there would likely be no permanent advantage in placing these boys in the Provincial Boys' Industrial School and consequently no such action should be taken if the Department is expected to pay for their maintenance.

Regarding the suggestion that three of them be transferred to other Indian residential schools I would point out that the schools mentioned have their full quota of pupils at the present time and consequently supernumerary grant would have to be allowed for the boys transferred. Practically every Indian residential school at the present time has its full quota of pupils and, therefore, they are earning their full per capita grant. As a result the Department is short of funds to pay the per capita grants for all residential schools for the December quarter and some of them will have to wait until the next fiscal year before payment can be made. Sir:

I beg to advise that I received a phone call on Saturday afternoon, the 2nd instant, that James Matrall, aged 13, and Donald Johnson, aged 9, left Sechelt Residential School on the 1st instant, and have not been seen since. I immediately notified the police and everyone likely to see them, including coast-wise shipping masters and naval patrol boats, and commenced an intensive search of the district myself. As their Reserve is at North Vancouver, the inference is that they would walk to the nearest point to North Vancouver and then steal a row-boat and attempt to row across Howe Sound.

On the 3rd, I followed the roads and on the 4th and 5th, I used a fish-boat and examined the coast line. Monday was particularly heavy weather with continuous rain and fairly big seas, and if they attempted the trip in a row-boat that day, it might have proved fatal. On Tuesday (yesterday), the weather moderated and search was continued without success, and I returned to Vancouver last night. They would probably travel at night to avoid detection. The Reverend Principal thought the truants might have been harboured by a former acting-Principal of the School, then known as Brother Dave, but who has since become a layman, David Gelpin. I found him in a bunkhouse or a logging company, but he apparently had nothing to do with the disappearance of the boys. This was the only clue suggested by the School.

The boys carried a quantity of turnips and carrots but would be in no danger or starvation, as they would probably break into one of the many summer cottages, where they would find canned food, and, of course, they may be still hiding in such a place. They told the other pupils they would go to North Vancouver and hide under the Squamish Council house, but they have not arrived in North Vancouver, and I put no faith in that report. The parents say they will commence searching today, but do not appear unduly alarmed. I will make a further search, but the Indian Commissioner suggested I report their disappearance to you at this time.

B/DH.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 6th instant notifying you that two boys had run away from Sechelt residential School, I beg to advise that they were found by a Union steamship official on Bowen Island, and have been returned to the School unharmed. They had done as expected, that is, they walked to the nearest point to North Vancouver and then stole a row boat, but on account of bad weather put in at Bowen Island summer resort, intending to continue their trip to North Vancouver when calmer weather prevailed.

They did not leave Sechelt until Wednesday, having lived in a vacant house since the previous Friday, which explains why I did not locate them during the period from Saturday to Tuesday when I was searching for them.

This affair has had one good effect. The School authorities claimed that once the pupils leave the School grounds, they are no longer their responsibility, and it is the Agent's duty to locate them. The Indian Commissioner has written to the Reverend Principal advising him that this is incorrect. I am surprised that although there are many men at the School, no effort was made to send out a search party - this has happened before when pupils have become truants.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has received two communications recently from Indian Agent Ball with reference to the truancy of two boys from the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

We are pleased to note that these boys did not suffer any mishap and that they have now been returned to the school.

May I point out that when pupils truant from an Indian residential school the Principal should immediately advise the Indian Agent who will give every possible co-operation in locating the truants. However, this action does not relieve the school management of responsibility. As soon as it is discovered that a pupil has truanted the Department expects the school management to put forth every possible effort to locate the truant, even though this will require travelling some distance from the school. We have had, in the past, some cases that have resulted fatally due in great part to the fact that the school management did not concern themselves with locating the pupil immediately following the discovery of truancy. I feel certain that in future the management of the Sechelt Indian Residential School will strictly comply with the wishes of the Department as outlined above.

Sir:

re: Sechelt Indian Residential School

For many years the situation regarding school matters at Sechelt was quite unsatisfactory. Unfortunately the school is built on the Reserve with the Indians living all around it and the slightest complaint of a pupil to its parents was magnified until the situation became quite serious at times, and one of the staff was actually assaulted by the Indians when he was on the Reserve. The Indians were sometimes justified in their complaints, which should have been easy enough to adjust but unfortunately some Principals seemed to resent the Agent's presence, although this was rather implied than actual.

However, the whole situation was suddenly cleared up with the appointment of the Rev. J.M. McGrath, M.I., as Principal. The change in the Indians was immediate and almost magical, as he appeared to have won them over within a month of taking charge. The pupils emerged from their downcast and sullen appearance into a happy lively crowd and this also seemed to improve their health. Father McGrath had not the slightest difficulty in controlling them, and has never been compelled to inflict corporal punishment. Although he appears stern and aloof actually his whole time is spent in keeping the school running smoothly, and the children contented. The pupils are well fed and well clothed and their interest is held every hour they are awake, there is none of the former situation where one would see groups of the pupils huddled together in the playground listless and uninterested and doing nothing.

Occasionally I have given the parents an opportunity of making complaints by asking how the school was getting along. Not only were no complaints ever made, but I received unusually favourable comments from the adult Indians. Father McGrath invariably invited me to the school for discussions on school matters whenever I visited the Reserve, and we were able to talk over any difficulties which arose, and settle them on the spot.

I was greatly disappointed to hear yesterday that Father McGrath is being moved from the School. The loudest complaints came from the Indians, the school being closed at present, and I know the pupils will be bitterly disappointed when they return. It will be a tragedy if we revert to the former state of affairs. We now have the confidence and full support of the Sechelt Indians, and I had hoped to see this continue at least for a few years more until they have forgotten their old objections and antagonism to the School.

From many years experience, I can say quite frankly that really successful school principals are not large in numbers and at Sechelt especially it requires more than a competent principal; it needs one who can obtain the fullest confidence of the Indian people. I do not know the reasons for Father McGrath's removal but if there is anything that can be done to retain him at Sechelt at least for a few years longer, I know it will be in the best interests of the Sechelt Indians, and that is, or should be, our main object.
I would appreciate it, therefore, if you would kindly support this request to have the Rev. J.M. McGrath retained at Sechelt, especially during these difficult times when the Indians as well as whites are under the mental strain of war conditions, and any trouble on the Reserve about the School would be even harder to handle on account of these conditions.

It is unnecessary, I presume, in face of the above, to say that I personally would deeply regret Father McGrath's departure from this Agency.

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C. Ball]
Indian Agent.

Re: Per capita grant for the Sechelt School.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

Would it be possible to have the per capita grant of the above school raised from the present rate of $170.00 per year to $180.00?

It has always been the policy of the Department to base the rate allowed for a school on the distance from the railroad and the general transportation difficulties. Although Sechelt is only thirty odd miles from Vancouver, it is very difficult of approach because there is no motor road and transportation by boat is a difficult problem in itself.

I am ready to admit that comparisons of rates allowed for various schools is not always the proper kind of argument to use in having the rate for any particular school changed, but I cannot see why the schools in the same territory and of easier access receive the $180.00 rate, and that it is refused to the Sechelt school.

Moreover, Sechelt is situated in a very rough country where there is not even pasture for milk cows and hardly any land at all for gardening purposes. All this contributes to the high cost of living and with its present rate, it is very difficult for the Principal to make both ends meet.

Hoping that you will consider this request and allow the increased asked for, which after all, will not mean very much in the general Indian budget, I remain,

Very truly yours,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Would you kindly forward the balance of the quarterly check immediately. I have not sufficient funds on hand to meet my obligations and I do not wish to have an over-draft on the school account again this month.

I am sure you are aware of the fact that it has become increasingly difficult to operate in the smaller school these past few years. The bonus and extra grant provided by the department has certainly been a real help to us and has been greatly appreciated, but it has not equalled the enormous rise in the cost of living. Anyone in a position similar to a school principal knows that the cost of living has risen much more sharply than the figures and statistics published by the Dominion Government on this question indicate. For example a pair of shoes may cost little more than they did before the war but the depreciation in quality is astounding.

In addition to the rise in the cost of living, Sechelt is entirely dependent on transportation by water. To everything purchased there must be added a freight charge of $4.50 per ton on tonnage shipments. If less than a ton, which invariably is the case, the freight may run as high as double that amount. Moreover we have no pasture for our milk cows (The Japanese farm we had for two years has been taken over by a returned man); we have less than one acre of very poor sandy soil for a garden. Hay laid down in Sechelt is thirty six dollars per ton.

It would require the ingenuity of a Philadelphia lawyer to keep this place on an even keel. Lack of funds handicaps me in so many things I would like to do for the children.

In addition to the balance of the quarterly grant I should like to ask if you could possibly arrange for an increase in our yearly grant. At present we are on the same footing as big school with farms attached and in close proximity to big centres, yet we must exist entirely on the $170. provided by the department. On the other hand we have not been given the same consideration as the other Sea Coast Schools.

Thanking you for your past kindnesses, I am

Yours very truly

H. F. Dunlop, O.M.I.
Principal.

"Dear Reverend Father:

We have received a copy of your splendid school magazine.

We would like to offer our congratulation to yourself, the members of your staff and the pupils who helped in publishing this magazine. It is one of which you all can be justly proud.

As a small token of our appreciation, we are sending you twenty extra library books for use in your school library during the coming year

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

We were very pleased to receive the above letter and I know the children were quite thrilled to learn that their articles were read even away back in Ottawa.

CHANGE IN PROGRAMME.

We have made a change in the school programme this year. We have not added any hours of class but have simply rearranged the classes:

Boys' and girls' in all grades take class together. All the children, boys and girls go to class from 9:00 A.M. to 11:30 A.M. and from 1:30 P.M. to 3:30 P.M. The girls take sewing from 4:00 to 5:30. The boys take woodwork at this time. There is no class on Saturday. Study on Sundays from 11:00 to 12:00 and from 4:00 to 6:00.

**********

CHANGES IN STAFF.

We were all sorry to say goodbye to Sister Anna Maria, Sister Mary and Sister Antoinette, who left us this term to take up work elsewhere in the Province. We wish them every success and happiness in their new duties.

This year the new Superior of the Sisters is Sister Matilda, who comes to us after many years of teaching experience in St. Mary's parochial School; Sister Stanislaus comes to us from St. Edmund's parochial School and Sister Lawrence who comes to us from William's Lake Indian School.

Sister Stanislaus teaches grades 3, 4, 5.
Sister Lawrence teaches grades 6, 7, 8.
Sister Mary of the Sacred Heart teaches grades 1 and 2.
SCOUT RALLY

FOR LORD ROWALLAN

BY DAVE FRAZER.

On October 25th Father Principal took us to Vancouver to see our Chief Scout, Lord Rowallan.

The rally was held at Brockton Point in Stanley Park. There were about six hundred Boy Scouts and Cubs altogether and about five hundred Girl Guides and little Brownies.

We Boys Scouts and Girl Guides were lined all around the park for about half a mile.

As the Chief Scout drove around in his car we all cheered. After he got off and came to talk to the King's Scout. Afterwards he came and talked to Father Principal, then he came over and talked to our troop. We were shy. So have a picture of him talking to our troop.

**********

KEEP SMILING LOUIE.

While we were in Vancouver at the rally Louie Lewis became sick. After we came home he got real sick. The Doctor sent him to the Hospital. He has been there over one month. Chins up Louie and we hope you will soon be back with your troop.

**********

Hallowe'en was an exciting time. We were all thinking how we were going to dress.

When evening came we dressed up and when we were ready we marched up to the stage behind the boys band. We marched around the stage about four times so Father could judge our costumes. The boys dressed up our dog "Butch". He looked funny with pants on and he won the first prize. Rose Peters and Esther August won on the girls side.

After that we had funny tricks on the stage and candies. We had ghost pranks too. The little children were frightened of the ghost.

When we finished our apples and candies we sang a hymn. Then Father told us there would be a picture show next night. We went to bed happy.

**********

The girls were glad to see Sister Anna Maria who paid a visit to the school last week.

**********
T.B.

TESTS.

BY WALLY MARK.

We had a tuberculin test last week. Everyone in the school was tested. It didn't hurt much but some of the little kids were afraid.

All the children who were positive had to get an X-ray. Nurse Gerry did the tests, Nurse Bullock did the x-rays.

In a month or two we will know how they turned out.

BANQUET FOR MR. TAYLOR. (BY A.JEFFRIES)

During October a banquet was held for Mr. Taylor, our new Agent.

The day before he came we decorated the senior class room with red and white and blue streamers. The tables were brought up from the dinning room. They were covered with white table cloth and fancy dishes and flowers.

There were eight guests at the head table Mrs. Taylor was one of them.

Four girls did the serving. They were Violet Williams, Sue Mitchell, Mabel Jackson and I. The Girl Guides and Boy Scouts were in uniform.

After the banquet Father Principal gave a speech to welcome Mr. Taylor. Mr. Taylor spoke to show his thanks. He gave us a holiday.

Then the Girl Guides and Boy Scouts gave Mr. Taylor the "Scout Salute". Then we sang, "For he's a jolly good fellow".

Later in the evening we had a show.

Auditorium-Gym Opened With Gala Evening

SF ALT—The new auditorium and gymnasium of the Indian residential school was officially opened by R. Taylor at the department of Indian affairs at a concert presented by the school last Wednesday night.

Culminating months of rehearsals, preparations, and building, the concert was presented to a capacity audience estimated at 1,500.

Father Dunlop, principal of the school, addressed the crowd prior to the opening ceremonies, and told the audience that the hall was "a dream we have had here for years."

The hall was officially opened by cutting the ribbon across the curtains on the stage with a pair of gold scissors.

The stage settings were the most elaborate yet presented at a concert here.

Future presentations of the evening was the two-act opera, "Snow White," starring Joyce Point in the title role. Pojo, her ever-faithful servant, was played by Doris August, while Esther Julie played the part of the vain and evil queen of poppyland, who tried to do away with poor Snow White in her envious fury. Here of the act, the Prince Henry Orpheus was played by Freddy Louie.

Capitivating the audience in this scene were the seven dwarfs. When they jokingly compared their slowness to the Union Steamship crew, there was big, real laughs of the whole evening.

Another highlight of the concert was the 18-piece string orchestra of the school. Rendering some very popular numbers, they were called back for three encore.

PRODUCTION

Gorgeous costumes and elaborate props made the stage settings the best seen at a concert here. All the costumes, from the beautiful girls' gowns to the handsome suits for the male actors, as well as the stage curtains, were made by the sisters and girls of the school.

Father Dunlop, Brother McGourty and the sisters designed the complicated stage props, while the boys helped out in the creative work, for which there was much.

The stage lights, very effectively employed, added greatly to the productions, especially the colored slides which lighted the stage with different desired colors. All light arrangements were made by Father Dunlop.

A boat ride was arranged by the younger members of the school, proved that they had learned something from the stage. While doing a duet of "Cruising Down the River," Shirley Julia and Junior Joe actually went for a boat ride across the stage.

In the closing number, Eliza, both and Joe Mitchell, backed up by the chorus did a well-received duet of "Good Night."
Superb Concert

(Continued from Page 1)

official opening night for the auditorium also marked the fulfillment of a dream for many of the students at the school. Father Dunlop in his opening remarks mentioned especially the two men who had worked so hard for the carpentry work, Mr. Morely and Mr. Temple; Mr. Al Jackson for his assistance on many occasions and many other times; the principal and staff of the Sechelt school for their cooperation; the thoughts of the whole Residential School in wishing Dr. Alan Inglis every success in his new work and expressed their sincere thanks for his work in the school during the past three and a half years.

CREDIT FOR LIGHTING

Credit for the excellent lighting effects went to Father Dunlop himself and also for his untiring work with the small performers and the re-written lyrics for the songs.

AGENT CONGRATULATES

Mrs. H. Taylor, Indian Agent with Mrs. Taylor was present and made a short speech congratulating Father Dunlop and the staff of the school on the splendid transformation effected in changing the old building into the new auditorium, calling it an investment in the future that had been made on behalf of the young generation by those who had made a dream become an actuality.

OPENING CEREMONY

The appearance of little Hazel Pielle, baby of the school, presented the very first occasion to Mr. Taylor for the cutting of the ribbon draped across the curtains marking the opening of a program that would have done credit to seasoned performers. The simple but effective performance was noted for the excellence of the music and the freshness and sincerity of the speech of the young performers.

CLEVER LYRICS

The first item "Big Shots and Little Shots" included Richard Francis, Val August, Roger and Russell Joe and Lloyd Jackson as blacksmith, fisherman, hobo, farmer and big shot, had clever lyrics that were well delivered.

SNOW WHITE

The operetta, "Snow White," children's stage, and presented with Estel Paul as a convincingly wicked queen and Joyce Paul as Snow White. The queen's charming ladies waiting were Gloria Paul, Anne Jeffries, Sue Mitchell, Doris Jackson, Mahla Jackson and Edna Paul. Dennis August made a mischievous Podglo. The eight dwarfs included Gloria Paul, Gladys and Hazel Joe, Phyllis Mark, Lillian Jackson, Florence Hurst, Shirley and Edna Paul.

DWARFS IN COSTUME

Snow White and all the seven dwarfs were cleverly costumed in sacking and red stockings with beards. Among the dwarfs' number included the Big and Little Shots plus Edwin and Phil Joe and Theo. Thomas.

PANS UNION CLEVERLY

In the final scene of the play where all her subjects were swearing allegiance to the new queen, Podglo brought the house down. You can count on all of us to follow in your band,

And I get there like the Union Band, probably be late."

CLEVER PARODY

Again the lyrics of a popular song were altered to fit the song "Every Commotion," Yvonne Shields and Eva Pielle on the swings and with Victor Johnston and Joe George for motive power and Georgina Johnston and Dolores Joe to balance. "It's a Grand Night for Swinging."

FATIMA CALLS DANCE

The new dance, "Buttons and Bows," contained more than the usual amount of fun and was danced and featured Clarence Joe, Elizabeth Mitchell, Junior Williams, Eva Paul, Dennis August, Diana Johnston, Joe Mitchell and Verna Hill. The singing made pleasant listening and the very well known square dance was added by Father Dunlop. We understand he is to be paged for the next old time square dance. Clarence Joe, Elizabeth Mitchell and Joe Mitchell with Verna Hill rounded out the numbers.

REALISTIC EFFECTS

The popular "Cruising Down the River" was the third number with the queen's sister Shirley Julian and Clarence Joe realistically cruising and singing by the old accordion as played by Moses Wilson.

EXCELLENT BAND

"Bowery Boys Rock," sung by the queen's maids filled in while the S.T.S. Band played its places the well played numbers. Here again the patient training and the hours of study by the band members paid off. The band alone was worth the trip in the rain to hear.

CHORAL PERFORMANCE

"You Can't Be True" was sung by several members of the band to give them time for the preparation of the stage for the finale "Good Night" and a better way of saying it could hardly be found than Elizabeth and Joe Mitchell's sweet voiced duet heard against the background of their schoolmates excellent choral singing.

IMPRESSION OF EVENING

For all it was one of the most enjoyable evenings and most certainly the official opening of the Residential School auditorium will not be forgotten by those who attended.

THANKS TO STAGEHANDS

Congratulations for their contribution to the lighting effects should go to Cagney and Adam Point—Junior Joe on the main stage and others contributing to Brother McGourty and Sister Rita and her Domestic Science class.

A patient called his dentist for an appointment today," said the dentist. "But I can't take you now. I have eighteen cavities to fill this afternoon." Then he hung up the phone, packed up his gold bag and left the office.

Dear Bernard:

I have just been told by Mr. Taylor, the Superintendent of the Vancouver Agency, that Father Dunlop is being moved from the Sechelt School. This has been quite a shock and disappointment to me as Father Dunlop is an excellent Principal and of the same calibre as Father Fleury, who you will probably remember, did such a fine job at the Mission Residential School. I do not know whether you are able to do anything in the way of retaining Principals at these Residential Schools but this move following so closely on the transfer of Father Fleury is to be deplored.

On the weekend prior to the 24th of May I visited the Sechelt School with Mr. Arneil and we were both delighted with the way in which the school was operating. The concert which was put on at that time was equal to anything that I have seen in Provincial or Indian schools. The academic work was also good and this June nine pupils graduated into high school. All this from a school with an enrolment of less than 100.

Unfortunately I have not given reports on this school in the last year so that the Department probably is not aware of the excellent work that is being done at Sechelt. I have purposely omitted doing this because the school has been so well run that I felt my time would be better spent visiting other places. Anything that you can do to retain Father Dunlop would be worth while.

Please do not feel that this letter is in criticism of Father Viney who I believe is to replace Father Dunlop I have no idea of the ability of Father Viney.

Kindest personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

We have a request from Superintendent Taylor to increase the authorized pupilage at the above school. We have received from him the following information:

Re: Sechelt Residential School
Your file 887-1 (El) Oct. 27

In view of the lack of dormitory accommodation at this school I cannot recommend an increase in the authorized enrolment. Dr. Tennant, the Regional Medical Supervisor, Indian Health Services, feels that most of our Residential schools are badly overcrowded and that there is serious danger of the spread of communicable diseases when the space between the beds in dormitories is so limited. You will recall that a year ago we had a number of cases of Tuberculosis at the Kuper Island Residential School which were apparently contracted from the admission of one child to the school who was a contagious case. The unfortunate occurrence at the Kuper Island School has convinced me of the necessity of avoiding overcrowding.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
