NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the septic tank, which has been put in exact accordance with the details, you will notice that the concrete baffle-plate does not connect with the top of the tank, but leaves a space of several inches, so the air is not sealed between the syphon tank, and the liquefying or digestor tank, it would appear that considerable odor would escape through the vent, this would be offensive and may prove dangerous from a health standpoint as it is it could be compared to a vent from a cesspool, further I have always understood that for perfect disintegration it is necessary to exclude, as far as possible, all pure air from the digestor tank, this could be done, in this case by bricking up the space above the baffle-plate and cement plastering on each side.

I have taken up this question with Mr Henry Crombie who has had a wide experience with septic tanks, he says, it is absolutely necessary in order to break up and fully digest all solids and the paper that this space be closed, when this is done you will have a perfect water seal; the cost if done now would be ten dollars. ($10)

Awaiting your instructions, I am.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the attached memorandum handed you yesterday by Rev. Father Welch regarding the Sechelt Indian Boarding School, I beg to report as follows:

1. Water Supply.
   The question of a water supply for this school is under consideration, and we are in communication with Inspector Tebb with reference to the installing of a satisfactory and economical water supply for the building.

2. School Furnishings.
   With reference to the furnishings required for this school, orders for same were placed some time ago and will be delivered at the school before the end of this month.

3. Fencing.
   The school authorities ask that the farm, approximately 20 acres, be surveyed and fenced. They also ask for some additional ground. The approximate cost of the fencing would be about $900.00.

4. A Meat-house and Root-cellar.
   A meat-house and root-cellar, with room over for the caretaker, are asked for. This could probably be erected for, approximately, $1500.00.

5. Barn.
   A new barn is required as the old one is falling to pieces. From information given by Rev. Father Welch, I would estimate the cost of the barn to meet the requirements of this school, at $2500.00.

6. Greenhouse.
   They intimate that a greenhouse would be very acceptable. The estimated cost of which would be about $3000.00.

7. Wiring Principal's Residence.
   They ask that the Principal's residence and proposed barn be supplied with electricity from the electric light plant now installed at the school. I would estimate the cost of wiring and installing the light in Principal's residence at $300.00.

RE WATER SUPPLY FOR SECHELT INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of January 21st, in reference to the water supply for the new Indian Boarding School here, would say on the 2nd inst. I sent out six requests for figures on this work, so far I have only received one reply, that from the Canadian Pipe Company. I also submitted a specification to a Mr. Burg, I think however that he is in some way affiliated with Johnson Bros. I enclose herewith these two Tenders. The tenders of Johnson Bros., and Baynes and Horie are still good.

I am forwarding the enclosed tenders rather than delay any longer, as the New School cannot be occupied until this work is completed, under present conditions we are unable to get water to fixtures on the first floor.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Inspector of Construction.
The water for the old Sechelt School was supplied through a pipe connected at a distance of one thousand feet from the building, to a main which supplies the Indian village with water. This point is sixty feet above school grounds. When taps are turned on in the Indian village, most of the water in the pipe is consumed and drawn past the connection that supplies the school with water.

In order to ensure an adequate supply of water for the new Sechelt School, it will be necessary to build a wood stave tank approximately 13' x 13' x 10", and make the necessary repairs to the existing pipe line.

Mr. Tobb was asked to obtain competitive prices for this work, and has submitted the following:

- Baynes & Horie, Vancouver, $2,083.00
- Johnson Bros., Sechelt, $1,780.00
- Canadian Pipe Co. Ltd., Vancouver, $1,750.00
- O. Burg & Co., Wilson's Creek, $1,700.00

Mr. Tobb's estimate of the cost of the work was $1,800.00 and I am of the opinion that O. Burg Co.'s price of $1,700.00 is fair and reasonable for the work, and beg to recommend that it be accepted.

Sealed tenders addressed to the undersigned, will be received up to noon on the 7th day of March next, for the Electric Wiring, and Installing Lights, in the residence of the Principal of the New Indian Boarding School here.

This contract shall include, the furnishing of all material, including wire, lamps, shades, shade holders, sockets, switches, panel boxes, and all outlets necessary to complete the work in a satisfactory manner. Contractor shall also supply all labor and tools, and when finished leave the job in good working order.

All work shall be done in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Canadian Fire Underwriters, and on completion a Certificate shall be obtained from the Provincial Electrical Department, if this building comes under their jurisdiction.

The current to supply this building shall be taken from the Lighting Plant of the New School, which same is located about 110 feet away. As the building to be lighted is not new, but built of frame construction, plastered and plastered, I would request that the wiring on the Ground and First floors be in metal moulding, and in the basement, where the joists are open, in knob and tube work. Dear Sir:-

Dear Sir:

FORTY SECOND REPORT OF PROGRESS ON SECHELT INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL

Dear Sir:-

The twenty six double desks, in use in the temporary school rooms, have been converted into single desks to conform with the new ones supplied, and are now installed in the new class rooms, the broom cupboards are finished, and work commenced on towel rails in the pupils lavatories.

With reference to the Lighting Plant, would say, the Generator appears to be of ample capacity to handle all the lights in the building; but the supply is not powerful enough to maintain the voltage at 110, with all lights burning, the voltage will fall to 74½. The Engine will stand up to load and maintain the voltage at 110, with about two thirds of the lights in use, and it will be a rare occasion that more than this number will be required at one time, if such occasion arise that more than two thirds of the number of lights are needed, it will be necessary to draw on the batteries.

I have received advice from J. Oliver & Son that the furnishings ordered from them have been shipped.

The water proposition, is the only thing remaining to prevent the whole of the building from being occupied.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

FORTIETH REPORT OF PROGRESS ON SECHELT INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL.

Dear Sir:

The staff have moved into the New School Building, and are now using the basement, cooking and dining in the same.

The Stove Pipes, for kitchen range arrived in due time and were at once set up, the Water Coil as supplied with the range is not at all satisfactory, it is a horizontal coil and the water does not circulate properly. I have taken this up with The McLennan, McFeely Co. and insist on either a water front, or a new coil being installed.

The Portable Bake Oven arrived and is set up, and the stove pipes for it are on order, it went together in good shape and I do not anticipate any trouble with it as it seems perfect.

The carpenter started work this morning, putting in the broom cupboards, under the basement stairs.

Have had no advice of shipment of Furniture ordered from J. Oliver & Sons, of Ottawa.

FORTY FIRST REPORT OF PROGRESS ON SECHELT INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL

Dear Sir:

The Broom Cupboards, under the basement stairs have been completed, ready for the painter, the Kitchen Table and Refrigerator have arrived and have been set up in place, also the stove pipes for the Bake Oven.

Regarding the Coil, in the kitchen range, which I stated in my last report as not working satisfactorily, I wish to say, I had the range-boiler raised four inches and now find it is giving complete satisfaction.

The Laundry Machinery, was used for a full washing on Monday, and the staff were surprised with the quality of the work, and the dispatch with which it completed the same.

The work of cutting down the double desks, taken from the temporary class rooms, is progressing.

The Electrician is here at present tuning up the lighting plant and instructing the Engineer in re-charging the batteries.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith the Annual Report of the Schelet Indian Boarding School for the Fiscal Year ending March 31st 1928, and to apologize for being so late in sending same. This is due to illness and I regret sincerely not to have been able to report any sooner.

Allow me, dear Sir, to tell you that the New School built by the Government at Schelet, B.C. is completed and would be ready for occupation if the water supply was sufficient, but unfortunately the water does not reach the first floor.

The Department had promised to improve the water system and as far as nothing has been done yet. I am afraid you may have put the plan aside having so many important affairs on hand. I see then to remind you of it and ask you to take this affair in hand and give orders to have the work started soon.

I also sent an application for blankets and bedding and since then I have not heard about this matter. We are in great need of the above mentioned items for everything was burnt in 1916 and at the present we have nothing worth to be carried into the new building.

Hoping you will grant my request, I am, dear Sir,

Your humble servant,

Forty Seventh Report of Progress on Sechelt Indian Boarding School

Re the New Water Connection for School

Dear Sir:-

Regarding the installation of the new Tank and pipe line, I wish to report, since same was connected up twenty days ago, there has been an ample supply of water for all domestic requirements, and pressure to give reasonable protection in case of fire.

The pressure by the gage is 127 lbs. at level of school yard with all outlets closed, the pressure drops to 122 lbs. when one of the fire hose is in use, and will throw a stream of water onto the roof about half-way to the ridge, from the ground.

At the present time the Y is set to deliver 10 gallons of water per minute to the supply tank, for school purposes, this appears to be a large amount being 14,400 Imperial gallons per day.

It is essential for the growth of vegetables to use sprinklers, the ground is little more than sand, there are usually two sprinklers in use, these are of ordinary size, about 3/8" discharge the two use 13½ gallons per minute, these with laundry and domestic requirements draw heavily on the reserve and at times practically empties the tank, but as stated before to the present there has been no shortage of water, only the loss of a few pounds pressure.

At the suggestion of Mr. Bitchburn, who went over the system with me I am adjusting the Y to give the school an increase of two gallons, making a total of 12 gallons per minute to the school, as I am particularly anxious to have an adequate reserve on hand at all times for fire protection.

The installation is a good job, and the working of the system up to expectation, although I under-estimated the quantity of water required by the school.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

Re Sechelt Indian Boarding School

Dear Sir:

Attached hereto please find report of working of new supply system for water to Sechelt Indian Boarding School.

This report has been delayed on account of the many leaks which developed when the pressure came on; this trouble was confined mostly to the tangle of pipes in the yard and gardens, many of these pipes were laid by using pipes which passed through the fire of last year and leaked badly under the increased pressure; considerable difficulty is experienced in locating these leaks, as on account of the nature of the soil, unless the crack or hole is not on the upper side of pipe water will not show at the surface of the ground, so in some cases whole lines have had to be dug up.

Under the old system, when there was little or no pressure, the mains had accumulated considerable quantities of sand and scale, this was loosened by the high pressure, and increased volume water and carried to fixtures of the new building.

The leaks above referred to have been repaired by me with the help of the Engineer, I have also cleaned out all supply pipes to fixtures and placed new washers throughout the entire building, so everything is now in good shape.

I understand Mr. Ditchburn has taken up with you the advisability of placing an outside hydrant, with hose and ladders so same can be carried up on to the roof of buildings.

The only further suggestion I can offer to improve this installation is that a Pressure Reducing Valve be placed in the domestic supply pipe, reducing the pressure to 60 lbs. on all the fixtures, retaining the full pressure on Fire Lines and Gardens, I recommend this as washers have to be perfect, to hold 127 lbs. pressure and will otherwise require frequent renewals.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

Sir:

I have to inform you that on the 15th ultimo I attended the opening of the Sechelt Indian School and availed myself of the occasion to say a few words to the large gathering of whites and Indians showing what the Department were doing in the way of endeavouring to educate the Indians of British Columbia, illustrating my remarks by giving figures to show what it was costing the Government of Canada in this regard. I spoke very plainly to the Indians as to their apparent lack of appreciation of what was being done in their behalf and told them not to pay so much attention to agitators who go among them leading them to believe that the Government were not doing anything for them. I asked them to help the school as much as they possibly could, more particularly in allowing their children to remain in the institution for the full school term.

I was very pleased to see such a comfortable building, practically complete in all its appointments and the Reverend Principal and the Sisters feel very proud of their new home.

I met Mr. Tebbs, the Inspector of Works, on the ground and went into many matters with him. I feel that he has fully looked after the interests of the Department to see that good value was received from the contractors for the money expended. I think it would be advisable that he should be kept employed for a further two months as there are a few things that will require some attention.

The building is practically fireproof from within and there is ample fire-fighting appliances such as hose and fire extinguishers, but I believe it would be well to install a hydrant on the outside of the institution to cope with any fire that might possibly take place from the outside, for the roof of the building must be watched for the future owing to the possibility of a bush fire taking place in the woods adjacent to the school or sparks from the chimney. At present there are no means for reaching the roof and the pressure from the one-and-a-half inch hose is not sufficient to throw the water any further than a few feet above the eaves. I would therefore, recommend that Mr. Tebbs be instructed to procure the necessary pipe and valves for a hydrant to be located at a suitable point on the right-hand side of the building. The work of making the connection can be done by Mr. Brown, who is employed by the Sisters as engineer. He is a competent man and a complete set of plumbing and machinist's tools have been supplied for his use. He is also a carpenter. It will also be necessary to purchase 200 feet of one-and-a-half inch cotton hose with couplings and nozzle. To reach the roof I would recommend that two short, removable ladders be either purchased or constructed, one to reach from the ground to the flat roof.

The water supply is none too good—plenty for the domestic requirements of the building but there are at present four acres of land under cultivation. The soil is nothing but sand though produces excellent crops if watered. To get results a number of stand-pipes have been laid and garden hose with sprinklers attached are used to afford a system of overhead irrigation. I found a number of these stand-pipes near the valley being worn out and I therefore wired to Victoria for one dozen half-inch hose bibbs to replace those out of commission. These will be found included in the account for the general hardware supplied to the school. In order that the water might be conserved as much as possible I directed that some of the stand pipes should be cut out and the sprinkling done from more central points in each garden plot. There will then not be so many of the taps to get out of order. I also ordered that the watering of the gardens should be done either in the early morning or in the evening to do away with loss through evaporation. As you are aware no doubt, the service to the school is through one-and-a-half inch pipe from a tank installed on the hill above the school but I found that this tank had never filled since it was erected, thus showing that the flow of the pipe is being used to its capacity. Later in the season when water is not needed for the gardens the tank will, no doubt, fill up. However, it is intended to clear up more land to put under crop and the need for water will then be greater than it is at present. It may therefore be necessary in the near future to provide for a greater supply from the springs or other source by the installation of a larger pipe to replace the one in present use which is a three inch one to the point of diversion to the school. Mr. Tebb informed me that two lengths of this three inch pipe was in a leaky condition and I would therefore recommend that he be empowered to obtain two new lengths and have these connected up. The force of water, however, may be increased by cutting off the supply from the Indian village to the Whittaker interests.
interests. This water the Whittaker people have been allowed to use through a private arrangement between the Indians and themselves. I understand the Whittaker people pay $200 to the Indians—this money to be used on the upkeep of the church on the reserve. The Whittaker interests include Sechelt hotel, store and a number of summer cottages. If their supply were cut off entirely the water, no doubt, would back up from the Indian diversion into the three inch main and cause a stronger flow into the river on the school. I spoke to Mr. Whittaker on this matter and informed him that it might be necessary to terminate any arrangement he had with the Indians but he asked, if possible, not to do anything this year as they anticipated having a joint water system for all interests of Sechelt undertaken next year. Dear Sir,

A report has been received from Mr. Bitchburn, with reference to a recent visit made to the new Sechelt Boarding School. He has brought several matters to the attention of the Department, and I would ask you to advise me on the following:

The installing of one or two hydrants on the outside of the institution in order to cope with any fire which might possibly take place from the outside. With reference to the installing of the hydrants Mr. Bitchburn states that Mr. Brown who is employed by the sisters as engineer, is competent and capable of making the installation if the Department will furnish the material. Kindly obtain and submit to the Department prices for the hydrant or hydrants and piping required, also for 200 ft. of 1-1/2" cotton hose with couplings and nozzle.

Two short removable ladders are required to reach from the ground to the flat roof of the Laundry, and two other from this point to the roof of the passage to the Chapel, and a short stationary ladder should be constructed to reach the roof of the main building. With reference to this matter, you may arrange to have the ladders built.

Forty Eighth Report of Progress on Sechelt Indian Boarding School

Dear Sir:-

Under instructions from Mr Ditchburn, (Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies,) I procured the material and I am constructing the seats for the sewing room, these are now almost completed, and are in keeping with the general furnishings of the school.

I called for competitive prices on the Pressure Reducer and necessary fittings, to install same in the domestic supply pipe, these prices should be to hand by to-morrow, and will be placed with lowest Tenderer, I intend to install the said pressure reducer myself as it would be quite expensive to bring men from Vancouver for so small a job. Tenders for Hydrant and the necessary pipe will be in any day now and will be submitted to you, this also I am willing to install if you so desire.

The new Range Boiler has been put in place and connected up, this was made necessary by the first boiler developing defects, as stated in my previous letter.

The Water System is working splendidly, and although the drought still continues, there has been an ample supply of water.

Constant watchfulness, and repeated instructions are exercised and given by the staff, on the proper use of the toilets yet in spite of these, at times some of these are choked by large pieces of paper or other material, up to the present time it has been possible to clear them with cup-pump, today one resisted this and I will have to lift the bowl, the sewer is clear, but obstruction is lodged in trap of bowl, otherwise everything is in good shape.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

Forty Ninth Report of Progress on Sechelt Indian Boarding School.

Dear Sir:

The seats for sewing room, as per Mr. Ditchburn's instructions, have now been completed and installed in place. There are 10 in number; in design they are a settee, but without arm rests, the ends and center supports are framed up; the seats are solid and shaped for comfort; backs are of strips finished with roll at top; the finishing consists of a coat of stain and two or varnish.

Regarding the choking of closet mentioned in my report of the 18th instant, would say, when I removed the bowl I found that two apples had been thrown into it; these had lodged in the trap and had to be broken up before they could be removed, as this happened in one of the boys toilets I took the opportunity of showing each boy in turn the obstruction while still in the trap by using angle mirrors, after which they were given a lesson in use and abuse of modern plumbing which I think will be remembered.

Some time ago I mentioned that the staff were furnishing and I had agreed to build a work table for the kitchen; this has been completed; it is enclosed underneath with three doors, and all the pots and pans used in the kitchen are stored within; it is provided with a drawn metal top, or work board, and furnished with a drawer for the Kitchen Cutlery.

Regarding the pressure reducer, authorized by you, I obtained prices from two of the dealers, and ordered from The Canadian Fairbanks Morse Co. Ltd. I will forward these tenders with invoice when same is received and checked; the fittings arrived yesterday; the installing will receive my immediate attention.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

Dedication of Indian School at Sechelt

When the new school at Sechelt was opened and blessed on the feast of Corpus Christi, the few of us there who had known Bishop Dupuis could but reflect upon what would have been the thoughts of that great missionary had he been present to see the imposing building built by the government for the children of the Indians he loved so well. He had died years ago. The school as we have it today is the outcome of his devoted labors. Others have worked and worked zealously for the Indians, but it was he who laid the Christian foundation broad and deep on which they have built.

Fifty years ago the Sechelts heard of the French missionaries and sent for one of the Fathers to teach them the true religion. Father Drouin as he then was went among them. He found several tribes, long distances apart, all speaking the same language and all asking for instruction. Sechelt was chosen as a central point where the different tribes could gather on the great festivals of the year. Only thirty miles from New Westminster, it could be easily reached, and yet in those days it was far enough away for the Indians to be secluded and by themselves. The place is of great natural beauty. The coast here makes a half circle around the bay. There is a long, sandy beach from which the land slopes gently up to the foothills, while from the shore there is a superb panorama of the mountains of Vancouver Island rising thirty miles away above the water.

After the Indians had become Christians, and the church (not the present beautiful structure, but an earlier building) had been completed, the Bishop brought from France the Sisters of the Instruction of the Infant Jesus. He called a meeting of the Sechelt Indians and explained his plan. He did not want their children to grow up ignorant of everything except hunting and fishing and logging. For this reason he had brought from France devout women who were ready to give their lives to teaching them. This, however, could not be accomplished without a building fit to house both teachers and pupils, and the school could not be had unless the Indians themselves were willing to build it.

These words made the hope for impression, and the Indians built the school under the superintendence of the Bishop. It was a frame building sufficiently large for their immediate needs, and it served its purpose well from 1904 to 1916. In the latter year there was a veritable epidemic of fires among the Indian schools, and Sechelt did not escape, for one night fire broke out in the laundry, and before it was discovered it had destroyed much of the entire school building and destroyed. Happily no lives were lost, but the Sisters now had to live in a building not much better than a hovel, and which was made to serve as dormitory, school room, dining room and kitchen. Their courage did not fail and they determined to remain where they were until such time as they could have a new school.

They waited for six years, but everyone who sees the large and imposing brick building which now stands on the hill overlooking the village knows they did not wait in vain. The school has cost the government at least $140,000. It accommodates about eighty pupils and is supplied with a heating plant and electric light throughout. The chapel is of good proportions and there is a large hall with a stage for entertainments. Taken all in all, the new school is worthy of the Department that has built it, and must come as a reward to the Sisters for the years of poverty and self-denial in which they elected to live after their arrival.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 9th instance regarding modifications to specifications for bungalow for the use of the chaplain of Sechelt Indian Boarding School, I wish to report after going thoroughly into the matter with the Reverend Father Plamendo, the chaplain of the school, who is exceeding well pleased with the plan and general layout of bungalow, but he with myself think that construction and specifications call for a far better building than is necessary for the coast climate here. We have a damp sometimes a chilly climate but never really cold, after a resident here for almost thirty years I have never seen the thermometer down to zero.

I will give below the usual construction of one and two storied houses and bungalows in general practice here, and while it does not enter the same class as your specification, it is plenty good enough for the purpose, and will stand and wear well without extensive repairs.

Note where no change is suggested the original specification will be followed.

EXCAVATION. Page 9

Excavate to a depth of 24" below grade level for the basement, and below this level dig trench for footings 10" wide and 6" deep, construct footing course of concrete as specified, on the said footings construct foundation walls 6" thick and 30" high, of concrete as before specified, all piers shall have similar footing courses extending 2" on all sides of finished pier. In case of the fireplace footings shall extend 6" on all sides and be of 8" in depth.

Basement Walls

On foundation walls, including the cross partition wall, lay sill of 2"x4" properly bedded in cement mortar and fastened to foundation wall in the usual manner, on which erect 2"x 4" studding at 2' centers with doubled 2"x 4" plate on which will rest the floor joists, all corners to be diagonally braced with 2"x 4" cut in between studding and securely nailed, on outside of basement walls, lay 1 x 8" shiplap securely nailed to each studd with two 2½" nails, cover with one thickness of tar paper with joints well lapped, cover outside to ground floor with No 2 xxx shingles laid 5" to the weather.

The cross basement wall to have shiplap similarly nailed on the excavated side.
MATERIALS Page 11

substitute Fir for the spruce specified.

Sheeting Page 12

Eliminate the inside sheathing, lathing direct on studding.

ROOF Page 12

In place of shiplap, except where it will show at the projection, substitute 1 x 6" roof boards spaced 2\(\frac{1}{2}\)" apart. This is preferable to close boarding where as thin a shingle as xxx is used, as it gives them a better chance to dry out. Dispose of rain water by placing rock pit at each down pipe, said rock pit to extend 12" below basement floor, or by tile drain discharging on road.

Storm Windows. Page 14

Storm windows not necessary, not used on the coast, screen windows and doors can be dispensed with, few flies or mosquitos, and the sand flies pass through screens.

DOORS Page 14

Should be 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" jambs.

Hook Rails Page 15

As there are no closets, provide and fix where directed 20 feet of 6" hook rail and hooks.

Hardware Page 15

Inside Doors may be hung with 3\(\frac{1}{2}\) x 3\(\frac{1}{2}\)" butts as specified, Outside Doors 4 x 4"

LATHS Page 16

Substitute fir for spruce as specified.

FURNACE Page 18

The Chaplain seems partial to the Pipeless Furnace; personally I have not seen them in operation, but no doubt Mr Orr is conversant with them, if they are satisfactory it would save $100.00 on this item alone.
GUARANTEE Page 19

This guarantee not necessary as it could not be demonstrated on account of the mild climate.

LOCAL VENTING Page 21

I think this will not be necessary where only one or at visiting time, at most three persons will be occupying the building.

Water Service Page 21

With the pressure we have here \( \frac{3}{4} \)" or even \( \frac{1}{2} \)" supply pipe would be sufficient for all purposes.

Door Bell Page 23

An ordinary rotary door bell or an electric bell operated by a dry cell would meet all requirements, as there is no kitchen, and would do away with the necessity of a transformer.

With the before mentioned changes this building could be completed for $2500.00 possibly a little less.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

In regard to our conversation on Sunday last regarding the trouble in connection with the sewerage system of the new school here, would say I have carefully examined same, and find the trouble is due entirely to the filter basin being unable to absorb the great amount of water entering it, first through septic tank, second the storm water from roof and areas of building, and third from seepage, as filter is placed on lowest point of school grounds a good portion of the heavy rains, of the last three weeks, falling in proximity to it eventually find their way into said filter basin.

The filter basin, in my opinion, is very small to care for the amount of sewage water entering it through the septic tank and was made four feet deeper than the plan called for as by boring we found a strata of coarse gravel at this depth, this under test carried off or absorbed 14000 gallons of water in twenty four hours, but this was in the dry season, now when the ground is saturated water appears to flow into it as fast as absorbed.

Effect on Septic Tank.

As filter basin, for the time being, does not absorb the water discharging into it, but rises to the level of the surface of the ground, water backs up discharge pipe into the septic tank raising the water in it to same level and interfering with the functioning of same, in fact converting it into a cess pit, so when sewers are flushed in the school almost crude sewage is forced into filter basin, and at times rising to surface of ground causing odors and consequently endangering health; there is also a further danger from water backing into discharge end of main sewer from the school, causing same to block or choke putting the whole system out of commission, and causing expense. I have taken it on myself to have an open ditch dug to lower water in the filter, and through it in the septic tank, in order to prevent the above referred to block, this is an emergency measure and cannot long remain.

There are two ways to remedy this condition permanently, first by constructing a pipe drain from discharge of septic tank to salt water below low tide mark, this would be expensive, the distance is about 800 feet, and would require a deep cut near sea front.

The second remedy would be to construct a filter basin 20' in diameter by 12 or 14' deep at a point about 75' south of present site, this would bring it over a raise of ground to a lower level and near the brow of the hill; storm water could be diverted by pipe to discharge directly over brow of hill, relieving filter of this. Rough estimate of cost First Scheme $1000.00, second $300.00

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Arthur R. Tibb,
Inspector of Construction.
Sir,

I have the honour to transmit to you herewith a copy of a report received by me from Mr. Arthur R. Tibb, who was the Inspector of Construction of the Indian Boarding School at Sechelt, which was completed last year. During a recent visit to this institution, Mr. R. H. Cairns, Inspector of Schools, and myself found that the septic tank at this school was not working satisfactorily, in fact its condition was a menace to the health of those in residence at the school. I met Mr. Tibb and requested him to thoroughly examine the system and report to me at his earliest convenience. This, Mr. Tibb has done and I would ask that the Department give immediate attention to this report, as conditions at Sechelt will not likely improve as the warmer weather comes on.

The Department's Officials at Ottawa, who give special attention to these matters will be in a better position than myself to make a recommendation as to the proposals outlined in Mr. Tibb's report.

Dear Sir:

In regard to our conversation on Sunday last regarding the trouble in connection with the sewerage system of the new school here, would say I have carefully examined same, and find the trouble is due entirely to the filter basin being unable to absorb the great amount of water entering it, first through septic tank, second the storm water from roof and areas of building, and third from seepage, as filter is placed on lowest point of school grounds, good portion of the heavy rains of the last three weeks, falling in proximity to it eventually find their way into said filter basin.

The filter basin, in my opinion, is very small to care for the amount of sewage water entering it through the sewer, and was made four feet deeper than the plan called for as by boring we found a strata of coarse gravel at this depth, this under test carried off or absorbed 14,000 gallons of water in twenty four hours, but this was in the dry season, now when the ground is saturated water appears to flow into it as fast as absorbed.

Effect on Septic Tank

As filter basin, for the time being, does not absorb the water discharging into it, but rises to the level of the surface of the ground, water backs up discharge pipe into the septic tank raising the water in it to same level and interfering with the functioning of same, in fact converting it into a cess pit, so when sewers are flushed in the school almost crude sewage is forced into filter basin, and at times rising to surface of ground causing odors, and consequently endangering health; there is also a further danger from water backing into discharge end of main sewer from the school, causing same to block or choke putting the whole system out of commission and causing expense. I have taken it on myself to have an open ditch dug to lower water in the filter, and through it, in the septic tank, in order to prevent the above referred to blocking, this is an emergency measure and cannot long remain.

There are two ways to remedy this condition permanently, first by constructing a pipe drain from discharge of septic tank to salt water below low tide mark, this would be expensive, the distance is about 800 feet, and would require a deep cut near sea front.

The second remedy would be to construct a filter basin 6' in diameter by 12 or 14' deep at a point about 75' south of present site, this would bring it over a raise of ground to a lower level and near the brow of the hill; storm water could be diverted by pipe to discharge directly over brow of hill, relieving filter of this. Rough estimate of cost First scheme $1000, second $300.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

MEMORANDUM

MR. MCLEAN,

It has been reported that the filter bed used in connection with the septic tank at the Sechelt Indian Boarding School is not large enough to properly absorb the discharge from the tank. This is caused by the excessive amount of rain water and also by the low-lying nature of the ground.

In order to remedy this condition, it will be necessary to construct a filter basin 20' in diameter by 12 or 14' deep at a point about 75' south of present site; this would bring it over a rise of ground to a lower level and the storm water could be diverted by pipe to discharge directly over the brow of the hill, relieving the filter of this amount.

The approximate cost of carrying out these very necessary extensions would be approximately $300.00 and I beg to recommend that Mr. Tebb who is acting as Inspector of Construction on this work be authorized to have this filter basin constructed at once.

Unless the existing conditions are remedied before spring, the present situation will be a great menace to the health of all those residing at the school.

"The water supply is none too good---plenty for the domestic requirements of the building but there are at present four acres of land under cultivation. The soil is nothing but sand though produces excellent crops if watered. To get results a number of stand-pipes have been laid and garden hose with sprinklers attached are used to afford a system of overhead irrigation. I found a number of these taps leaking, the valves being worn out and I therefore wired to Victoria for one dozen half-inch hose bibs to replace those out of commission. These will be found included in the account for the general hardware supplied to the school. In order that the water might be conserved as much as possible I directed that some of the stand pipes should be cut out and the sprinkling done from more central points in each garden plot. There will then be less chance of the taps to get out of order. I also ordered that the watering of the gardens should be done either in the early morning or in the evening to do away with loss through evaporation. As you are aware, no doubt, the service to the school is through a one-and-a-half inch pipe from a tank installed on the hill above the school but I found that this tank had never filled since it was erected, thus showing that the flow of the pipe is being used to its capacity. Later in the season when water is not needed for the gardens the tank will, no doubt, fill up. However, it is intended to clear up more land to put under crop and the need for water will then be greater than it is at present. It may therefore be necessary in the near future to provide for a greater supply from the springs or other source by the installation of a larger pipe than the one at present, which is a three inch one to the point of diversion to the school.

Mr. Tebb informed me that two lengths of this three inch pipe was in a leaky condition and I would therefore recommend that he be empowered to obtain two new lengths and have these connected up. The force of water, however, may be increased by cutting off the supply from the Indian village to the Whitaker interests. This water the Whitaker people have been allowed to use through a private arrangement between the Indians and themselves. I understand the Whitaker people pay $500 to the Indians---this money to be used on the upkeep of the church on the reserve. The Whitaker interests include Sechelt Hotel, store and a number of summer cottages. OTTAWA, February 23rd, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the water supply for the Sechelt Indian Boarding School and Indians' houses on the Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department agrees with you that your recommendations as to the action to be taken to overcome the shortage at the school should be carried out, and that any arrangement made with Mr. H. Whittaker, of Sechelt, B.C., should be terminated. A second communication regarding this matter has been received from Mr. Whittaker, in which he states that the school building and Indian Reserve have been without water for several days. We, therefore, sent you the following night letter of today's date:

"Second letter from Whittaker, Sechelt, regarding water supply make immediate action advisable. Please acquaint Agent Perry with facts and instruct him to proceed to Sechelt and take action recommended in your letter 12th instant."

No doubt, if the valve in the pipe line at the boundary of the Reserve and the Whittaker property was kept permanently closed, a sufficient supply of water would be obtained for the use of the school and Indian houses.

I shall be pleased to have a report at a later date as to the action taken by Mr. Agent Perry upon your instructions.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Memorandum.

Mr. Chene:

Certain parties interested in a joint water supply for the Sechelt Boarding School Village and Selma Camp have requested that we inform Mr. Agent Perry concerning the findings of the Dominion Water Power engineer. The intention of the Union S. S. Co. and the Selma Park residents is to form a little company and make a proposal to this Department concerning their wishes in connection with a joint water supply system. If Mr. Agent Perry is informed concerning the probable costs and the nature of the scheme, the interested parties from Selma Park will secure the information from him and will make an overture to the Department.

Re. Bungalow for Chaplain of Sechelt Indian Boarding School

Dear Sir:

According to the plans of bungalow no door has been provided in the basement, and while fuel might be passed through window, it would be difficult to dispose of the ashes from the furnace, except by carrying up the stairs and out by the front door.

I would suggest that a door 3'x 6' be placed in rear wall, with an entrance area 3'4"x3'4" formed of concrete same as, and of same thickness and height as foundation walls, and to be fitted or molded with three concrete steps, viz. four risers of 7" and said area to have concrete floor as specified for basement.

The Contractors have agreed to make this change for the sum of $25.00 same to added to contract price.

Yours faithfully,

Inspector of Construction.

First Progress Report on Bungalow for Chaplain of Sechelt Indian Boarding School.

Dear Sir:

On February 20, all dimension material, cement, and shingles for construction arrived, since that time the excavation for basement has been completed, the concrete foundations, and footings have been put in, and frame of building practically completed, the lumber was supplied by the Hastings Saw-mill Co. and the material is No.1, the contractors, Johnson Bros., do their own towing, and in course of a few days the brick for fireplace, and lath and plaster will be on the job.

At the present time there are three carpenters, one helper, and one laborer employed on the building.

AND the Contractors for themselves their executors, administrators and assigns, further covenant and agree:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractors fail at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractors for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such account and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractors, and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractors fail at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by them upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractors and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractors shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.
